The acting, characterization and dialogue sub-par as well, resulting in something silly, amateurish and empty.

reviews.review_title: A Sound of Wonder ??? I Wonder Why This Movie was made ?
reviews.content: If you are reading this review, you probably read the first 4 pages of reviews, and they are some of the Brightest, Funniest, and Cogent remarks ever written , which is really the Greatest triumph of the film, "A Sound of Thunder." A Ray Bradbury short story, has even a shorter life expectancy at the theaters, first and only run.. Mavbe it will make it as a "Midnite Movie?", possible ? All they have to do is add a couple of musical numbers, it could be done.Basically ,in 2055 a.d. time travel is made possible and entertaining as "Time SafarI" offers its clients the possibility of going back 65 million years to shoot a dinosaur. sound like fun, until the "Butterfly Effect " kicks in. Scientist turned time travel agent Ryer(Edward Burns) , is the lucky person who takes the people back in time to repeat the safari.Then, something goes wrong on one of the trips and time waves start to appear after their return. With each passing of the wave, evolution changes the reality, and weird things happen, and none of them are good.They really needed to re-edit the film and shorten some of the needless scenes, like when the Monkey Men attack the black guy. Way to long, and why didn't the hero just mercy shoot him, instead of letting the Monkey Men eat him alive, ?As for the CGI, the Dinosaur in Toy Story 2 looks MORE realistic... Like I stated, a lot of logic flaws, say, if you go back in time, and you open up a Time Hole, would the hole change history ?And , wouldn't you have a safety rail on the path ...? I appreciate a good Sci-Fi film, and Ray Bradbury was making a good point with his book, but the movie fails badly as drama, but succeeds on a hilarity level seldom seem...Also, it becomes ,ironically, TEDIOUS on a time level...Doesn't it ever end ?There were only 3 or 4 people in the audience when I went, which was a bad sign, since I had never seen ANY advertisement , and the film had set on the shelf for a couple of years, and they went BANKRUPT...BIG SURPRISE...That would have made a GREAT story....Even the March of the Penguins had a bigger audience !!!As the story goes , clichés' abound, scientist can't die, hero HAS to fix things...on and on....not like the book....Where did the BUGS come from..? I wish I HAD gone to a free screening....Ben Kingsley was GREAT, as he plays the scenes over the top as he HAS TO ... it has to be exaggerated to some extent..it is Sci-Fi...if you underplay it, it won't work... Actually, the most significant point Bradbury makes intentionally or unintentionally is that YOU can make a difference positively or negatively as to how things shape the Future !! Now that's POWER!!!Anyway, wait for the SCI-FI channel to pick up this entry, and play it between Anaconda 1 and Anaconda 2.....I wouldn't hold my breath for the DVD...It gets a 5 only because it WAS based on Bradbury story, and everyone still gets PAID... I hate to slam any movie , but this one should be placed in limbo....

Yes, this movie is ineptly made, but I found it completely enjoyable! I am a sucker for cheesy sci-fi, and I love bad movies, and when you factor in Giant Mutated Animals you have a WINNER! Here you've got Ben Kingsley going OTT as the ONLY way to deliver his character, Edward Burns putting his one facial expression to deft use, a lot of ludicrous exposition, special effects that wouldn't look out of place on an Atari 2600... oh, and did I mention giant mutated animals? That hunt and kill our heroes? It's not often you get to see such a horrendous yet fun disaster on the big screen, and I suggest you get some friends together and hot-foot it to the theater before this thing is relegated to 4am on the Sci-Fi channel! ----- Hey! Visit my website devoted to bad and cheesy movies! Cinema de Merde www.cinemademerde.com

NEVER see this movie!!!!! I wasted 9.75$ on this piece of crap. The cgi sucked!! I'm a big fan of SF (Sci-Fi) movies, but this was just bad. The cars in the background do the exact same thing over and over again and the actors are clearly walking on an escalating floor (like in an airport). And why is Ben Kingsley in it?!?! He's an amazing actor and should not lower himself to such horrible standards. Aside from from the horrible cgi the premise for the movie was good. Good story line, changing the past and having it come to bite everyone in the ass because they messed with time travel, bad effects. All in all don't waste your time with this movie, if it could even be called that. Maybe the second time you see it it'll seem better, but don't bother there are millions of better movies to watch in the world than this.

reviews.review_title: On my top 10 worst movies List
reviews.content: I thought the special effects were better on the Simpson's episode where Homer steps on a butterfly in prehistoric ages...Special Effects- bad even by Sci-Fi Channel standards. Idea of a subtle change in the past resulting in altering the future of the world was great (all credit goes to Ray there though). But why would it take 'time waves' to make the changes occur? You would think the main characters would come back to the present to see civilization in ruins- not slow changes to what it would be due to the change. I often laughed out loud at the 'scientific' jargon. Sure the power to the entire city is out- let's go to the university and use their "particle accelerator" that's now powered by a back-up generator. Many more like that...What could have saved the movie...? - Have the last character at the end of the movie leaving the past step on the butterfly anyway...

What could have been a good story was destroyed by the ludicrous time travel scenario. If something was altered in the past that changed evolution and humans never developed, the time machine would never have been built. If something from the past was brought into the present, it would have no effect on the past.I really wish film producers would run their ideas past an actual scientist before finishing the script. Even if you suspend reality and assume time travel is possible, you have to stick to logic.OTOH, Ben Kingsley seemed to be having a great time with his over the top performance. All of the other actors seemed to be doing the best they could as well. It was the writing that left them twisting in the wind."Back to the Future" handled it better.

Charles Hatton has made a fortune by founding Time safari, which offers rich 'big game hunters' short time travels to kill dinosaurs just before their natural death.When Travis, a scientist come adventurer, notices the weather and wildlife are not behaving as usual, he consults Dr. Rand, the contractually invisible inventor of the supercomputer which controls the time travel.They soon face 'time waves', each worsening the effects in 2055 of evolutionary distortions, lower lifeforms first.They attempt to identify and rectify the past alteration, but each attempt gets harder in their distorted present.....One that this film has going for it, is the sheer badness of it all, and its obvious that the studio more or less disowned this from the get go, because not many people have heard of it, and you'd be amazed the acting calibre that features in this.The first thing you notice, is just how really awful the special effects are. I know the film is nearly ten years old, but there is absolutely no excuse for a film, pretty major at the time of being green lit, to have such poor special effects.They are so bad, they detract you away from what is going on in the actual narrative. It's as if the studio have released the test screening, because response was so bad, they decided to cut their losses.The script is terrible, McCormack and Burns have a hard time with the script, and Ben Kingsley is credited as Sir in this, so that tells you a lot.It's a shame though, because this film should be more notorious. Here in the UK, it had a really quiet, no advertising DVD release, and has never been screened on TV.A must for all bad movie enthusiasts..

Based on the late Ray Bradbury's short story of a time-travel big-game hunting business that has some unfortunate effects on time itself, is adapted poorly here, with only co-star(and former Academy Award winner) Ben Kingsly giving a fine performance, as the head of the company behind the time-travel excursions of "time tourists", who want to hunt and kill dinosaurs(!) but instead quite literally prove the "Butterfly Effect", that is if you change one thing in the past, everything changes. That is certainly demonstrated here! Pity this film is so illogical, both within conventional time-travel theory, but even within itself. How can they keep going back to the same point in time, and not encounter themselves, since the dinosaur kill is a fixed point in time? Yet, the whole premise of the film has them frantically trying to do just that, in order to put things back to normal, and restore their time line! It makes no sense. Substandard F/X as well, since this sat on the shelf unfinished for years after the production company went bankrupt!

reviews.review_title: Be ready to watch one worst and bizarre sci-fi !!!
reviews.content: Did you heard something about these greedy Boss of a large entertainment company that works on a journey to Jurassic era to hunt a ferocious T-Rex, such Boss usually cut the coast of the system safe, yeah here we have the same premise, Ben Kingsley is perfect as rogue owner of this weird enterprise, Doctor Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) is charge of the journey process leading a small team having just two rich customers who coming along, they travelling back 65 million years in same spot, punctually, however the last travel one of the client bought at their boots a butterfly, it changing the past, starting many waves from those period with drastic consequences, lizard-monkeys mutants the whole planet was swallowed by plants, vines and threes, an absurd concept, even in craziest mind such oddity will be dreamed, all these facts surrounded of a second rate special effects, clearly to save money, get ready to watch a trash sci-fi!!!Resume:First watch: 2011 / How many: 2 / Source: DVD / Rating: 5

reviews.review_title: A good sci-fi movie but with some flaws
reviews.content: This was a decent sci-fi movie, and I've seen quite a few time travel shows. (Small spoiler here) You have time tourists who are warned that the slightest interruption in the past can cause a cascade of disastrous repercussions in the future. Here, the changes in the evolution of nature don't come immediately but instead through a series of time waves. The acting and special effects were good too.This is certainly better than the effect in Ray Bradbury's original story "A Sound of Thunder", where stepping on a butterfly 65 million years ago only caused a change in the outcome of a Presidential election. Now that's too much of a stretch.My main problem with the movie, as a scientist, is that the movie completely overlooks the mass extinction of the dinosaurs. Any interference with the evolutionary time line the travelers made during the age of the dinosaurs would have been greatly impacted by their mass extinction around 65 million years ago. However, no mention is made in the movie of the effect the mass extinction could have had on ripple effect caused by the killing of the butterfly.

reviews.review_title: I'll tell you what's science fiction....
reviews.content: I'll tell you what's science fiction...having Ben Kingsley and Peter Hyam's involved in this dung of a movie. I never thought Kingsley could actually act THIS BAD. He must've been desperate for money while being ill on the set at the same time.Banal dialogue, cheesy production values, terrible FX-CGI, wooden acting, etc., etc., Just think of what the concept (only interesting part of the film) could've been like in the hands of a David Cronenberg, Ridley Scott or James Cameron.

reviews.review_title: It may not be academy award material but it is infinitely better than another time paradox movie I watched recently that had a rating in the high sixes.
reviews.content: It may be a simplistic plot and it is true that there are some holes in the logic of it. However if one accepts that this is after all a fantasy so what the director and or writer says is possible is true for the duration of the film, then it is a watchable yarn that is entertaining without requiring any major effort on the part of the viewer; to work out what is going on (Pure escapism). Anyway as time travel is not possible at present (as far as I know) no one can really know what would happen or what would constitute a significant enough change to affect the present, or for that matter if any change you make has already happened in the past so is required to maintain the present we have. Although I doubt that killing a butterfly would produce the extent of change depicted in the film (or if butterfly's even existed in the caroticus era), this is fantasy and anything is possible, if you accept that; this is not a bad movie. It may not be academy award material but it is infinitely better than another time paradox movie I watched recently that had a rating in the high sixes.

reviews.review_title: Back to the Future of Sci-Fi Calamities
reviews.content: Coming from the director that supervised a classic like Outland in addition to at least plausible releases such as The Presidio and 2010, you can't help but wonder whether A Sound of Thunder is a firm heralding of Peter Hyams' professional twilight. How an accomplished filmmaker such as him signed on to a disaster like this remains a mystery, just as perplexing as the destruction of Ray Bradbury's venerable source short story.To pre-empt, what was a great read those many years ago now comes across as a poor imitation of vastly less intriguing concepts like Jurassic Park. Marred beyond recognition by shoddy production values and subpar performances, the original text barely makes a cameo amid the desolation.Thunder features Edward Burns and Ben Kingsley, two respected performers in roles they'd certainly live to regret. Burns plays one Dr. Ryer, chief scientist in a Total Recall-esquire firm specializing in time travel safaris, whisking ultra-rich clients 65 million years back to hunt for vicious dinosaurs. As greedy company owner Hatton, Kingley's hardly evident except for a whacky hairdo, whatever else he contributes (or tries to) makes absolutely no impression. There's some friction between his money-grabbing mantra and Burns' masculine idealism, however, you would need to be seriously bored to care either way.Naturally, like any story dealing in time travel and other meddling in the universal order of things, there's a cautionary note. Staff and clients must take care to avoid changing anything while in the past, lest repercussions chase them back to the present. We don't need to tell you this flimsy proviso lasts about as long as a short lived insect, but that's not where the surprise lies.What's surprising is how they went and utterly thrashed this project from start to finish. For starters, although set in 2055 Chicago, the cast is conspicuously British in mannerisms and accent. Save for re-colonization, what else could have brought about such a seachange remains obscured in horrible casting choices. Additionally, the CGI and other effects throughout simply suck, starting with the poorly textured dino and culminating in a flat, fake looking Chicago. They did try to include subtle touches like authentic bus colors and what not (those'll be familiar to windy city locals, nobody else), but in terms of appearance A Sound of Thunder makes straight-to-video look deep and invested.When things go awry, it's not limited to the story. Sure, inevitably some freaked-out client steps on a bug, sending devastating "timewaves" (those are visible and even make a roaring noise, by the way) towards an unsuspecting Chicago, where vines and other creepy crawlies emerge to take over the metropolis as reality devolves into a prehistoric jungle for some unknown reason.Only Burns and his posse can save the day, with not a peep from the National Guard. They battle several reasonably-conceived but poorly executed creatures while figuring out where and when the incident occurred so as to nudge things back on their proper track.That's the extent of it and clear indication you should give this one a miss. What was a very refined and startling Outer Limits-type story full of elegant suspense and menace became a garish, cheapened thrill ride minus the thrills. Embarrassing indeed for those behind this fiasco, the talent involved, and anyone gullible enough to pay for watching it.If there's any reason to rewind time, it's to prevent this from ever being made. Even if that takes stepping on a butterfly.Rating: * 1/2

This is a tough movie to review. First of all, I really like Ed Burns. I'm not sure why, but I think he has great charisma and screen presence and doesn't get the credit he deserves. And this movie has the perfect story line for a book and possibly for a movie if done right. But this movie's story was not told in a manner that was easy to understand and the special effects were absolutely HORRIBLE! I felt like I was watching a video game with real people walking through it half the time. Just unbelievably awful. If you can get past that it's not a horrible movie, but I just could not. The plot is pretty convoluted towards the end, but if you pay enough attention you can make sense of it. It's worth a rental, but only if you can't really find anything else. I say, however, give Ed Burns the right role in a bigger movie and he could be just as big as, say Brad Pitt, Ed Norton, etc. The man can act.

I know that "A Sound Of Thunder" is based on a short story and might not technically qualify for Book Month, but I did watched it anyway. It's mostly because I have in fact read the short story, for school nonetheless. You'd think they wouldn't be able to make a good movie based on a short story. And...they didn't! This movie suffers from terrible special effects. These are some of the most fake looking animals I've ever seen.There are these weird reptilian baboons that just look stupid. This film is also so amazingly boring. It is just what you'd think, a basic story stretched out to feature length with no interesting characters or good action scenes. Do yourself a favor and read the classic short story. It won't take as long as this movie. For 2005, you'd think it would look better. *1/2

reviews.review_title: Be warned, it's just a B-movie
reviews.content: No more, no less. Bad script, bad acting, bad story, worse special effects... just forgettable. Even the trailer is flawed by the obvious lack of money spent on the film. The overall impression is that we're viewing a bunch of clichés about the time traveling and the chaos theory applied to the evolution theory, connected through a poor developed story filled with gaps and script errors, from right the beginning to the end. Of course they've tried to conceal all those errors with the inclusion of not-no-nice special effects, a trend that's common those days, but even there the lack of funds is obvious, turning them into a minus rather than in a plus.My poor Ben Kingsley... what have you done?

reviews.review_title: Another one of those interesting misfires, uneven but intriguing to the end
reviews.content: Fifty years into the future, Travis (Edward Burns), a fine scientist, has sort of "sold-out" to a powerful businessman, Charles (Sir Ben Kingsley). With a great deal of species, such as the big cats, having finally vanished from the earth, Travis can bring them back to life with his genetic prowess. But, as a match made in hell, he must also re-create a prehistoric "hunting ground" for the rich, run by Charles. Folks pay big bucks to get a chance to bring down a T-Rex at their feet. Woowee! One day, a fellow scientist, Sonia (Catherine McCormack) invades the compound and gives everyone a severe tongue-lashing, especially Travis. According to Sonia, if anyone takes a creature away from the enclosed prehistoric world, even a butterfly, or makes any changes whatsoever in the habitat, it could have catastrophic consequences on the present world. Well, naturally, on the next trip, something goes awry and the world starts to change. Bugs get more plentiful, apes gain dinosaur-like features and the bats get much, much larger. Uh oh. Sonia and Travis, now allies, try to reverse the situation but, will they succeed? This is a complicated tale of the future, which never quite makes sense, but, which is interesting to the end. Who wouldn't like viewing humans do battle with an ape-a-saurus? The acting is fine, with Burns and McCormack doing respectable work, never over the top, and others like Jemima Rooper supporting them nicely. Kingsley, however, looks ridiculous, in wiry gray wig that gives him the look of an oldish Jamie Farr, and which makes his performance hard to appreciate. On the other hand, the art direction and action sequences, most made likely under budgetary restraints, are pretty darn enthralling. While the direction is quite lively, the story, based on a tale of Ray Bradbury, suffers from its complex translation to film and doesn't always seem plausible or coherent. Nevertheless, if you like science fiction, Burns, or technology-gone-mad story lines, you would happily sit still for the two hours it takes to view this one.

reviews.review_title: Sound of Thunder, what does that title mean?
reviews.content: This is a movie based on a short story by Ray Bradbury. I'm not one of the those people who is going to tell you how much better the book was than the movie. I find Bradbury's writing to be overly loquacious self-indulgent crap. That said, Sound of Thuder is one of his more interesting short stories. The premise is interesting though somewhat played out in this day and age, but the clincher is the twist ending from which the title is derived. The problem with the movie (other than the awful CGI); THEY CHANGED THE ENDING! I know this is not a new phenomenon in Hollywood, but i have already said i feel this was the best part of the story. Add to that the fact that the title now makes to sense at all. I think the movie version of H.G. Wells' "Time Machine" is the best comparison for this picture. Started with a good story, good actors, and then screwed it up beyond recognition.

reviews.review_title: A remake of a remake of several originals
reviews.content: Simple indeed. A dramatic rewriting of "Back to the Future". But this time it is back to the past. If you play with time and manage to take people for ten minutes to the time of dinosaurs, in order to make money of course, you are playing with more than fire, with genetic dynamite. The slightest change in the past environment, or the slightest souvenir, willful or not, brought back from the past to the present will change the whole genetic perspective and the present will be transformed because the past will have been. One simple insect missing in the past may have drastic consequence son the evolution of life on the planet.Maybe one insect is a little bit too little, and yet that absent insect will mean that some other being on the chain will not find its food and some flowers will not get pollinated, and a whole drastic transformation may be introduced in the run of millions of years. Keep in mind each creature, each vegetal organism in this life is the prey of some predator, the food of some living organism. That basic Darwinian rules can cause miracles and catastrophes if it is tampered with.The film is just that kind of idea implemented in 2055. It is creative as for some of the beasts, though it is rather simple as for the general idea. Man becoming the prey of some new species was already worked on by H.G. Wells in his "Time Machine", and setting the future right by correcting the change in the past your inattention caused was the main argument of "Back to the Futur"e. So you should enjoy the simple plot and the beautiful adventure.The monsters are yet far from the creatures of "Avatar" or "Aliens" and the change seems to have blocked the evolution line so that no intelligent species of the human type was produced by the mistake. I doubt that one very much. If evolution there is and animal life there is Darwin's evolution of species can be stated as a general rule and an intelligent species should appear. That's why we can say that in the whole cosmos there must be several planets with intelligent life. They will not necessarily look like man physically but intellectually there is a fair chance the same articulated and logical intelligence will be produced, eventually and unavoidably.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

reviews.review_title: Crappy Dino Pic... with Ben Kingsley
reviews.content: Oh man, what a horrible film! Acting is pretty atrocious in this one. What's most devastating of all is the mis-use of such actors as Ben Kingsley and Edward Burns. Yes, THE Ben Kingsley! The same man who played in such classics as GANDHI and SCHINDLER'S LIST. Like most of the crappy films they show on Syfy, this movie features quite a bit of fake-looking CGI effects. In this case, mainly dinosaur effects.Now here's the incomprehensible story: In the not-too-distant future, a team of scientists/ explorers have discovered a way of teleporting wealthy hunters back in time to the Jurassic period. They're led by Edward Burns as their guide, whose know-it-all smartass attitude quickly rubs you raw. Back in the Jurassic, they are given a five minute window of opportunity. Before a nearby volcano erupts, a terrifying Allosaur is about to become bogged down in a swamp. And the hunters have the chance of killing that dinosaur before the five minutes are up. They are given specific rules too: Don't leave the trail. Don't touch anything. Don't leave anything behind. However, as you might imagine, all does not go well. What follows is, literally, the butterfly effect. As now, back in the future, waves upon waves of evolutionary change occur. And yes, Edward Burns and an equally-excruciating female scientist must go back in time to set things right.Please gentle viewer avoid this film at all costs, even if you're a die-hard Ben Kingsley fan. This is clearly his worst role ever!

... yet not bad enough to be "good." I loved the short story. I even liked the old "Ray Bradbury Presents..." short that was done of the story back in the 80's. There is great potential for a real thinker's "time travel paradox" movie.This doesn't do it.As others have commented, the absolutely pathetic effects are one of the first things that grab your attention. While I tried to grit my teeth through them, they are simply too distracting and completely prevent you from suspending disbelief.I can understand that the screenwriters would take some liberties with the concept of how a time travel paradox might unfold -- after all, who really knows? -- but the lack of basic logic compounded with an appalling butchery of high school evolution was appalling. For a movie which pretends to play the role of "science" fiction it falls decidedly short.He "stepped on evolution" indeed...

reviews.review_title: the worst thing about a bad movie is the money spent on it
reviews.content: This is a pitiful movie. What makes it even more pitiful is the time, effort and money put into a super predictable script and action.It's about some kind of monsters, by the way, and some kind of insects. Don't expect an explanation of the plot. There is none. That might work, if there was something of interest, or characters we could care about. There isn't. Everything that happens to any person is as predictable as the other movies Sci Fi channel does.Don't try to understand what some of the characters are saying. They speak gibberish, especially the annoying lead woman, whose accent is a sort of thick British that is harder to understand than any old British movie you may have seen. She's unintelligible.A lot of money is spent on some great sets and scenery, and that is the major crime of this movie, because it just isn't worth it.

Yea, it is a mess, but it has a certain charm. It would be a shame if you were suckered into watching it not knowing some of the problems beforehand. I found some of the effects to be rather good, the time waves and the ape creatures for example. The serpent is really awful, as are some of the city scenes. I guess the effects will be updated for the DVD release next year. It would be a shame to leave the movie the way it is. I feel sorry for the actors, especially David Oyelowo; Player in the Royal Shakespeare Company and the first black man cast as the King of England, he must have felt great to have a substantial part in what seemed like a Hollywood blockbuster only to have the overall movie turn out to be a steaming pile of muck. My rating would change if the effects were substantially updated.
At starting i thought i would be good to watch.. But after a while feel boring although understanding the movie..vfx are too immature and bad screenplay...

When a hunter sent back to the prehistoric era runs off the path he must not leave, he causes a chain reaction that alters history in disastrous ways.I've read the short story the movie is based on. I really liked it. It was very ingenious and clever. I loved it so much that when a movie is based off this film, I find it hard to believe the movie may mess up. Well, I was wrong. How could someone make a movie so bad, based on a very good story?What's the huge flaw(s) for this film? Yes, there are some good special effects for this film but mostly, it's really bad, if you get what I mean. They don't mix and match well with the actors on screen. Fortunately, here and there, you get some great production values.Another flaw is the stupid logic and inaccuracies not made from the book. I'm not saying movies that don't follow the books is a bad thing but there is one thing in here that is so annoying, that they probably used it to make the movie more "entertaining" and "suspensful."However, I do admire this film's potential to be entertaining. There are some parts in the film that certainly makes you feel like you're watching a popcorn film. I was thinking, why not make this film have a bigger budget and a bigger cast to make it a Hollywood blockbuster?This film certainly had a big potential, but there were just a lot of problems. It could've been an entertaining monster movie (with its situations set in a way where characters die one by one). In the end, it was a huge disappointment. There is a bit of predictability here and that's all you'll get.

Bloody awful! There's just no other way to put it. In fact, it's **SO** bad that the only reason I'm wasting words on this is to warn off other reasonable viewers who want to be intelligently entertained. You'll lose I.Q. points watching this. Come to think of it, it's not even suitable for mindless viewing because of the irritation factor. There's no guilty pleasure in watching something this incompetent.Reasons to avoid it:1) Horribly scientifically inaccurate, to the point where this isn't sci-fi anymore, it's just mindnumbingly sloppy, lazy fantasy.2) It sports FX that are cheesy beyond belief. Not even cheesy-kitsch that's a wink and a nod, like vintage Doctor Who, but just cheap and shoddy to the point of being insulting. The FX are so bad they're not even laughable. They spent about a dollar-fifty on this, not more.3) The direction is so weak and mindless that the only way the actors could make it through to the end of shooting without becoming terminally depressed was to sleepwalk through their roles, although Catherine McCormack made some effort anyway, probably on principle and despite the director. Moreover, this isn't Peter Hyams's only bad film: his flubs vastly outnumber any barely salvageable ones, of which Timecop was the last such, and that was 15 years before this writing. he's had nothing halfway decent since (End Of Days was just as slapdash, Arnold was the only draw, and he needed much firmer direction than Hyams provided). Hyams just keeps making it more and more pointless for anyone to consider giving him more work.And finally,4) Ray Bradbury's stories deserve far better treatment than this. Refusing to watch this film sends that message, not that Hollywood is particularly listening.Watch at your own risk. If you do and it turns you off movies altogether, you've only yourself (and Hyams) to blame because you've been more than adequately warned.

big disappointment, I read about this movie in a magazine a few years back and was excited about seeing it, there was talk of a big budget and star power, what happened? this movie had such potential, 1/3 action 1/3 sci-fi and 1/3 mystery. special effects were laughable. one scene in the beginning shows the main character and a woman walking down the street, it was so painfully obvious they were walking in place. every part of the movie was flawed, but the concept was good. except too many conveniences. everybody and every place in the movie was within walking distance. hope this helps. ten year olds might get a kick out the dinosaurs and creatures. adults, buy some fish and watch them.

Man, I went to this movie because of the great preview. It looked like it had a great story and nice special effects.Boy was I wrong. I wanted to walk out of the theater because of those horrible special effects. A cartoon dino, of cart board would do even a better job then this. The story was fine, if it would have been taken on by a big movie producer. Who would trow in some more money to make the effect more life like. The only thing I liked about this movie where the plants that pop up everywhere.Even worse where the cars, in one scene 2 characters walk along the street. If you watch those cars you'll see the following: Taxi, car, motorcycle, tri-pod, big bus. And about 4x in a row!And then there is the "butterfly death" that would set the whole "evolution changes" in to progress. If that guy didn't step on the butterfly, the next dino would have eaten it anyway! So that's absolute bull. Then, if you change something in the past, the future will be different in the same instant. Not in those "time waves" they made. reviews.review_title: Yeah, it's bad, but it's thoroughly watchable
reviews.content: I started watching this movie knowing that it was going to be bad, so maybe that's why I'm not all that repelled by it. Make no mistake, "A Sound Of Thunder" is really, really bad. It's got quite possibly the worst CGI I've ever seen in a movie that relies on special effects. Of course, you can blame it on bad luck because the studio had to fight with financial difficulties at the time of production, but with a script as full of plot holes and dodgy lines as this one I doubt that even under the best circumstances would this have become much better than say "Paycheck" - definitely not as long as Hollywood-botcher Peter Hyams was going to direct.Still, it's hard to mess up a premise as intriguing and promising as the one of Ray Bradbury's classic short story, although the makers of this movie really try their best by moving as far away from it as possible. There were a thousand ways they could have gone from Bradbury's outline, yet they chose to turn this into "Evolution II".Hell, the movie is still somewhat entertaining. Maybe I'm just a sucker for evolution-gone-wrong-movies, but I didn't really get bored watching this (although watching Edward Burns' wooden acting is about as exciting as watching paint dry).No, "A Sound Of Thunder" isn't a masterpiece and it's damn frustrating that it isn't. Under the right direction and with the right budget this movie could have been really good. As it is, it's a watchable little videostore item that deserves the bad reputation it's got, but that still has more heart than most other b-movies out there.

Those of us of a certain age will remember the greatest comic-books ever; the EC comics of the 1950's. One issue of a particular comic freely "borrowed" the Ray Bradbury short story "A sound of thunder" for adaptation and produced a seminal comic-book work. Bradbury noticed and initially protested to EC, but the company and the author came to an arrangement whereby EC would adapt many of Bradbury's short stories to the comics medium, thus providing us comic readers with many wonderful comics stories. This particular story was also re-adapted in Ray Bradbury Comics many years later. The new film has expanded upon what was, after all, only a short 'cautionary tale' type story, otherwise it would have been a very thin film indeed. I found the film thoroughly enjoyable and certainly not out of place in today's movie world. It is thrilling and fun and definitely worth a couple of hours of anyone's time.

For those who don't mind deciphering yet another plot with a time puzzle, this one designed by Ray Bradbury, who (satirically) comments a delicate predicament with evolution such that the mere destruction of a butterfly at a very beginning point in time - the prehistoric era - could upset later events. Chances are the alteration of events could be very minor with one less butterfly from the Crustacean Era, but suppose that one-in-a-million occurs and the chain-reaction due to an altered event causes a disturbance, such as the one depicted in the movie. In general, a plot such as this may be undergo criticism as one with a far-reaching or far-fetched concept, stretching our minds too far over another type of time dilemma in the prehistoric past. But for the scientific and ethically-minded, the story supports a moral with a credibility factor yet unproven (i.e., there is no way to disprove the credibility of such a plot - time has already passed). Additionally, it is expressing a scheme of balance at an early point in time, where the felling of a clumsy dinosaur isn't necessarily a critical event (dinosaurs killed one another off and eventually became distinct from the ice age); but on the other hand - the other end of the spectrum - the delicate existence of a butterfly does matter. For skeptics, remember that the events we are focusing on are at a very beginning point in time-life history of our planet, where such an altered event could matter. In other words, the will of God's hand was to exact the very beginning of life with a thundering herd of dinosaurs balanced by the paradox of another side of life, one that is harmless although delicate The moral, of course, is the consequences of tampering with nature, even the mere act of killing a butterfly out-of-sequence with evolution.For entertainment, the film provides enough action to keep you riveted to the screen, but follows in a sense, the way other action-adventure films are made. This doesn't disqualify its uniqueness, however, for an adventure-type movie utilizing its own repertoire of villainous monsters (apparently mis-created due to the time-event accident).The acting may be a bit over-rounded in some places but with some spunk as well, the dialogue not intending to be the highlight of a time-puzzling sci-fi plot.

I watched it on DVD one week ago. From very beginning it made bad impression. Interesting is that picture was very dark, so I need to go in some extra settings to make it lighter (was it maybe to cover 'not to developed' CGI? ). I looked for Ray Bradbury's short story with same title as movie. It is quite good, and well balanced - considering it's length.So, first problem with movie is title itself - it is shame to change book so much, and keep the title, especially because part of story where 'thundering' occurs is not present in movie.They put unnecessary textual intro where explained about time-travel in 2055, but all it can be guessed in first 15 minutes of movie. Then it starts right with 'dino-hunt'. Very lame made. I doubt that someone would pay lot of money for so limited hunting. In book limit was to not step out from path, and to shoot only marked animals. In movie was only one target, and whole 'hunting' looked pretty poor, not to mention bad CGI and even worse sound effects (nothing from 'thundering' allosaurus voice). However, as usual, script is worse part - it makes not sense. Limiting kills in area which will be destroyed after 5 minutes by big volcano eruption? And of course, whole 'butterfly effect' looses sense. I don't know origin of phrase - was it by Ray Bradbury? Of course, whole time-paradox issue is actually problematic, but at least Bradbury kept it on some reasonable level of logic.Then came some corrupted businessman whit glowing white hair. I needed couple minutes to recognise Ben Kingsley. Again ask myself: how such crap scenarios can attract good actors as Kingsley or Catherine McCormack? Or it was budget of (supposedly) 80 million dollars? Is CGI so bad, because they ran out of money?In second half of movie starts the 'monster chase' - is it obsession of Peter Hyams in last years? Cheap entertainment, instead of great possibilities with books 'alternative political reality'. Idea of 'time-waves' lacks any physical sense, and I really wonder why Hollywood likes to film scripts with such 'makes no sense, but sounds-good' rubbish.Too bad - I believe that with some decent script it could be much better. It would motivate more director, actors, set makers etc. But, as I saw there is lot of producers, and then usually nothing goes right. To say something positive: Catherine McCormack was pretty good in all this mess. Only because of her: 4/10 .

reviews.review_title: See this movie it is worth your time.

reviews.review_title: A good bad movie that could have been better
reviews.content:
"A Sound of Thunder" was great. By that, I mean the short story. The movie on the other hand? Well, the premise is that they changed the past and now, it is changing the future. It happens in these time waves that look like tsunamis, and each time the wave changes one thing, until it eventually changes everything with a scientist and an anti-time travel software engineer trying to stop it. It's a cool premise, but it didn't work so well in the movie.
A Sound of Thunder directed by Peter Hyams and written by Thomas Dean Donnelly, Joshua Oppenheimer, and Gregory Poirier. The main actors are Edward Burns, Ben Kingsley, and Catherine McCormack. It was released in 2005. A rich guy (Ben Kingsley), starts a time safari, where one of the tourists accidentally messes up time by killing a butterfly. Then, it is up to time traveling scientist Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) and the software engineer who designed the computer that controls the time travel, Dr. Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack) to go back in time and fix everything.
A Sound of Thunder opens with the main characters on a safari, hunting an Allosaurus. After they kill it and return to the present, Travis (Edward Burns) meets Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormack), who explains why they shouldn't be messing with the past. Travis explains why he is doing it and they form a mutual respect for each other. After the next safari goes awry, Travis goes to Dr. Rand's apartment, where they find that a time wave has hit and the world has started changing, which starts their journey to repair time and try to save the world.
The main character, Travis (Edward Burns), was a very interesting character. He is a scientist, safari guide, and he is the lead hunter on the safari. He is an antihero who is part of the Time Safari that messes with time for money. He claims he only does it to research extinct animals, but Rand doesn't believe him. He is also a static character, he does not change, or become better through the movie. He just fluctuates between smart scientist and Navy SEAL throughout the movie. It doesn't make him a super likable character, you just have to take the producer's word that he is a good guy and that he isn't just saving humanity to save himself.
Overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who is willing to overlook plot holes and have a silly bad movie to convince yourself that even you could become a CGI artist in Hollywood. The CGI is pretty bad, the acting isn't near Oscar-worthy, and the dialogue can be juvenile at times. While I can recognize that this movie changed a lot, from actors to directors, was even shelved for a time, and ran out of money, I firmly believe it should have stayed on the shelf. It is a three out of ten in my book, only because it is just bad enough to make it enjoyable if you want that kind of entertainment.

Monkeysaurus's, giant bats, sea snakes, and killer plants! Mix that all in with dinosaurs and time travel? I have to say that this has to be one of the most unique takes on sci-fi that I have seen in a very long time.I agree that with a huge budget, this movie should have rocked. But if you don't go into it with any expectations it really is an entertaining movie. Don't pay any attention to the horrible special effects. When Travis and Jenny are walking down the street, I swear the same white bus passes her like 12 times! And don't pay attention to the logical flaws. The last species to evolve (humans) should have been the first species affected in a time wave. And whatever you do, don't pay attention to the dialogue. They actors have a way of overstating the obvious. "Look over there" "What is that"? It gets very tedious.If you can get past all of that and treat it as a low-budget sci-fi flick, then you just might like it. I think some sort of director's commentary on the DVD could have helped explain a lot about the film, ah, but alas, only the theatrical trailers are available in the special features. :(

reviews.review_title: An enjoyable sci-fi movie with interesting concept
reviews.content:
A time machine, that has the ability to take you back to prehistoric times and hunt a dinosaur. Will you take the chance? With this risk comes others... changing something so small can turn into something much bigger. The operation is carefully planned out, but there is always room for error....
The film A Sound of Thunder is based off of the well known short-story written by Ray Bradbury. Directed by Peter Hyams, the film stars Edward Burns, Catherine McCormack, Ben Kingsley, and Jemima Rooper. A Sound of Thunder was released in the year 2005, after some financial difficulties that delayed the film's release. The film is of the science fiction genre- a company called Time Safari Inc. uses a time machine to bring its wealthy clients back in time to hunt a tyrannosaurus rex.
A Sound of Thunder is about a series of trials faced by Dr. Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) and the rest of the staff at Time Safari Inc. Dr. Ryer is in charge of running the "time safaris", and he works closely with the rest of the time travel team to ensure that not even the most minute change is made to the past. Despite their efforts, one of the clients accidentally changes one tiny thing- and this leads to many other changes in evolution that are much larger. It is up to Dr. Ryer and his team to determine what is causing all of the changes in the modern world- and how to reverse the damage that has been done. It will be difficult though, and there are no guarantees that the change is reversible.
The concept of A Sound of Thunder is one that is actually quite intriguing. You wouldn't think that manipulating the small, insignificant life of a creature from tens of thousands of years ago could change the entire course of evolution. In general, the idea of time-travelling back to prehistoric times is mind-boggling, as it makes one wonder if that concept will someday be a reality in our world, which becomes more technologically advanced every day. What if someday, this movie doesn't seem so crazy and unrealistic? Anything can happen, and if you choose to look at the movie in a more serious light, it may lead you to ask the bigger question... is time travel really possible?
Overall, I did enjoy the film when I didn't think about the cheesy special effects and mediocre script. I would recommend the movie to anyone who just wants a casual way to pass the time and doesn't have very high standards. For the most part, A Sound of Thunder is family friendly, but younger viewers may not fully understand the concept. There is also some foul language in certain scenes, as well as a couple of suggestive ones. This movie also has a roller coaster of a plot that can be slightly hard to follow, but anyone can get a kick out of it. This film will keep your attention, and it is one of those films that you "love to hate".

This movie is a load of rubbish. It is badly acted, badly designed, badly edited and badly scripted. The more I watched the more of a spoof it became. I felt nothing for any of the characters let alone the world they save. Ben Kingsley appeared to be the only actor having fun with his part (hamming it up) and his moments on screen were the most bearable. Otherwise there is nothing redeeming about this movie whatsoever. I think the producers wanted a thoughtful gritty sci-fi (all that time paradox stuff) with epic disaster movie scope - but instead are left with a mish-mash of "cost-effective" Hallmark TV sci-fi, with a cheap Jurassic Park dinosaur, some bugs from The Mummy, a dragon-eel from a BBC programme about 65 million years ago and a whole lot of reptilian apemen who naturally want to kill everything that isn't an ape with a lizard tail. The worst part of the movie: The first death of the protagonist's team; he is black man and is killed by reptilian apemen because he "had to stay behind". He kept firing his liquid nitrogen gun until they devoured him. There are too many clichés in that one moment - and that's what this movie is: a collection of really bad clichés. Back to back. Save your money and give this a miss.

reviews.review_title: This movie made me want to be eaten by baboon-lizards...
reviews.content: A Sound of Thunder is such a bad movie that it was actually extremely enjoyable. You can tell a lot of work went into it but it just didn't come out all that perfectly. It is amazing the time and effort that went into this and how little credit it gets for the writers and actors who had worked through the loopholes of time travel and acted through not having real backgrounds and antagonists in front of them. It made me embarrassed for the cast and crew, so much so that it made me want to be eaten by those baboon-lizards.A Sound of Thunder is based on the short story of the same name by Ray Bradbury. Being made in 2005, this movie most notably stars Edward Burns, Ben Kingsley, and Catherine McCormack. It also features Jemima Rooper, David Oyelowo, Wilfried Hochholdinger, August Zirner, William Armstrong, and Corey Johnson. This Action, Adventure, Sci-Fi movie was directed by Peter Hyams with the companies Dante Entertainment, Warner Brothers, Crusader Entertainment LLC, Franchise Pictures, and Forge. Primarily taking place in 2055, A Sound of Thunder tells the story of a corrupt time travel company that eventually causes mass destruction.2055, Chicago, there sits a place known as Time Safari Inc., a supposedly safe company, who takes the wealthy to hunt in prehistoric times. Run by money oriented Charles Hatton(Ben Kingsley), Time Safari has an array of employees who work hard to take clients safely on safaris. This crew is led by Travis Ryer(Edward Burns), and consists of the video keeper of the "time jumps," Jenny Krase(Jemima Rooper); the engineer of the safaris, Marcus Payne(David Oyelowo); and Dr. Lucas(Wilfried Hochholdinger), who keeps track of the clients' vitals. However, this supposedly safe company is proven not so when one "time jump" goes awry. This causes a series of events and creates so-called "time waves" that hit their present world with washes of evolution. They then have to work side-by-side with the time machine creator, Sonia Rand(Catherine McCormack), in order to set everything back how it was. To do this, they have to work against the clock before one of the last "time waves" hits which would, in turn, cause humans to evolve.The beginning of this movie starts off with a group of travelers in a poor green screen, prehistoric, jungle. This moment set a low bar for the rest of the movie. It would have been so easy to step over and grow from that moment on. Then a CGI dinosaur walks out and somehow manages to knock that bar even lower. This first scene really set up the whole movie where it could've gotten better, but it didn't.The very movie itself is confused; it can't decide whether it wants to be good or bad. I felt like this was the result of someone's small idea that they wanted to create so badly, when it started to go down hill they refused to let it go or try to fix it. Every time you think the movie is going to get better, it hits you with poor dialogue, wonky CGI, or really awkward green screen skills. For example, near the end of the movie marks a suspenseful spot where they are in a subway. This suspense and realism is quickly killed by the computer generated visual of water crushing the train. Something with the physics of the CGI wasn't convincing; it definitely could've been refined to get that scientific, realistic touch. Or the strangeness and impossibilities of the baboon-lizards. This supports my stress of not taking this movie too seriously. A Sound of Thunder probably isn't what you want to watch if you're looking for a well thought out plot of a Sci-Fi or the thrill of a Horror film. This is more of a movie that is fun to watch, you just have to sit down with the intent of something fun and interesting, not serious. It really is an enjoyable movie if you're willing to see it as funny. The plot and dialogue is so strange and weird at spots, it is hard not to be captivated.

One commentator asks what the sound of thunder was. Aside from the sound that the time wave changes, it might be the sound of farts, which is how bad this movie stinks. At first I thought it was a rip-off of the film Butterfly Effect, but it seems to have been filmed at the same time or earlier. At any rate, you would be much, much better off to avoid this stinker and spend your time watching The Butterfly Effect with Ashton Kutcher which is a much, much better movie and an excellent, pithy treatment of the same ideas but on a much higher plane of thought.There are some good moments here but nothing that can really make up for the bad ones and the feeling that you've wasted two hours of your life you could have been spending doing something better, hopefully with the opposite sex.

I saw this film after seeing the trailer on the internet and thought it looked fairly interesting. I knew that it would be a no-brainer, dumb sci-fi flick, but to be honest...i didn't care, i was looking for fun.The story is that a "time safari" is opened up, where rich people can travel back in time, kill a dinosaur and come back (all for a heft price of course). Then, something goes wrong, and the entire course of history and time is changed, which throws the future into a unbalanced mix of mutant dinosaurs, forests and urban buildings in which our heroes must solve the mess they created.I thought this sounded like a perfect popcorn film, and has endless possibilities to be a great film. This is not a great film though.So I sat down, and watched. The first 10 or so minutes pretty much sum up what the rest of the film is going to be like. When the T-Rex came staggering onto screen, I was amazed, I was in awe, I was shocked at how bad the special effects were! It truly did look like a big gelatin blob, or a rubber toy. It wouldn't have been too bad if you were without the knowledge that Jurassic Park is about 12 years old and has far superior graphics to this film. I'm afraid it doesn't get better, all the creatures in this film looks unbelievably fake that its hard to enjoy the film. There's a sequence in which two characters are walking down a street, behind them are futuristic cars and buildings. It's so obvious that it was done on a blue screen and overall it just makes you want to cry.The story itself is full of huge plot holes that in effect ruin the film and its progressive story. However, it is not the worst film I have ever seen, and even though I was disappointed, I still think the premise was a good one. Next time though, the filmmakers should know they have enough money before setting out to do a film like this, as audiences demand decent SFX. Especially after the likes of LOTR, King Kong and Harry Potter.

reviews.review_title: Franchise Pictures goes out with a whimper
reviews.content: A Sound of Thunder was collateral damage from the legendary bankruptcy of the scum production company Franchise Pictures, best known for inflating their film's budgets on paper, so partial investors end up paying for most of the budget. This was their final film with Warner Bros who obviously couldn't wait to terminate their contract, as this film is in unreleasable condition. It's a generic dumb as nails big budget film with no money shots because the visual effects are all pre- viz, which makes this look like Z grade Mystery Science Theater quality. Even if the effects were polished, it would still be weak with a boring lead performance from the always boring Edward Burns. But as it stands the effects are so hilariously awful they never let this movie rise above the bottom of the trash bin. Despite Franchise's money woes, neither them or Warner's felt this was a film worth finishing and you can't blame them.

*MINOR SPOILERS* QUICK PLOT OVERVIEW! Rich idiot owns time machine. Takes other rich idiots out to shoot dinosaurs in the distant past for exorbitant prices. Nothing could possibly go wrong here, right? WRONG! Someone changed something! How is that possible? I mean we've only got like five or six idiots with cool guns that they have no idea how to use blazing away in the middle of the Cretacious period, shouldn't be any problems at all. As a result of this, the poorly animated CGI city of the future is now infested with equally poorly animated CGI monsters who all look the same and share the same hunger for heroic dying black people. Time to run around screaming for a bit! Eeeyaugh! As we reach a deeply moving conclusion in which the life of an innocent butterfly is saved, we come to the shocking realization that maybe stupid idiots sending even stupider idiots with cool guns back in time to lay waste to history isn't such a good idea as it originally seemed.Well a few good life lessons can be learned from this movie: 1. Don't use a time machine as a thrill ride.2. Don't be black. If you are black, you will find a way to die heroically and horribly, and usually very expediently as well. This holds true for almost all major motion pictures.3. Don't change the timeline. If you do, the future you return from will be infested with poorly animated CGI monsters and bad actors reciting cliché scripts! 4. Don't buy this movie. Renting it will suffice since you will never watch it again anyway.Not a horrible movie, but definitely not the brightest I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: Marginally entertaining B-grade production of a childish plot
reviews.content:
First, we have to get this out of the way: Ray Bradbury was an exceptionally good writer, but he was fascinated with the unknown. That is why he's so good at fantasy and horror. Ray Bradbury was first and foremost a religious man who understood very little about science. Science fiction requires a little more work than reading the bible. This story is one of the most clueless takes on the concept of evolution that anyone can ever imagine.As for the film:
-Paper-thin and ludicrous plot
-Competent cast, blessed with the star power of Ben Kingsley (whose talent is wasted on this enterprise)
-Laughable CGI, even for 2005
-Good score, good editing, good pacingThis is a movie on the brink of the "so bad is funny" category.

I have always been big in to stories. This movie has a Great story with action...as long as you can get over the dismal digital effects. When first viewing the movie, get over the bad special effects as soon as possible. Doing this first, you will see the good aspects of the movie instead of looking for even worst effects.I had saw previews for this movie on-line and was confused as to why it went straight to DVD in my area. Once I started the movie, I understood completely (bad special effects as I explained earlier).But I do not care what anyone else says, I liked it. If you hate reading books and want a good story, I say watch this movie on a rainy day.

As you slip into catatonia during the first half hour of A Sound of Thunder you may wonder how such a terrible film was made. Do not blame Ray Bradbury, who I sincerely hope has not seen it, as his short story is one of his many moments of brilliance and could make an excellent short.There are chances to marvel. How did Ben Kingsley ever get involved, and where did he get that toupee? Is Edward Burns truly that dull an actor? And why is every character so extremely unlikable? The conversations between Burns (as Ryer) and Catherine McCormack (as Dr Rand) would almost have some substance if not for Burns using the high impact emotion of wet cardboard and McCormack delivering almost every line with a machine gun staccato.Ryer's logic for travelling in time is an almost reasonable wish to recreate lost animals, killed by a mysterious virus by 2055. Rand though is seriously flawed. The character who built the time machine because she is, "a scientist", expecting that if it remained in the hands of the scientists, rather than the company who paid her to create it, it would not be abused. It's a time machine. How can it not potentially affect time?These time affects make little sense too. Although the changes sometimes come in "time waves", which don't logically centre on the origin of the change, the time safari building itself, sometimes they don't. The centre also seems to still be operational even when overgrown due to these changes and who realistically builds park benches and hot dog stands in places with dangerous creatures. Some of this criticism can be waived due to the collapse of the original production company but Peter Hyams has directed far better pictures and should be ashamed of helming this mess.There is simply little to recommend throughout. If you are a fan of the short story this will simply leave a very bad taste and each actor has appeared in far better works. The one main concern is that writer Thomas Dean Donnelly is also involved with the upcoming Uncharted and Dr Strange franchises. Hope for a change of form.

Peter Hyams just doesn't seem to ever make a solid movie, despite many tries. Some of his films are o.k., like "The Relic" and "Outland", but aren't great Both have one common flaw, dialogue. Scripts have good ideas, but just don't ever hit, like, John Carpenter quality. "A Sound of Thunder" is a full film version of a "Ray Bradbury Presents" episode, where a group of jerk rich thrill searchers end up ruining the future by going in the past. The descending chaos of the warp problem was, despite ridiculous, kinda cool and really does throw the movie in a direction where you really do not know what is going to happen next, which is good. Man, some of the dialogue when characters try to emote a personality is quite bad. It seems actors were cast because they look like more popular actors and actresses. You'll figure out which one's if you watch this overambitious sci-fi flic.

reviews.review_title: This movie got a bad rap
reviews.content: Having read the numerous negative, and even vituperative comments this movie has gotten here, I felt compelled to write to say that this movie doesn't deserve them and probably only the people who really didn't like it bothered to weigh in, giving the ratings an unbalanced perspective. Well, I'm writing to help correct that. I'm a big fan of classical science fiction - not bug eyed monsters or fantasy sorcerers and dragons, but of imaginative stories that are based on hard scientific data of today, with allowance for some poetic license, and I think this movie fits that description. It's based on a Ray Bradbury story, beefed up and modified for the screen, and I for one think they did a good job. Yes, the special effects were a little weak in some spots, but overall this was a good scifi movie with an engaging story, lots of action, and some edge of your seat thrills. It's out on DVD now (as of 3/28/06), so if, like me, you like good science fiction, give this one a try. Who knows, you may be the next positive commenter.

Now I do not mind low budget movies with bad scripts and bad special effects. They can be pretty funny. But this one is not a low budget. I really can not understand why they didn't pull the plug halfway the making of the movie seeing it was becoming...what was it becoming? A joke, a disaster? This movie is a bigger disaster than what is happening in the movie. You start hoping that it does come true and mankind is whipped out before it can make something like this. I truly admire Ray Bradbury, I read much of his work. He did the right thing, when the hunting party returned they found out something had changed, of course the people who stayed in the present didn't notice, only the time travelers). Then Ryan shoots Eckels for leaving the path (that is the sound of thunder). Now in Hollywood this story is too short so they had to make it a bit longer. They invented the time waves that gradually change everything and of course it does result in evil monsters.Now I can also start about the special effects, which are in most cases a joke but never mind. If you want to show how a good story can be turned into utter movie garbage, this will be a classic example

One of those "blink-and-you'll-miss-it" theatrical releases, this little 2005 sci-fi film is only one step higher on the evolutionary ladder than those cheesy creature features being produced on a weekly basis for the Sci-Fi Channel. Based on the 1952 short story by Ray Bradbury, I couldn't help but continuously think of "The Simpsons" Treehouse of Horrors parody, "Time and Punishment" (see below) while watching Peter Hyams's film."If you ever go back in time, don't touch anything. Even the slightest change can alter things in ways you can't possibly imagine." Truer words were never spoken. While Travis Ryer (Ed Burns, the poor man's Ben Affleck) and his crew of Temporalnauts respect this prime directive, the clients of Time Safari's boss man Charles Hatton (Sir Ben Kingsley) do not. The inadvertent death of a butterfly proves out Grandma Simpson's admonition, causing literal ripples in time that really ruin Ryer's day. His present day timeline changes with "time waves" that bring about a surge in plant life, bugs, and some odd hybrid creatures like the vicious baboonosaurus. It's up to Ryer, his team, and the grouchy Dr. Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack) to put things right again. Will they make it? Of course they will. The real questions are "What order do they die in?" and "What is Sir Ben Kingsley doing in this film?" Another puzzling aspect to the film is the budget. Was everything spent on catering? Certainly, very little was donated to special effect work. Street scenes feature actors walking against backgrounds of looping "futuristic" cars that look like they were accomplished with chroma-key effects done at the local Public Access Cable studio. A SOUND OF THUNDER was doomed not only by its horrible effects but by the cinematic saturation of the Novikov self-consistency principle. The film was the fourth of four films. While two others, John Woo's PAYBACK (2003) and Eric Bress & J. Mackye Gruber's THE BUTTERFLY EFFECT (2004), shared the same core idea they boasted far better marketing. A SOUND OF THUNDER was all fury and no thunder when it came to marketing, coming out with a whimper only equal to Richard Donner's forgettable TIMELINE (2003).It would be a few years until another such timeline film would get that amount of funding; Tony Scott's DEJA VU. Even then, the time travel aspect was minimized and only visible in previews that ran before fantasy or sci-fi films.

Just came back from the screening. First of all let me say that 90% of movie that is based on a book turns out bad (especially if u READ the book). I having read the book thought it strayed way too much from the book and is a horrible way of interperting Mr.Bradbury's masterpiece.I liked the book very much but this movie was bad. First they used cgi in every scene they had in the city which looked very fake. The cars... They only had 2 real cars built all the others were fake. I am not saying don't use CGI but if you saw minority report or I Robot, those CGI were done much better.Acting, The only person who was even believable was the main character Edward Burns. All the other characters needs some work...Moving on the script was poorly written, tho in the movie there were some comic relief which is good but not enough to save the movie The ending is different from what Mr.Bradbury intended and seems just too unrealistic even for a Sci-Fi. The time travel theory they used seems improbable mainly because I know of other theory that is more widely accepted (of course the average viewers don't know as much as I do so they should be OK)

reviews.review_title: Not -that- bad, but good enough for DVD or TV
reviews.content: Well I don't want to say that it was just as bad as the others say.Indeed it looked like they came a dollar short and if there was put some more effort in this movie, it could have been a lot better.I still gave it a 5 because the last half of the movie it get's even very good with tense and thrill if you don't look to hard for the right kind of greens or other special effect things which could have been made a lot better. Unfortunately the first half of the film which is in fact a lead-in to the second half, takes too much time. They could have cut this in half, so more time could have been spend to more thrilling and suspense, and special effects and story. The story has lots of possibility's to make it a great movie, but unfortunately, they did not make enough use of it.I would not go and watch this movie in a Cinema, not worth the money, however it's good enough for DVD of TV and in that case it would be worth the time viewing it.

Don't judge this against the best of thrillers; judge it for what it is -- pure fun.The plot and its time theory is debatable, but like all good science fiction, that's the point. It's theory -- there's no right or wrong, and to judge it on its scientific merits is asinine. The concept is not new, that a small change in the past has immeasurable impact on the present.The acting is tolerable for the genre; seeing Ben Kingsley in this is funny, though. The man who played Gandhi shouldn't be in bubble gum like this. Neither should Ed Burns for that matter. But they do what they can with the material.The effects are cool; the vision is fun. Pop some corn in the microwave and just have fun with this. To judge it seriously is to miss the point.

reviews.review_title: The big budget Sci-Fi Sleeper of the summer has arrived!!!
reviews.content: I have read this short story by Ray Bradbury which was written in the 50's; finally made into a big budget movie; and was eagerly anticipating it's big theatrical release since this past spring. I was not disappointed.The for the movie says it all: "Time travel in the future is possible"! But there are three rules which you must follow: "Don't touch anything", "Don't change anything", and "don't take anything back with you"! I'm used to logging on this site and reading all the hateful comments. It's so easy to hate, its even harder to like....for me it's easy to like.I was pleasantly surprised by how well this movie was made. It was thought through extremely well. The story line was totally believable and the actors gave strong performances. I was shocked that Ben Kingsley was in it, I was unaware of that and he played a role that even surprised me.I read one comment from someone on this about the butterfly sequence and what if the volcano killed it. Obviously this person is not too bright and didn't pay attention to what he/she was watching. The butterfly would have been killed by natural causes if the volcano erupted and killed it. The butterfly's life was ended by someone stepping on it who should not have even been there and ended it's life unnaturally, altering the butterfly's natural evolution and it was brought back on the bottom of the killers boot, changing things three fold...don't touch, don't change, don't bring back...HELLO? Thats why the time travelers would always go into the past with the safari party a few minutes before the t-rex would attack and make everyone wait before shooting & killing it because right before the travelers would kill the t-rex, the t-rex would meet its death at that point in time in the tar-pit, so they were not altering the death of the t-rex..he would die anyway and they knew this fact.Anyway...it's definitely the sleeper of the summer and a definite DVD "I can't wait for" release...hopefully with lots & lots of extras!

Let's start with the story... I have read the original Ray Bradbury's short story, and i thought this should have been a good sci-fi movie to follow up the success of I, Robot or Minority Report, but i was so disappointed in how the Bradbury's story was crippled. OK, for those who just want to sit in the theater and watch good cgi - NOT A F**** chance!!! I mean the cgi is so bad, and the dinosaur crossover monkey thing? NOT a must see!!! Now, let's talk about the actors. Now, when i think of Ben Kingsley, i imagine him in a must see movie, but at least he is the only entertaining person in the movie. And Edward Burns - well, he does nothing special in the movie - he's just your average doctor/good shooter type of character. Overall, this is the worst movies i have ever seen. And Peter Hyams should end his movie making career.

reviews.review_title: Why did they go and do it
reviews.content: I'll start by admitting that I enjoy many movies that have low ratings on this site. I find that if I can see what the creators were trying to do I can find appreciation for their work. Sound of Thunder was a story that interested me. I wanted to see what angles the filmmakers would attack in telling the story. By and large they attempted to create an entertaining movie. The plot was contrived, but most action movie's plots are. Ed Burns doesn't know how to carry a rifle, but still holds his own well as an action lead considering he isn't asked for much. The main problem, !destroys the whole movie!, is the horrible CGI. It is totally unacceptable for the animals and backgrounds to look soooooo very fake. Aside from that the animal conceptions could have been really good, as could the action scenes but failed because the production failed. This could have been a really memorable film if they had only finished it. It really looks like they meant to go back and fix all the horrible CGI but ran out of money and still released it. Save your money because someone failed this movie. I give it three stars because it really could have been good but was totally failed somewhere I can't say it enough.

Life is a delicate balance between order and disorder. Once a small disturbance... One minor infraction of nature's law is all it takes.This movie is based on a short story by Ray Bradbury.Chicago 2054. We have discovered a way to do time travel. Even though we use it for recreational purposes there may be a deeper impact.The application of the story may be misleading as we see from trailers somebody steps on a butterfly however this was not the problem but the effect. You should be aware of the saying "keep your powder dry." In this case, a beautiful woman caused negligence which caused a short which caused the butterfly effect. The moral of the story is "don't let a beautiful woman distract you or it may be the end of the world."Just a side note, it looks like they tried to include every disaster movie you've ever seen and big bug movie (okay little bug), volcanoes, monkeys taking over the world, flora gigantic, and many more unspeakable disasters. Oh and don't forget the evil, uncaring, unthinking, unscrupulous, and many more un's of the government. And don't forget Ben Kingsley as the corporate head who has more un's than the government.Coming back to the actual movie presentation, the graphics are appallingly hokey. They spend a lot of time on a treadmill in front of a blue screen and don't have any qualms about letting you know that they are more interested in the story than the visuals. Maybe we should be too, yet it is very distracting to see how disjointed the people scenes are from the graphic scenes. This has all the feel of a Hallmark movie without romance.I'm sure that they're just trying to deliver one simple message. "Don't mess with mother nature"

reviews.review_title: Can't believe i'm even writing this one.
reviews.content: A Sound of Thunder (2005) directed by Peter Hyams is like if you took every bad attribute from every movie ever, and threw it into one big dysfunctional smoothie. Not only did it have the worst CGI effects I've ever seen, but it managed to have a terrible plot and a cheesy script, like pick a struggle... I'm going to guess that if they had not run out of money while filming and producing this monstrosity, it would have turned out better than the sad excuse for a Sci-Fi movie that "A Sound of Thunder" is.In the short story version of "A Sound of Thunder" (the enjoyable version), from Ray Bradbury, the characters actually have some depth to them and they are fairly intriguing. Travis, played by Edward Burns, was putting me to sleep with his so- called "acting". There was not a single actor in this movie that entertained me, I'm almost positive that the cast aren't even actual people, they seem like robots. The actors had zero sincere emotion in anything they said, it was almost like Siri and Alexa were the main characters of the film.Let's break down this already decomposing and rotten plot some more, shall we? The film depicts a bunch of fat rich people paying for top-of-the-line entertainment, a prehistoric safari, sound familiar? In these safaris, the clients/customers pay to go in and hunt down dangerous, predatory dinosaurs with liquid nitrogen bullets? But when they are returning from the expedition something isn't right, Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) suspects that something is wrong, so he goes to consult Dr. Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack) for some explanation. The two figure out that something had to have been brought back from the safari, thus altering the present. The real action happens when these "time waves" start to hit, these horrendously CGI rendered "time waves" cause changes to occur in the present day, turning the present back to the past. The goal of the Geek Squad was to go back into the past and prevent the change to set things right and return the present back to normal.This movie is just bad, it doesn't deserve the attention that I am giving it by writing this review, which turned out to be quite lengthy... What can I say? There's a lot to complain about.

Have you ever heard the phrase so bad it's good? Well this movie is so bad its bad, but that makes it good!
