This may sound contradictory but trust me, if you are looking to flush away one and a half hours of your life then this is the movie for you.To get the boring stuff out of the way, this movie "A Sound of Thunder" based on the short story by Ray Bradberry was Directed by Peter Hyams. Starring Edward Burns as the lead character Travis supported by Caterine McKormic as Sonia Rand as well as Ben Kingsly as Charles Hatton. Produced in 2005 by Franchise Pictures, this movie cost around 80 million to make, yet grossing only about 11 million. In a short summary this movie is about Travis and his quest to hold the fabric of time together. After disaster strikes Travis and the crew will be able to fix everything. (If only they went back in time and stopped this movie's production...)
We first see our knock off spartans in the primordial jungle, and you guessed it they are hunting dinosaurs, after the hunt we are introduced to Dr Rand and she is the blah blah blah. Look all you need to know is go back in time, kill dinosaurs, make an oopsie and BAM! Now there is super predators in the modern era. Crazy, unexpected, mind blowing stuff really. On a more serious note this movie meant to explore the butterfly effect and how the small and benign things that happen every day can blow out of proportion give enough time. Basically don't step on that bug or you may be ripped to shreds by the flying monkeys from The WIzard Of Oz.I think if I had to pick an important scene that I feel exemplifies this movie I would say the scene where they enter the time travel room with the creatures sleeping is it. In typical shoty sci-fi movie fashion this scene is full of dumb chacters doing dumb things. The saving grace is that the awful CGI creatures are asleep and you don't have to see them in action.No it may sound like I'm just ripping into this movie, and I am. However, if you want to waste your precious life force watching this piece of garbage, it's not the worst. This movie is a great watch if you like terrible 2005 CGI, but most importantly, if you go into not expecting anything you will be pleasantly pleased by the little that is there. Anyways my broskis I gotta bounce. Haha movie review go BrrrrrrWritten by some Zoomer.

I was really interested in seeing this film as I was a fan of Bradbury when I was a teen. In fact I very much remember this as one of my favorite Bradbury tales. Unfortunately it was completely destroyed.In this tragic rewrite of a classic tail the story opens well and consistently with what Bradbury wrote but after that it goes horribly wrong. Upon returning from the second trip to the past the present begins to change. Events called "Time Waves" pass through changing nearly everything as they pass. We're warned that with each wave evolution will change from the lower order to the higher with humans changing last.As the characters move through an increasingly dangerous Jurassic Park like environment they seek to understand the change they made in the past that cause such a change in the future. Eventually they discover that one of their clients killed a butterfly in the past and that caused all the changes in the present.While this was the premise of Bradbury's story, it quickly falls apart when we discover that seconds after killing the dinosaur a volcano erupts which would have killed the dinosaur if it hadn't been killed by the clients. Somehow we're supposed to believe that the pyroclastic flow that killed the dinosaur and laid waste to the forest spared the butterfly. Can you say "Oh Please"? Even if we can forget a plot gap so large you can fly a 747 through it, the special effects were terrible. There were several street scenes where it was more than obvious that the actors were filmed on blue screen and the rest of the action digitally added. It had that same unreal quality we saw in films of the 40's - 70's, people moving out of sync with the background.Somehow this got 4 stars, as far as I'm concerned that's 2 stars too many.

reviews.review_title: Darn and I thought it was a very good sci-fi channel original movie!
reviews.content: This was distributed in American theaters? I don't remember hearing advertisement of it. Oh well...Started as a theater film or from the Sci-Fi channel don't care; I liked it. I really did. Both for acting and script I found it to be the rare caliber I didn't feel the need to get into character backgrounds but still cared for who "died"--Well except Ben Kingsley's character. There's nothing redeeming about greedy Mr. Hatten.This is a film that is good on the eye--the guys are so-so. What got my attention the set designs, the metropolis and the gradual descent from civilization to the primeval chaos. Where can I get the taxis? The CGI images blended in realistically. The dinosaurs were standard. Although seen repeatedly the "time wave" fx didin't bore. If there's anything about the movie's props I found irksome--the prehistoric baboons--good God, hanging from the ceiling???? Just that and only that pulls my rating this a 9 to 8.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies in film history.
reviews.content: I saw this movie in my 9th grade English class after we read the short story, and I didn't know how it would turn out. Ten minutes into the movie I knew that this would be an hour and a half I would never get back. Fortunately I wasn't forced to take notes on it or anything because I would've wrote down every bad thing about it, and there was a LOT of bad things about it.First of all, if stepping on a butterfly changed the future, then why would they add a volcano about to explode that would kill it anyway? This movie made absolutely no sense and was an absolute insult to the original short story.I also can see by the other comments that this cost $80 million dollars to make, and it mystifies me as to why the studio continued to poor money into this epic failure.
The special effect is not up to mark. But the concept was OK considering 2005 technologies. The team could have done better. Because the budget was bigger on 2005.

This film is bad but why do I own it on DVD. I love the fact that this is a major studio movie that cost about 80 million dollars to make and yet has the worst CGI I have ever seen. I often put on the DVD and watch the scene when Edward burns and some woman are walking down the road with the cars driving past. I just cannot get my head around the CGI. If you compare the graphics of the city in this to say The Island you will understand just how pathetic they are. The fx team must have been wasted when they were doing the fx on this film. I live in England and I remember seeing the trailer on a summer blockbuster preview DVD I got with a movie magazine but the film just never came out until I saw it a few years later on DVD in Blockbuster. I dislike Edward Burns a lot and am really happy that this film killed his career. I do however like the story to this film and I did enjoy some of the action such as the giant bats. To sum up its a film that anyone who is interested in cinema needs to see. Its one of the most notorious flops in cinema history and you will be amazed by the fx just not in a good way.

A Sound of Thunder is founded on a genuinely interesting science fiction concept however the writers were unable to make a good movie out of it. The films starts out well but becomes less and less believable after the timeline is interfered with (not a spoiler because timetravel films always involve this sort of thing). The B-grade nature of the film unfortunately becomes increasingly apparent. The cast do a pretty good job and the film is entertaining while disbelief is suspended, so even though it was disappointing for a science fiction fan like me I can't say it didn't provide some good entertainment.

reviews.review_title: Ha Ha Ha... and more uncontrollable laughter...but not in a good way
reviews.content: I saw the trailer for this film many years ago and remember thinking how bad the FX looked at the time and wondering why I was being subjected to it in my local flea pit. Having never remembered the title, never got to see it....until now. Oh my god, this film is terrible. I never thought I would see a film as bad as Timeline, I was wrong.How do these films get made in this day and age?? It not only looks bad, it plays bad , the direction is bad, the pacing is bad, the script is bad. And boy does it look bad. The scene when they are being chased in the car is the funniest thing ever. I thought I was watching Garth Merenghis Dark Place.There is no way to describe how you will get nothing out of this film. OK maybe if you are a kid...but are kids not more demanding now days. It is the eighties no more.Was there even a credit for FX in this film, do those guys have an 'Alan Smithie' they can use if required. Seeing as this dross was shown on the Big Screen, you can see how Primeval gets the green light for TV. Hey.. maybe that's where the FX guys went next.The biggest crime is that they managed to get some real acting talent in for this film. No doubt swayed a little by the fact that Peter Hyams was directing??? Was he? Im not so sure....maybe the cash swayed them as well. When will people work within a budget instead of trying to stretch it far too far. Grrrrr... I'm off to watch Highlander III.

reviews.review_title: great story, great screenplay, terrible execution
reviews.content: Yes this movie is awful, that's to be sure... and it's mostly to blame for lack of budget... the screenplay is actually quite good for this type of film.. it does at times "over simplify" the principles involved and throws lines of crap at you about time waves and such, but that's just the way it works...This film takes place in the 2055 and revolved around a scientist that works for a company that gives "time safaris" to rich men who pay to go back in time and kill the same dinosaur every time... they use ice bullets to not leave anything behind and walk on a floating liquid bridge thing as to not alter the ground or step on anything... so they go back in time to the last few minutes of the life of some dinosaur and kill it on their own rather than letting it die of the natural causes that are already on their way... but then something goes wrong... and the past is changed therefore changing our future... much like in Back to the Future, when you change something in the past the present isn't immediately effected and this film just simply puts a visual to that idea with their "time waves" which sweep over the planet changing everything once something in the past has been altered... But as i watched it i knew the director and the cast had more in mind when they shot it... it has a want and a need for scope and scale... their version of the city of the future has some great ideas but it's executed sooooo poorly... i currently play video games that have better graphics which saddens me... how could this movie come out today and come into theaters with CGI FX like these... the dinosaur they kill looks awful and they blur it at times to cut down on the fact that it hasn't been finished... all the special effects look like tests or half finished ideas... like they literally ran out of money and threw this all onto film and slapped it in theaters... what bothers me is that all this movie needs is a better director, a little bit more money and a decent CG house to do the effects and you'd have a killer film... a b-movie to be sure... but one you could enjoy with friends on a Saturday at the cinema...This screenplay is good... this movie is bad... if we're going to be doing anymore remakes in Hollywood this next year i hope Spielberg will take a look at this and say "hey yeah... i've got nothing better to do"...

reviews.review_title: and it had so much potential :))
reviews.content: this is a VERY (i don't usually use capital letters, but i really felt the need to do it now) bad movie. it's very bad in every aspect. starting with the acting, which is mediocre at best, continuing with the CGI, which in turn does more bad than good to the movie and ending with the story, which has more holes in it than any story i've ever. i don't mean to say that it's a week plot with not a lot to say, like those horror movies that have no point to them or something. no no no. this is a story that pays no respect to the cause-effect principle or at least to simple logic. it can't even be ignored. it's annoying. it bothered me more than those disconcerting special effects, and that's not easy. i'm not going to say it's the worst movie i've ever seen, but it's close. i'll give it 2 stars instead of one, because i understand it's been done with relatively limited funds, but i strongly recommend against paying to see this. i saw it at one of my friends', so fortunately i didn't waste any money on this, and had it not been for a few bottles of beer we drank, i don't think i could've last through the whole movie. so be warned ;)

reviews.review_title: Sympathy needed here - a budget would not have hurt either
reviews.content: Within the first 10 minutes, the first dinosaur in all its plasticity walks onto the screen with trees offering no resistance whatsoever to his lumbering lethargy and the viewer feels let-down. This could have been a really great scene. There is a seed of a good idea in the mix. I've never read the Ray Bradbury story this was based upon but I have a feeling that the core of the concept, that is, what could have made this movie a real thought provoker, is buried by the semi-good acting and distracting half-conceived special effects. Ben Kingsley actually shines in the movie - but no one else does. The computer, TAMI, was more memorable than any of the other cast. As for the effects? Nothing disappoints me more than seeing what could have been a really good effect wasted because it was half-finished. The baboon-lizard creatures are actually a good idea and quite frightening but are frequently stiff and cartoonish. Too bad. All other creatures are disappointing in the 'could have been great but falls annoyingly short' category. Perhaps a wasted moment came after the 'final time wave' and the viewer gets a glimpse of what humans would become. I know I was curious. And then there it was - and there it goes. The depth of this movie can be summed up with that brief encapsulation - nearly no thought went into the conception of the neo-human. There it is....it blinks...the end. It might have been more interesting to get a bit of reaction from this new creature - but no. Why start making a movie with substance now when it is nearly over? Bottomline: I didn't hate the movie really. It only came close to being unwatchable. I was mostly irritated by what it could have been. Thus, it ends up being a waste of the space-time continuum.

It's not a spoiler to talk about the Ray Bradbury short story, because this movie has almost nothing to do with it.In the short story, people go back in time to hunt a dinosaur, whose death has been carefully studied and shown to cause no effect on the time line. They when they come back, they find numerous *subtle* changes to the world they left, and eventually realize that a small mistake they made in the past caused them.In this movie, they go back in time to kill a dinosaur, and... that's pretty much where the similarity ends. Time travel stories are usually problematic, but this one throws all logic and reason out the window, not to mention the fact that there are plot holes you can drive a bus through.Even with a bunch of extra stuff thrown in, they still have to pad the movie with superfluous and annoying action sequences to stretch it to the requisite run time.And let's talk about the quality. When I started watching this, I assumed it was a low budget made for SyFy movie, but this came out in *theaters*. I guess the budget was slashed and they couldn't afford the post production processing they had planned to do. The result is that the dinosaur looks like a theme park animatronic, and large parts of the movie are really obviously shot on green screen. It's hard to believe this came out 12 years *after* Jurassic Park.The only bright spot is Ben Kingsley, who can even bring some class to this train wreck. Besides that, it's not fun enough even to hate watch.The original short story was made into an episode of The Ray Bradbury Theater. You can find it on YouTube. Do yourself a favor and watch that instead.

reviews.review_title: Really liked it, despite all the criticism
reviews.content: I loved the original story by Ray Bradbury. Read it as a kid and envisioned the whole story. Although the movie is very different from the book, it's still great entertainment. The only reason I'm not giving 10 stars is the poor special effects.

After watching the imdb and some screenshots i thought this would be some random low budget flick but wasn't that bad...First of all a hats off to the shittiest cgi of hollywood..cgi failures can be ignored if story is good..some scenes were dramatic and the science behind it was bummer at some point ,but its worth a watch..dont watch it with family coz they'll curse u(not nudity)..watch alone which makes it a worth watching movie...

reviews.review_title: How does the butterfly death work?
reviews.content: Not sure i understand how the killing of the butterfly by the safari affected evolution/time...after all, wasn't the entire area where that butterfly lived wiped out by a volcano, a toxic cloud of ash and hot gas, mere minutes after the safari leaves? are we to believe that somehow, that one butterfly out flew a speeding hot gas cloud, and survived the devastation to the area? that somehow, that butterfly flew 40 miles in 5 minutes, an escaped the volcanic debris that wiped out life in the area for decades?wasn't everything in that area pretty much "free game" for the safari, since it was all going to be wiped out in five minutes anyway?

OK, let's see ...One, they go to hunt this dino because it will sink in the tar and then a vulcano destroys all. No change to history, evolution. OK, I get that. But why would it matter if they also killed a butterfly?Two, they go to hunt the same dino on every safari. Wouldn't it get crowded at that point in time and space after a while?Just my two cents.Believe it or not, I still enjoyed this movie. You have to forgive the CGI and stuff as it is really bad. Is Catherine McCormack hot or what ...

reviews.review_title: Two out of three is bad
reviews.content: Forget special effects they are just eye candy. Three things make a good movie, the director, the actors and the script. You can occasionally escape this trio if you get an inept director or a bad actor, but NEVER with a bad script. Sound of Thunder had the bad script. Where do they get these idiots we laughingly call writers. And how does anyone convince investors to put money into such rubbish. Frankly I get insulted. Do the people who decide to produce this stuff believe the viewing public are that stupid not to see the large gaping plot holes and the inconsistencies. Where is the intelligence?? This is Burtons "Planet of the Apes" all over again.Spoilers – They go back & kill the same Allaraurous dinosaur 3 times. Now assuming the time continuum does some sort of reset to compensate for a paradox which allows this, how come he can go back and warn himself in the third visit to save the world. And if it does reset every time, what they do in the past does not matter because all you have to do is visit at the same time after, do nothing and cause a reset.I am a SCFI fan but frankly, can't they get some bozo's other than 6th graders to write a better script??

There's a slight difference between a terrible film and a bad film. As surreal as it sounds, I really enjoy watching this film a lot. Just to get things right, this film is crap, but it really has some really great ideas.For example the Baboonosaurus. Great idea, but very questionable. I don't think evolution works in such weird ways, but I take it for the cool idea it is. The design of the so called Ichtyo Sapiens (for the short moment its in) is fun to watch. Also I enjoyed the jungle setting.Just forget about the acting, its that crappy. It's a bad film over and over, it's an enjoyable film.As much as I would like to say, get it and check it out on your own, but this film ... Well it's a Si-Fi film, a bad one with many very enjoyable parts. Not everyone will like it. If you enjoyed movies like EVOLUTION, you will enjoy A SOUND OF THUNDER.

Oh, come on. A Sound of Thunder may not be a great movie, but it managed to keep me entertained for 90 minutes! Yes, the graphics are bad, and the movie is cheesy and not very well-made, but it isn't really boring. Movies like Star Trek: Nemesis and The Cave are the ones that bore you out of your skull, but not this one. I almost...sort of...liked it.I'm giving it a 2.5/4 because even though it's a pretty bad movie, it's never very boring, and the acting isn't terrible (although Ben Kingsley's character is wasted). IT'S NOOOOOOOOOOTTTTTT THHAAAAAAAT BAAAAD!!!!! Geez! Loosen up a little!

reviews.review_title: I Wish They'd Gone Back in Time to Unmake This Film
reviews.content: Supposedly based on a classic Ray Bradbury short story, "A Sound of Thunder" does a great disservice to the science fiction master. A potentially great plot becomes a two-dimensional rip-off of such superior films as "Jurassic Park" and "Time After Time." First of all, I know that you generally have to suspend belief for science fiction. At the same time, however, you do have to have your basic facts straight. The plot involves Time Safari, a company run by Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsley in a wasted role as the stereotypical greedy businessman), that takes rich clients 65 million years into the past to hunt the dreaded Allosaurus. During one such hunt, a glitch with the weaponry causes someone to leave the guide path and interact with the environment. This causes time ripples that change the present. The company's main guide, Travis Ryer (Edward Burns of "Saving Private Ryan" & "American History X") must team up with renegade scientist Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack of "Braveheart" & "Spy Game" in the stereotypical role of the beautiful lady scientist) to correct the mistake.As each time ripple washes over the world, things get worse. Plant life runs amok. Carnivorous insects appear. The descendants of dinosaurs make fast food of the human race.From the get-go, the film gets the facts wrong. The Allosaurus hunt is set for 65 million years in the past, yet this particular dinosaur had already been extinct for 80 million years at that point.A company doctor warns two clients not to interact with the ancient environment, explaining that they might kill a butterfly that would then not pollinate a flower that might not germinate to bear seeds to feed an animal and so on and so on until someone is not born who should be or someone stays alive who should die. Yet, when the time ripples emanating from 65 million years ago wash over the city, nothing really changes. All the buildings stay around. All the people stay around. All the fake-looking CGI cars stay around. Nobody suddenly ceases to exist. None of the technology that makes the time jumps possible is affected. It's as if the city were suddenly picked up and tossed into another dimension.Burns is the only watchable thing in the film. Ben Kingsley appears to be embarrassed to be in the movie. McCormack is rather blasé. Jemima Rooper (TV's "Sinchonicity" & "Hex") is annoying as the snot-nosed rookie Jenny and David Oyelowo ("Last King of Scotland") does his bit as the required token black guy.The worst thing is the special effects. The CGI looks bad. The allosaurus seems to be made out of gelatin. The futuristic cars are CGI and appear rough and distorted around the edges. The actors obviously look to be walking next to screens and, in one scene with Rooper and Burns, appear to be walking in place. CGI animals in the future (or present) don't interact well with the scenery (for instance, an eel glides through water without making a ripple).Apparently, this movie was in and out of theaters over the 2005 Labor Day weekend. I'd originally contemplated taking it in, but wisely decided not to when I saw that it didn't even crack the Top 20 in sales in its debut weekend. I got it at one of Blockbuster's 4-for-$20 events. Even $5 seems like a waste, though.Do yourself a favor. Pass this up. If you bought it like I did, go back in time and put it back.

reviews.review_title: Complete disregard for their own premise
reviews.content: I don't mind watching movies that have a smaller budget than what I carry in my wallet. But when there is a complete disregard for the science the writer/producer is trying to sell you...I get upset.The premise of this movie was described in a previous comment. One of the things they try to sell you is that they have to hurry after 'killing' the t-rex, because a volcano is about to erupt. During the movie, the crew barely escapes a nasty pyroclastic flow.IF, and that is a huge if, the pyroclastic flow is as bad as they showed it to be...the 'item' they brought back that was the premise of the movie, would have been destroyed anyway.So unless you have absolutely nothing better to do with an hour and a half of your life, I would recommend almost any other movie before this one.

reviews.review_title: One of the wost movies ever seen.
reviews.content: This is one of the worst movies i've ever seen. - Vey bad SFX (worst since ages) - Very bad scenario - Bad acting and the plot.I know porn movies with a better plot, really.This movie contains all kinds of plastic stuff, plastic dinosaurs, plastic weapons (worst weapons ever made for a movie), plastic trees. In scene 3 or 4 people are walking in a digital made street, but it is far to obvious that they are cut out of a blue screen and walk some kind of low budget home-trainer to imply walking.I'm willing to take a plot as it is, but this plot is outstanding. It's totally unacceptable and really strange. Only watch this movie if you want to have a laugh about the worse elements of the movie or if you want to realize that worse movies (like Electra) are at least relatively well made.

This movie was really bad, plain and simple. How a movie like this gets wide release is a wonder to me.It's a decent idea, but it just didn't flesh out. Edward Burns is a decent actor though. I liked his small role in Saving Private Ryan.Let's get down to the big issue here.The visuals were so incredibly bad, I thought I was watching an old "Dinosaurs In 3D" CDROM point-and-click adventure demo on Windows 3.1 I mean, I've seen cut-scenes in console games from pre-2000 that have better looking dinosaurs than this. I mean, heck... the original Tomb Raider T-Rex looked better than this one.The lizard-monkeys were laughable. I thought they were some sort of ripoff creation from "Killer Instinct" I've seen better sock-puppet monsters now that I think about it.You know, there's a ton of made-for-TV movies that are better than this. How does a gem like Scifi Channels "The Shining" get such a small audience, but this load of "CGI, easy to make 4 Kidz" gets put out in the open? I don't care if it's a Ray Bradbury story. Lameeeee

Oh man, I really didn't think they made movies like this any more. Sound of Thunder is a stinker in virtually every single department and I mean stinker. And I mean every department.Ed Burns is the only decent actor in the whole thing. Even Ben Kingsley looks embarrassed to be here and rushes through a mediocre by the numbers (and thats being kind) performance so he can get on with some real movies. Everyone else in the movie is utterly forgettable. The special FX are bloody awful and half of them don't look like they are even finished. There are one or two that look OK but- actually no I'm not going to stand up for this movie. Sound of Thunder really has no business whatsoever being on the DVD shelf at your local rental store (was it even released in theaters?) and Franchise pictures (who the hell are they, never heard of them and if this is any indication of their products then I don't ever want to hear from them again) should be shot for allowing an obvious work in progress, and not a very good one at that, out into the market in this state.And what the hell does Peter Hyams think he's pulling here. I mean he has some decent flicks under his belt (Capricorn One, 2010 and The Relic, even the mediocre TimeCop was OK on a base level) but this movie feels like it's been directed by a two year old. A two year old, I might add, whose slightly older brother was dragged in to do the editing as well. Most, if not all, of the outside shots that had actors in them were shot using a CGI backdrop which looks so obvious it's laughable. Like they couldn't take a couple of cameras downtown and shoot something more convincing (and probably less expensive).The sound also was uneven with the sound levels going up and down during scenes for no reason whatsoever.I'd rather gouge both my eyes out than sit through this again it was that painful. No actually I'd rather watch Alone in the Dark than watch this movie.Although, if you've got some mates round with some tins and a pizza then you might want to give this a rental so you have endless fun ripping it to bits. It deserves no less......Thank you drive through....

Despite a great premise (based upon a superb short story by Ray Bradbury), this film is simply dreadful. On the plus side, it's so bad, it's actually fun to sit back and laugh at the horrible acting (only Ben Kingsley's turn as a sleazy CEO in blond hairpiece is notable), the crappy FX and the storyline that has holes large enough for a pack of the films' "Baboonasaurs" to leap through. Don't waste any $$ on this, but if you've got some time to sacrifice, pour a healthy adult beverage, sit back w/ friends, and enjoy ripping into it. Who came up with the "time waves" - and how come they make no sense? Why is the British scientist, who's supposed to be the hot love interest to the hero, why is she such a stick in the mud? Was the wooden dialog written by some off-the-shelf crappy screenplay writing program? Do we care?

reviews.review_title: Sitting alone in the dark would be better than watching this movie
reviews.content: It is seldom that a film comes along that is so bad that you can not take anything positive from it. The original story writer must have been paid a fortune or blackmailed to have allowed this film. From the "special effects "which a child with crayons could have bettered to the plot which had more holes than Swiss cheese, this film was terrible. The actors were all of a reasonable caliber ( the odd suspect American accent as the vast majority were British ) the story line was a good concept and special effects can be done well and for not too much money, wouldn't it have been easier to have made this a good film ? I think you would struggle to make a film this bad.The only one of unlimited holes I would like to discuss is this< Why was evolution in perfect sink with the man made constraints of time and I believe the Gregorian calendar? that the time wave was to hit from 65 million years ago every 24 hours exactly is absurd.

Rarely have I seen a film this bad. A futuristic movie that is hard to understand, poorly explained (even with the actor's monologues), pretty badly acted and with dreadful special effects. It could be a candidate for B Movie of the year but it takes itself too seriously for that and there are few laughs to be had at its expense. There is one scene where two actors are walking on the street with CGI cars and stores around them that look like something out of a 80s/90s computer game. That made me laugh. If you watch this movie after these comments you deserve a medal so do something better with your time... anything... even watching paint dry has to be more entertaining!

Don't spend any money to watch this class "B" Sci Fi Movie. It is not that bad, and a good way to spend a couple of hours. We just finished watching "Queen of Blood" 1966 with Basil Rathbone about a Mars mission where the astronauts bring back to earth a Martian vampire. Take for what they are and not try to make them classics for the time. I remember studying this story in high school (1967) English class. I recall that there were many layers to the story line including the butterfly. Ray Bradbury was a master of small stories, and this one is right up there with Martian Chronicles. The movie does not even touch any of Bradbury's meanings, but the movie does lay out the story visually. So the CGI effects are kind of cheesy. The reptile bats were interesting as were the baboon-o-saurs. Pop the Popcorn....curl up and enjoy.....don't waste energy over thinking.

For all those who posted negative comments about this movie, I have just one word for you, De-caf. Just because this movie takes itself seriously doesn't mean we have to! I do feel bad for you if you did think this was good enough to pay a movie theater ticket price for, though. I rented it and watched the movie where it belonged in the first place, on the television.Maybe you all read Bradbury's short story on which this movie is based, and you were all expecting some kind of Spielberg/Peter Jackosn epic. C'mon, director Peter Hyams does not have that kind of talent, although his resume is not completely awful. I think by comparison, The Butterfly Effect was a much better movie and executed the same plot much better, too. I thought the movie was entertaining-Ben Kingley's hokey acting proves that(most) actors won't turn any role down for a quick paycheck. His presence in the film, white hair and matching thin soul patch, are all nauseating. Yeah, the blue screen stuff was terrible in a very funny sort of way, like the phony walking-down-the-street scenes with Edward Burns-hilarious stuff! I must have blinked during the nudity scenes which was listed in the rating details because I never saw anyone sans clothing that required a nudity warning. I hate when that happens.

Overall, I didn't think this movie was all that bad. I was interesting. My only problem was that the middle of the film (where the characters had to cross a park once the time-waves where affecting the time-line), was exactly like Jurassic park. The characters get picked off only by one. In the subway scene, there were three left, and I knew that the younger girl was going to be eaten or killed in one way of the other: Wait, 3 seconds later it happened. Then right when they were going to save the world, the baboon-lizard things break in and then a time-wave strikes. Come on, can't get more predictable then that. BUT; the plot is mostly imaginative. There were dinosaurs only during part of the movie and not in the future when it get screwed up. I liked how they made the baboon-lizard things and the eel (which scared the crap out of me). The idea of the future being messed up over a period of a few days because one of the rich guys stepped on a butterfly; was interesting. I don't think this is a 3 movie more like 6 for the predictable parts and being like Jurassic park.

reviews.review_title: A Sound of Thunder-Who's to Blame?
reviews.content: OK-It looks like I may be the only person here that actually enjoyed this film. It obviously had serious production problems but being a child of fifties sci-fi I guess I'm able to overlook more of the poor FX in this film than say the CGI generation. I found the story to be engaging, the acting adequate and the monsters scary. I did have to use some imagination though to get through some scenes in the film especially the "walking treadmill" scene but all in all an enjoyable watch. I don't know that I would have had the same feeling had I spent $10.00 to see it at the multiplex. The studio should have released it direct-to-video.There are so many aspects to a production of a film that the public is not aware of that it is hard for me to blame the director for the finished product. To me the failure of the film should fall directly upon the shoulders of the studio and the production company. The former for releasing it in it's "unfinished" form and the latter for not having enough money to properly render the special effects so critical to the success of a film of this type.

reviews.review_title: I enjoyed it,suspend belief and enjoy
reviews.content:
I enjoyed it, you can pick holes in plot and story but sit back and enjoy it
The obvious CGI, B grade acting but I stuck it and kept tossing up between solid 6 or maybe 7
But would give it a 7
The ending is 'rushed' and unbelievable but you leave the theater happy.I hate horror/scifi films with the action occurring at night or underground you know it's a money saving action but you have to really concentrate to see what happens.Most of the film is at night which is uncomfortable viewing but I stayed with it.

reviews.review_title: To make a movie this bad must have been hard work
reviews.content: I went to see this movie with a friend........... yes we are both girls, but we really do like sci-fi, but this one was too much. It is the kind of movie that might have made it big time 10 years ago, but how does somebody come to the idea of making it nowadays is beyond me. The worst part it, that it starts, well it starts with a bit of potential, the plot isn˙t really original, but nobody expected it to be mind bogging and deep.I was hoping the movie will get better up to a scene where the plants break trough the wall and there is a group of people around it, looking at it, all very surprised. After I saw that scene I knew for sure, things will only get worse. And they did, a lot worse.The plot makes no sense, the lines are mostly just plain stupid, and all the little subplots that could carry an interesting story are discarded. One too many "bad" creatures are introduced, the movie feel fragmented and as the end even if you're trying really hard, you cannot help but laugh

I watched this movie on TV. As usual, I checked IMDb to give me an idea of how this movie was liked by the movie base users. Only 3.9/10. OK, I won't watch THIS movie. On second thought I was intrigued by the cast. Some of my favorite stars. In that case how bad could it be. So I watched it, and may I say ,I really enjoyed it. I am always surprised by how seriously some people take a fantasy action film. After all, it is only fantasy, so one can get away with a multitude of sins. OK, so some of the effects could have been better, but they were, on the whole very exciting. The creatures were quite well done and sometimes, very scary. It's no secret how it will end, so I'm not giving anything away by revealing a little of the plot. The plot, based on Ray Bradburys short story may not be known by all, so why not use the basic premise. The tiniest change millions of years ago may change evolution. Guessing the ending I realized that even the "bad guys" would get a second chance. So do as I did, give this film a chance and if you are a sci-fi fan, you may be pleasantly surprised. I know I was.

reviews.review_title: Fake, low budget, lousy acting and cheap CGI Effects
reviews.content: FIrst let me say that I watched this on PPV because I didn't have anything else to do so it wasn't a total waste, it burned up an hour and a half. THe acting in this movie is really lousy. THe actors deliver the lines as though they are reading them from a teleprompter which makes it very very monotonous throughout the movie. Next, the backgrounds. As fake as fake could be. They go back to the backgrounds of the 30's. I don't think you are supposed to laugh at this movie but I found myself laughing out loud 3 times. One in particular Id like to mention is when Ed Burns and McCormack are walking together through the city. THis particular scene is so ridiculous that I almost guarantee you will laugh. THey are walking. THe screen behind them is moving and you can see how they are simply picking up their legs and putting them back down rather than actually walking (Unless people actually do just walk from side to side lol). Another humorous scene is when Burns asks McCormack what will happen as far as the screw up in time goes and McCormack asks how long its been since the jump, when they jumped into the past. Burns says "24 hours, almost exactly" and she says "Well Look" and opens the window shade JUST IN TIME TO SEE THE TIME WAVE COME THROUGH!!". Then she explains that its going to happen every 24 hours and exactly what will happen each time it comes through. Never in the movie do they explain how she knows all this, she just does. One of the other laughable scenes if when you see monsters that the Dinosaurs and Apes have evolved into. First of all they look extremely fake, as do all of the monsters in the movie. I would compare the monster CGI to an average video game. Take my word for it, this is NO Jurassic Park. In fact the Tyranosaur is so cheesy you would think it came from a cartoon, its that bad. THink "Land of the Lost" only worse. Anyway, since they screwed up time and changed everything the Dinosaurs apparently didn't disappear. They "evolved". Dinosaurs and apes must have somehow figured out a way to mate in the past because what we have is Dinoapes or you might call them apeosaurs. Whatever you call them, RIDICULOUS is a word that fits. Simply put, they look like man size lizards with baboon faces. And they walk both on all fours and upright. At one point in the movie Burns makes the comment "They have really evolved". THey have? Into Apeosaurs! Crimeny what crap this movie is. Now, don't get me wrong. For some serious laughs and to be astounded by some serious lousy acting and cheesy CGI this movie is worth the viewing. But if your looking for a serious Time Travel movie, I suggest seeing something else.

I watched this film expecting a horrendous piece of crap. What i got... was exactly that. The main problem was the CG. The city of Chicago in 2055 looked so clearly green screened it made I, Robot look like Inception. And the designs of the creatures. Oh, where to start? It's like the producers looked at the very first design and decided to stick with it. Their animations hardly looked fluid. And the actors hardly tried. Not even Ben Kingsley in a wig could save A Sound Of Thunder.Pray The Relic is 10 times better.

Reading the back of the DVD, this movie sounds quite good. Some actors I've heard of, and a really great idea as the plot, but boy did they mess it up somewhere along the way.When watching this movie, I almost fell asleep. I also came very close to just giving up on it, but I decided I wanted to see the ending, yet it too was a let down. I am amazed that studios let such a terrible movie waste their money away. Sure, there are some great movies out now, like The Prestige (have to watch it a few times, NOT JUST ONCE) but the balance is evened out by the sheer amazing amount of useless movies studios churn out every year.The thing that bugs me about this movie is that they had it all there, they had a good plot to work with, they had a good idea to start with, but they took it and ran it into the ground with terrible acting, cheap and pathetic looking scenes, and drawing out the story way longer than it needs to be.Looking back, the entire movie could be half the length and get the same point across. In conclusion, if you like the story, I suggest Jurassic Park, because this movie is putrid.

reviews.review_title: Really good movie! Special Effects were before 'their' time.
reviews.content:
I bought the DVD. It's a keeper.
It's 2021 and I happened upon this title and watched it from my library. It's a great movie! It's got a very good written story, with lots of action, some drama that you can sink your teeth into and some great special effects on film.
This is something I keep, JUST BECAUSE I like the special effects on big screen, in ADDITION to the fact its a great movie.
I remember when I first watched it in 2005, I noticed the sharp contrast in the film APPEARANCE and thought it odd, and maybe too much computer generated backgrounds instead of actual filming BUT, now is 2021 and I am used to my 4K tv, and realize the depth of the picture etc is really good quality and probably before it's time , back in 2005, see? *pun pun*
This is really good time-paradox tale, with lots of unique monsters, and a vile villain. It's got cool effects, cool gadgets and inventions, and some handsome and very talented actors. Aside from the shoot em up violence I would recommend this to any audience. There's no cursing and no nudity. They made a great movie without catering to any cheap shots to pull more audience into it. WELL DONE.

I think people are often in too much of a hurry to condemn a film for their own reasons. I found this movie entertaining and well made. It is not one of the best of all time but for me , a wonderfully escapist treat. I am surprised at how harshly some people have judged it and wonder if they actually watched it completely at all. I am saddened by the negative comments on films sometimes , especially if the average viewer reads and follows the advice of the writer. In this case the creatures are believable, the suppositions plausible and the acting ... better than average. Grab a friend, some popcorn and this movie and I'm sure that you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people say, not bad film
reviews.content: Not the best film, but clearly as good as others of similar like (Godzilla, Jurassic park, Etc), Granted CGI's are not great, However who cares its the story that counts, the premise is OK, go back really far back in time and slight changes can have unpredictable effects on the present, Been done before, and is far fetched (Like Godzilla and Jurassic park are not just as far fetched !!!), I agree that there could have been a bit more explanation, however the film was not spoilt by this.From watching this I can recommend it to people, Personally I prefer a more in depth type of film with a complex plot which u need to think about, however many people enjoy just watching a film without thinking too much.All in all a good action / fantasy film which kids should enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Sound of a Thunderous Bad Movie
reviews.content: I remember reading this short story by Ray Bradbury, and was captivated by its thought provoking brilliance, as warning about time travel (as if that will ever come to pass) as well as an intriguing adventure for well heeled hunters... so I was extremely excited to see that it had been made into a movie. Welllllll... the spirit of the story was destroyed on just about every level - awful, absolutely incoherent story, awful dialogue, awful, awful awful effects (in the age of Lord of the Rings - how dare they!). Even awfuller acting, especially by a British girl doing a bad job of playing an American. One bright spot - Ben Kingsley was brilliant in the midst of this bizarre muck. (SPOILER ALERT) The original story - highly recommended - was adequate for a film, perhaps a short film, because it showed immediately the dramatic effect of disrupting the most mundane item millions of the years in the past. In Bradbury's story, when the time traveling hunters return, they find that language is a bit off, different people are running the country... obvious that somebody on the safari had screwed up. Why not just go in that direction? Really a shame. Too bad Spielberg didn't handle this one.

*Distr.(US) by Warner Bros (2005)*I did enjoy my viewing of AST. The suspense that had me at the edge of my seat till the end, more than made up for some of the film's other shortcomings. Heike Makatsch, is lovely in the female lead. Ben Kingsley as always, gives a splendid performance as the leader of the antagonists. The depiction of the "time-wave" idea is original and unique to cinema, though some of the other special effects had one feeling like you are playing a computer game. A single event in the past (in this case the killing of a butterfly) alters the chain of evolution so much that mutants take over the Earth leaving the protagonists in a race against time to save the human race.If you do like having an objective understanding of time travel, then this film is a must see, along with the negative: Butterfly Effect, The (2004- a year before A Sound of Thunder, an adult romance), or eventhe positive: Back to the Future (and Trilogy, a family movie), Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure (a comedy/horror series), Lost in Space (science fiction /horror)

Hmmm...where to begin...should I start first with the terrible script, horrible special effects or completely laughable plot line filled with monumental flaws in science? Let me begin with saying that Hollywood has bastardized yet another good story by cramming ridiculous CGI effects and terrible writing down our throats. The story is based around the fundamentals of time travel and evolution, and this movie constantly defies everything we know of the topic. A classic allegory written by Ray Bradbury...destroyed by writers Thomas Dean Donnelly, Joshua Oppenheimer and Gregory Poirier.Is this movie what we are left with? Has Hollywood officially run out of quality screenplays to keep us paying obscene ticket prices to balance the over-inflated actor's salaries? I am TOTALLY disappointed with Ed Burns and Ben Kingsley...what where you guys thinking? For two actors that have proved themselves with quality roles in the past...I think it's time to re-visit your ability to differentiate between Hollywood fodder and quality film-making.Paper thin characters, major plot holes and B rated effects coupled with too many Green Screen moments left this movie to be my #1 Cinematic Disaster of 2005.

reviews.review_title: Not As Bad As People Think
reviews.content: This is based on one of Ray Bradbury's wonderful short stories and doesn't measure up to the source material. But neither does the classic giant monster movie, "The Beast From Twenty Thousand Fathoms", compare to "The Fog Horn". The Harryhausen-driven SFX movie didn't have any of the melancholy poetry of the original short story.And this movie doesn't either. Not when you compare it to the master's original. But the story, with some corny, stereotypical moments, is a decent SF thriller. The effects are awesome and the overall pacing of the story is good.If you're looking for a good way to waste a couple of hours, and not expecting something like Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" or Scott's "Blade Runner", this might be worth a look.And do yourself a favor afterwords, read the original story (and "The Fog Horn"). Beautifully crafted short stories.As to Ben Kingsley? Maybe, like Max Von Sydow in "Flash Gordon" or "Strange Brew" or Maximilian Schell in "The Black Hole", he just wanted to have some fun making a movie.

The acting was terrible, the cheesy, fake, CHEAP green screen effects were ridiculous, and the creatures were absolutely retarded. The only good thing about this movie was the concept, and the laughs I got from watching such a bad movie- then I became pretty angry because I realized I wasted 4 bucks on renting it. Why would a movie like this ever be in theaters? I know this movie came out almost 5 years ago, but does anyone put any effort into making movies anymore? I am just writing random things to fill up space- because I need ten lines of text in order to publish this review. This next line should just about do it. Annnndddddd there!

I thought this movie was great. It started out a little slow, but it was building the story, explaining... This movie represented possibilities to things you hope could never happen, but what if? Interesting concept, cool special effects, good storyline. Everything was not presented in black and white, so it took some figuring out and stretching of your mind to understand what was going on. Once chaos began, it kept you on the edge of your seat wondering what could possibly happen next, all because of something so small, overlooked, insignificant.... All in all, I would definitely recommend this movie to others!

When I hear there was a "Ray Bradbury" story about time travel coming-out I couldn't wait to see it and I was not disappointed. The special effects are excellent. The story line is believable and easy to follow. The film is also genuinely scary in parts. The movie is just plain fun. It's good to see a sci-fi film that is worth watching. This film is actually worth going to see on the big screen, which is also rare these days. I hope there are more movies coming out in the near future that can keep up with this one. Maybe will see a Ray Bradbury film explosion in our future. Although I doubt it, this film seems to be focused a little too narrowly on sci-fi fans to win broad market support.

Don't know what Peter Hyams was thinkin' of . Either he lost some marbles or this was done by someone else . What was I lookin at ? A parody ? A drama ? Was I supposed to laugh all the time ?In music terms I would see this as a Frank Zappa at his worst .What do we get ?We get Jurrasic park meets 50's SF , meets Star Gate , meets Star Trek , meets Day of the triffids ....what a mess .The CGI is at times sooooo bad that you wander if this was done on purpose . The astronaut suits could have come out of 50's movie the likes of Forbidden planet or so .At some point I wondered if this movie would end with someone of the likes of Groucho Marx closing with a " That's All Folks " and a wink .Would I find this soooo bad , that it becomes good ? No ....is doesn't . It's a movie but not as we know it would Bones have said .

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies of 2005
reviews.content: Well before I went to see this movie I really didn't know the plot of the movie until I was watching inside movies the t.v show and it was previewing the upcoming movies for the weekend and sound of thunder was one of them and I thought the movie had a unique story line to it, so I decided what the heck why not. The movie is basically about time travel to the past back in the dinosaur days and the purpose of going back to the past is to bring these billionaire to past is a part of this big cooperation to make money off of a scientist machine Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack) who built the machine but its Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) and a team of his bring these multi-billionaires to the past to encounter a t-Rex if you will and shoot it down. You maybe asking but if they shoot the t-Rex wont that cut a glitch in the time-line well no because Mr. Ryer and friends set a 5-minute timing on t-Rex just before a volcano explodes and eventually kills the t-Rex. So they jump to the past a few times more until they have 2 odd couple billionaires wanting to jump to the past but one of which is starting to get second thoughts about going but his buddy convinces his to live on the wild side. So they all make the jump to the past once again and they wait out until the t-Rex comes then well something goes wrong with the guns and they aren't firing so Mr. Ryer try's to distract the t-Rex while the 2 billionaire run away like any billionaires would in this situation. Eventually Travis Ryer got his gun to work and shoot the t-Rex. Once they go back they notice their changes to time-line and their time-waves that are affecting everyone. Ryer and friends have the unfriendly task of finding out what altered the time-line, they track down the 2 billionaires one of which stepped on a butterfly not lying here, now they have the dangerous task of going back to the past where the original jumped took place there's only one problem they'll only have 15 seconds to warn themselves in the past. Confusing I know it was at that part of the movie I decided I'll go see the transporter 2, this I not a movie even worth buying I don't know how it made it to the big screen I'll never know. ALL IN ALL this was a badly done movie none of the actors had no to little facial expressions I mean when they had one of the team members ends up getting attack by some dis-informed app-monkeys nobody screamed or showed any worry to the situation, when the movie first started I noticed how badly done CGI computer generated images the cars don't even look real and neither does the city very unbelievable, my first thought of this movie was this must have been a low budget movie I find out on IMDb they spent 80 million dollars on this that movie, the money definitely didn't go to the actors. Am giving this movie a 2/10 just for the concept of the movie.

reviews.review_title: Not that good. Not that bad. The special effects are bad.
reviews.content:
This is definitely not an A-list movie. The story is bad, the special effects are horrible and the dinosaur looks like something from an animated movie.
But if you can look past that and have about 100 minutes, it's an okay movie to watch. But just DON'T expect a great movie.
But it could serve as an inspiration if Hollywood one day decides to remake this as an all-star A-list Hollywood version.
It's not that bad, but not that good either.
I'd give it 60%, or a 6/10.

reviews.review_title: Plot line from a German short film
reviews.content: This picture is a bad and blown up rip off of the Michael Pohl short film EXTINCT from 1995. While Michael Pohl's idea was original and perfect for a short film setting, A SOUND OF THUNDER's plot was poorly adapted from Pohl's story and not fit for a full length feature film one would expect from a major Hollywod studio. The tragic flooding situation that ruined the sets in Prague was just one bad link in a long rusty film production chain in this case. For a studio to release such a product... it is a shame. Especially for Warner Brothers, a studio which broke new effects grounds with shows like BABYLON 5 in 1993. On TELEVISION. Visual effects for television shows pioneering CGI in episodic television in the mid nineties were way more sophisticated than what is brought to the screen in this picture. In cases like this, sad as it may be: Can the film.

reviews.review_title: Good Music Score, Nice Action Scenes, Good Story Line. Could use some better special effects.
reviews.content: After reading some of the reviews on this site, I thought this movie was going to really suck. After watching it on DVD, I didn't really think that it was as bad as people made it out to be. The soundtrack is great in my opinion, as well as the story line. The action scenes were pretty cool, even though the special effects weren't extremely excellent. I think that this movie could have been excellent if a little more time was spent on it, and a little more work was put into it. Overall though, not a really bad film. Just don't expect to be floored by it. I didn't get a chance to see this in the theaters, but I am kind of glad that I didn't spend the $20.00 to go see it. I knew about this movie quite a long time ago from the database site that I am a member of. I thought it sounded cool, but after reading further into it, I found out that it was barely even finished on budget. This is probably why all of the special effects aren't as great as they should have been.

reviews.review_title: not bad needed more money to make it better
reviews.content: i saw this tonight-I've been looking forward to seeing it since it was announced 2 yr back but then i think it was going to star Liam neeson or someone-any way the movie-well its got a good enough story some good actors -even if ben kingsley looked like he was trying to win pantomime villain of the year.but i like him so i put this down to the studio-or director.also if it was a starring role for someone like will smith-tom cruise etc it would have been given a lot more money etc-its just a same no one bothered to put more money into it,the special affects -ie dinosaurs+wave were OK-but the city's etc were completely over the top-there's a part where the hero is "walking down the st with the inventor"and you can tell there not walking-+they must be just walking on a conyeror belt-but if you can put aside this and enjoy the film its not bad -with more decent effects it could have been a big movie-i remember when total film advertised it as a big blockbuster coming soon-but then it did have a lot more money-actors in the pipeline-one more think this is your standard movie in the same way has category 6+7 and supernova-when it comes to effects-but with a bit of a better story.by the way this is my opinion and no-one has to agree-but i still say watch the film.

reviews.review_title: Could have been much, much better.
reviews.content: When I was in 7th grade I read "A Sound of Thunder" by Ray Bradbury. I liked it very much. This film I did not like. One night I was sitting at home debating about what to rent on demand, and I previewed this movie. In the preview the only CGI effect shown was the dinosaur, that was a pretty sucky image, but I figured that was just one flaw and the rest of the movie would be great especially with Ed Burns and Ben Kingsley on the screen--I was wrong. Not only did this movie not in anyway follow the story, but the effects were quite possibly the worse ones I had ever seen (no exaggeration). I don't even think I saw one scene that wasn't computerized in some place. Just about the only effect I did like was when each "wave" hit and everything went in slow-motion and the audio got choppy.The adventure would have been great if it didn't look so damn fake. It got boring because of the lack of quality. A lot of pointless parts were included as well, when the first scientist died he was getting delirious and telling some story about how is family members got him a telescope or something, that made me feel embarrassed to be watching this film. Several parts were stupid and very (for lack of a better word) corny.The idea of the movie was actually entertaining and could have been excellent, but the graphics and acting killed it for me. Ed Burns also happens to be an excellent actor. Even though his acting wasn't as up-to-snuff as usual in this picture, his role plus a storyline with potential just locked in a 4 out of 10 star vote from me.

I remember reading about this film over a year ago when Pierce Brosnan was attached to star. Brosnan was replaced by Ed Burns (Saving Private Ryan) when the budget was cut. Burns does a good job in this sci-fi time travel/paradox film. The effects were a bit rough (due to budget problems) but the story is good enough to ignore the dubious effects. The story is set 50 odd years in the future where rich eccentrics pay a team to take them back in time to the cretaceous period to hunt dinosaurs. The main rule of time travel is don't change anything, no matter how small. However, on one of the trips something is changed that has disastrous effects on the evolution chain. The team have to work out what was changed and rectify it before history catches up with them and the results of an altered history become permanent. The only real knock to the film was Catherine McCormack as the female lead. Her character was totally unlikeable and she never really seemed to fit with the rest of the cast.

First, I just want to say that I really liked this film. I tend to avoid most movies that fall into the sci-fi/fantasy genre, but I was incredibly drawn to this story. And as i figured, I was pleased. It was very clever and very engaging.However -- and this isn't as big of a deal to me as a decent story -- the special effects are, at times, so bad it's funny. If the only reason why you see movies is for the special effects, then I suggest you avoid this one. I just want to know what happened, what they were thinking. This movie could have been a huge blockbuster, but the special effects team was so sadly misguided. You think they would have left some money in the budget for post-production work.Honestly, that's the only problem I found with this film. It has an even pace, decent performances, sufficient thrills, and fairly developed characters. Before you rent it, read the back of the case. If the story itself doesn't interest you, rent something else.

reviews.review_title: Two out of three is bad.
reviews.content: Forget special effects they are just eye candy. Three things make a good movie, the director, the actors and the script. You can occasionally escape this trio if you get an inept director or a bad actor, but NEVER with a bad script. Sound of Thunder had the bad script. Where do they get these idiots we laughingly call writers. And how does anyone convince investors to put money into such rubbish. Frankly I get insulted. Do the people who decide to produce this stuff believe the viewing public are that stupid not to see the large gaping plot holes and the inconsistencies. Where is the intelligence?? This is Burtons "Planet of the Apes" all over again.Spoilers  They go back & kill the same Allaraurous dinosaur 3 times. Now assuming the time continuum does some sort of reset to compensate for a paradox which allows this, how come he can go back and warn himself in the third visit to save the world. And if it does reset every time, what they do in the past does not matter because all you have to do is visit at the same time after, do nothing and cause a reset.I am a SCFI fan but frankly, can't they get some bozo's other than 6th graders to write a better script??

For anybody who is thinking of watching this movie please please please please don't waste your time.this movie was a poor excuse of any time travel event, and you had to think what the hell the director wasthinking when he made this film. the only good movie this director actually put effort into was "end of days". My suggestion is that PeterHyams needs to go back to his roots and find out what the hell happenedbecause it seems like he has endangered his own existence with thismovie. GO BACK IN TIME AND CHANGE ITWIth Love Ryan i would haveput a 0 for voting but that option is not allowed.

reviews.review_title: If only the special effects were even half good....
reviews.content: I first read this Bradbury story as a kid in comic book form and I loved it. It was and still is a great idea. The story is pretty short and, to be honest, a little predictable. This movie is nothing like the short story aside from the idea of rich folks going back in time to hunt dinosaurs and then wrecking the future. I won't give away what happens in the short story. It's short and worth the read. Since the movie went very quickly to DVD, I figured it wasn't that great anyway. I attempted to watch it with the point of view that it was not going to be great and maybe it would be better than those crappy sci-fi channel knock-outs that come on every week with the corny effects. Or maybe as good as watching Ray Bradbury Theatre, which I also loved watching when I was younger. It was a great show. I had this feeling that this movie would be slightly better because Sir Ben Kingsly was in it. He was Ghandi for crying out loud and won an academy award. No dice. If they had even tried a bit more with special effects I would have not recommended it but gave them credit for choosing a great story to bastardize. Heck, I don't even know if a good nude scene would have saved this movie. My quick (trying to be nice) review: It was better than Battlefield Earth.

I read before, that the CGI was bad. But I did not bother that much, since a good SciFi story can also be interesting to watch, when the CGI is cheap or not so prominent (also I can enjoy rather old SciFi films, when it is interesting -- like "Millennium" with laughable special effects for todays standard, but rather viewable and not so predictable story).BUT this film tries to hard to be a blockbuster with "big action" that it absolutely must disappoint. I hoped to get at least an interesting story. But as much as it fails to deliver "big action" it also fails to deliver a really interesting story. And further more, it does to much stealing of story elements from other films. I even was remembered of the "Triffids" ... and that is a bad signal. From that point on, the film got worse and worse.The film starts rather good (aside from the bad CGI, that really can put you of). Ben Kingsley was really good as the clever and reckless business man. The story unfolds rather interesting and the writing is not that bad (in the beginning). It contained some rather good humor, writing and acting. But after a while it gets lost in all that monster fights, that seam to say: Hey, we can't have a solution now -- the film must be at least 90 minutes ... and we have fired off all our good ideas in the first 25 minutes -- we now don't have an other idea than throwing yet another bunch of CGI on the actors.So, we come to the situation, that the SciFi film converts to a slasher video. We start out with seven or so actors ... and after 80 or so minutes one or two of them are left. This is so predictable.You see nothing, that was not done before (SciFi-wise, CGI-wise and Action-Wise) in better quality. Many ideas are plain copied. Also the base story was filmed at least once before.Also there are some really bad logical errors contained. The biggest one: The change in the past is coming in waves, but in the moment, the change is changed back, this change is coming immediately -- why?? But there are also worse logical errors and gaps contained which are not explained at all. I would also rather have a more elaborate ending and cut off one or two of those CGI fights which did not add to the story at all. So, the ending was the biggest disappointment ... also because of the big list of gaps and "illogicalities" it contains alone.To round it up: I had hoped to find a little more substance -- and even with rather good performances from some actors (Kingsley, Makatsch) all in all, the film can not satisfy, since so many older films provided more substance with similar stories (e.g. Millennium, Jurrasic Park, .....) The start of the film could have been an 6/10 -- but with the middle part and the weak ending, it is 4/10. The really interesting part are the first 25 minutes or so, after that it gets more and more predictable and the finish is to much clustered with story-gaps. Instead of an interesting twist (which I hoped for) they just "gap" the resolution out. The extremely weak ending alone costs the film at least one point in my voting.

...After reading the other reviews I approached this film with some trepidation. Now I have to say that whilst not up there with the big ones it is still pretty good. I have concluded that the almost vitriolic condemnation comes from not really understanding the the premise - "changing the past changes the future". This was explained in the film but obviously some people were not listening. Crushing a butterfly 65 million years ago, which therefore did not produce offspring -which did not produce their offspring etc, could conceivably make a change in the evolutionary process. Is anyone arguing with the asteroid hit theory that destroyed the dinosaurs and gave the mammals their big chance? Basically the same thing..... The effects were passable - in fact the idea of the primate-reptile was quite clever

I first read "A Sound of Thunder" during the early 50's when comic books were being banned for contributing to juvenile delinquency. I was an avid EC fan and came across this short story by Ray Bradbury with artwork by either Frank Frazetta or Al Williamson or both, (They sometimes worked together.) It was the fantastic art that drew me to the story. I had never heard of Bradbury, though the people at EC claimed that he was their favorite SciFi contributer. I wasn't impressed with the story but was crazy about the artwork. Anyway, "A Sound of Thunder" comes to TV (HBO) and,of course,I tuned in. I figured with Edward Burns and Ben Kingsley it was worth a look-see. Gee, it was a disappointment to say the least and an insult to Ray Bradbury. Stephen King was next, with his novel "The Butterfly Effect" that I have yet to read (It's my understanding that it's an extended version of Bradbury's short story.) However, don't spoil yourself by seeing this horrendous movie.

reviews.review_title: Worst film i have ever seen
reviews.content: It was .....AWFUL. Its the worst film i have ever watched. Alright, i stayed till the end to watch this crap movie end. But just barely 20mins at the start and I cant believe that there are people who decided to film this film and people who would agreed to act in this. Everything about this film is fake. The city is so fake, the streets, the guns that were used to kill the dinos, the cars... If this film is shown during the 80s or early 90s. I can understand it the limited technology use to create such a futuristic blockbuster. But its filmed in the 21st century!! What a shame!!And they went back just to kill dinos who are gonna die anyway.. Are those people in the year 2055 so bored that they spend a fortune or put their names on a 6 year wait list to go back in the jurassic age to kill dino for 20mins?

reviews.review_title: Candidate for worst time travel/Scifi movie ever
reviews.content: My goodness what a disappointment! Even with a low budget one can make a good scifi or time travel movie if the plot is intelligent and the actors are convincing. None of this is the case with this sad piece of wasted time. The actors apparently are only in it for the money; particularly Ben Kingsley acts so mechanical, bored and not connected to his role that one can feel how much he hated his job(and himself, probably, for having to make a buck by playing in this movie). The CGI is so poor that one wonders if it is due to the lack of money for special fx or because of the incapability of the CGI designers. The plot.... what could be a good idea is completely wasted in the ever growing paltriness of the effects and the ridiculous CGI-generated characters (a dim rip-off of Jurassic parc characters). The time travel issue is merely a pretense for silly chases and bad acting. Apart from few minutes in the beginning, the entire movie displays the lack of money and the un-inspiredness of playwrights and director. I didn't even watch the movie to the end. Summary: Waste of time.

reviews.review_title: Traveling back in time, a small change causes big problems for humanity
reviews.content: This was an exciting movie that is not as bad as the reviews would indicate. The effects of futuristic Chicago are pretty bad, but the creatures they encounter are pretty realistic. Watched it with the family and it scared them. The acting was pretty straightforward B movie, but it had more thrills than the Grudge or the Ring. The concept is the same basic one as the Butterfly Effect or even 13 going on 30....if you change something in the past, it has big implications on the future. Since this comes from the Ray Bradbury short story it pre-dates the other movies, even if the release of this movie does not. This is a good movie to rent on a Saturday night or to watch on cable.

Time travel and dinosaurs. Can you ask for more? Well, the story is actually pretty good, with some holes here and there. Some of the CGI is OK, and some actually so horrible (even for 2005) that they should have left it out. The movie is watchable with an exciting theme, as long as you can live with Commodore 64 graphics in some of the scenes.

..that dd not carry through into the presentation.I did not read anything about the movie before I started watching it....no preconceptions to deal with good or bad.The theory was good...the premise of the movie was good but the presentation needed a bigger budget. I would have wished the special effects were better as well as improvements to the script.Overall I liked the movie, but I found myself disappointed in Hyams this time around.Watch it only if you don't mind a lower class of effects, and are willing to enjoy it as it is.

reviews.review_title: Fun for most of the family
reviews.content: Given the conciseness (about 10 pages) of the Bradbury short story on which "A Sound Of Thunder" is based, it was inevitable that any movie version would have to take some liberties with the source. That would be putting it mildly for this film, which strays far and wide from its base. And yet, in its own Hollywood way, the movie stays true to the central concept of the story - how the smallest alteration of a long-past event could have ramifications cascading far into the future.That the dialog and acting have flaws is not unique to "Thunder's" literary-to-screen transition, and those flaws did not take so much away from my enjoyment of the file that I was truly dissatisfied. I did not see this movie in a theater, but on HBO, with someone who'd not read the story. Although HBO's own synopsis declared the film a "shoddy" adaptation, both of us felt that might be just a bit strong.Many of the FX in "Thunder" seem derived from other modern sci-fi films - Aliens to Star Wars and much else. Occasionally it displays some originality. If it were a little more well done, I'd give it another star or two. In fact, I'll give it an extra half-star for not having any tedious, contrived romantic sub-plots (at least I don''t remember any). When I saw this movie, I hadn't even known it'd made the transition from printed page to film, so I had no expectations. It's obviously not a major work and may not stand up to repeated viewings, but I was happy enough with what I saw.

I saw this movie today and the green screen effects don't actually look green. However when you saw the people close up walking down the street you could tell it was the green screen scenery going by. I have also seen this effect when they shoot in cars but not always. In fact once in Seattle I saw a movie being shot with a car scene. What they did was put the car on a trailer and shoot from the truck that was pulling the trailer with the car. That way everything looked natural such as the reflections going by.A lot of the scenes of 2055 Chicago looked OK. Then this same Chicago got invaded by more and more plants and then animals. I guess you would have to make a set for that and then add more plants and animals as each time wave comes by.Those pre-historic scenes looked much better with all those plants but you could tell those animals as well as the animals that came in time waves to Chicago looked like they were made of rubber.When the movie started you saw WB and then Franchise Pictures presents. No mention was make of the Franchise going under then or during the closing credits.When the movie was over I watched all the credits role by to see if there were any improvements make by WB when they took over the movie but none were mentioned. Most of it was shot in the Czech Republic and many of the people had names from that region you could tell. No mention of the floods was given in 2002. The movie said copyright 2004 and Franchise was in the closing credits but not WB.Spoiler ending ahead.In the end as the time wave that changes humans they are able to finally make that trip back in the nick of time to meet the expedition just before the shoot and stop them from stepping on the butterfly. They did finally find the butterfly on the shoe before that final trip back. However they didn't have to actually replace the dead butterfly because when they warned them they were able to save the butterfly which you saw flying off. The crushed butterfly problem was caused by the gun not working correctly. It is the leader that is to say when the guns are ready to fire and he is the one who activates the guns for the other members.
