He couldn't get the guns to activate properly and as the Rex tries to attack the hunters one person fall off the special tract. You can see a mud footprint on the tract as they return so that is where the guy fell. When they come back from the trip to correct things they do succeed and everything is back to normal. There is no altered spelling or a different person winning the election like the short story. 2055 is not an election year but 2052 in the short story is.

reviews.review_title: Not Bad At All, If Not The Best
reviews.content: H! there,The fact that many people may not be liking this movie (rather most), is that there can be very little, small detail missing, that can act as an ant in the trunk of an elephant, preventing fresh air to the elephant. And when people are unable to point what's wrong, they go mad on why they did not get satisfaction after spending money. Once I thought that the movie Spiderman was a hit because there was a shine in the costume of the Spiderman. For when I myself watched the poster, I thought wow, what a costume, must go and watch the movie. Here, I am able to point out what attracted me to a movie. If that costume was not good enough, I can say it would have been very difficult for me to go to a Spiderman movie, because somehow the concept of Spiderman does not interest me at all. After all, the weirdness of his powers is itself the limitation of the Spiderman; at least it seems so. Now Superman is something. And for the movie "Spiderman" too, I thought I would not go, until I saw that costume.Secondly, most people of today's era, and all over the world, don't like too much of a hi-fi stuff and space and time gibberish, or the movie "Star Wars" and all its sequels would be the biggest hits ever, for which people have camped outside the theatres prior to the release dates, in the US, to watch sequels. Can you name any movie for which this has been done ever? But this is for the "curiosity-conscious". People here in India went to see Terminator sequels because they have heard about Shwarzenneger. Otherwise films like these are garbage to Indian audience. Here in India, you make a real, REAL crap of a love story drama with a few senseless songs in it, and the movie is still okay if not very good, with the audience, even if the story hardly meets its own parameters.What's wrong in this movie is that it has a problem with the contrast; the brightness is less. So the effect of flashing sunlight in daytime is kind of eaten away, that robs of a certain reality in the movie. I understand the movie had run into many problems for a couple of years. But this effect is also not that bad; it can be associated with the tone for this particular movie; there are various tones out these days, for different movies.And as far as the special effects are concerned, people tend to dislike everything of something they did not enjoy. The special effects were much advanced than any of the Jurassic Park movies; after all, the technology is now more advanced. The effects were, in fact, quite good. If someone says the effect of 'time wave' in this movie wasn't good, then he needs to describe how a time wave looks like. But even the visualization of the 'time wave' was also good enough. In fact, the brain wave of the time wave coming and affecting everything one after another was a good one! As far as acting is concerned, this movie wasn't the movie "Scent of a Woman". It was the message of the movie all the way, with less scope for showcasing acting skills.A Sci-fi movie is like the making of a musical composition. You can start it real bad, but now the rest of the matter has to be IN ACCORDANCE of what has been started. And if this happens, the creation becomes at least inevitable, if not a masterpiece. And this movie meets these parameters perfectly.We highly enjoyed it.

How can they say that we, humans, are the last to evolve???? EVERYTHING is in a constant mutation! Evolution!! Our sons are smarter, taller and stronger than us! The plants evolve! The animals!Another thing... Can someone explain to me, when they go back the second time, why they don't meet with the first trip? And, why, when the hero goes back for the third time, he meets the second team?Special effects not so special. Bluescreen on the back all the time. The cars, the buildings... So bad, so bad... But, one thing I must say, at least, the animals, they were nicely done. I didn't leave the cinema because my girlfriend didn't let me! 20mn were enough. Don't go watch this...

Based on a short story by the great Ray Bradbury, this is a fast-moving and suspenseful yarn with a good cast. Edward Burns gives a good turn as a technical expert brought in to usher "clients" into the prehistoric past for the thrill of hunting dinosaurs. Although the special effects are good, they don't overwhelm the movie. The characters are actually believable and you wind up caring about a few of them. I do not remember reading any reviews on this and I consider it a nice find in this genre. The primary female lead, Catherine McCormack, plays the scientist who created the software/technology that opens the porthole to time travel. She is well-cast and develops her character with more subtlety than time should allow. When Burns' character meets her, she has had a falling-out with the man (Ben Kingsly very good as an over-the-top greedy millionaire)who funded, and now owns the technology and the venture it spawned. Both characters mesh well with the story. Jemima Rooper is the young pretty assistant who Burns looks after. There are rich clients, a corrupt government overseer and other members of the crew sprinkled in for effect. The plot takes you in a different direction than expected. All in all a fun tale with a capable cast. Enjoy.

I felt that the movie had a very sad production. It looked as if they used a digital camera to shoot the films, and the green screening was horrible. The night scenes they made it all blurry so it was not as horrible as the light scenes. I did like the movie in full, just felt that it had no funding, and I am curious to know if anyone knows. If you do email me at Pagigostra831@yahoo.comAlso, has anyone else noticed that the writers strike never ended? All the movies that are coming out are covers of old ones, remakes and then comic books into movies. T_T Anyways, I did enjoy the movie as I said before.

reviews.review_title: What are you people bitching about? Have you seen the last batch of sequels that we've been force fed?!?
reviews.content: "A Sound Of Thunder" the WORST thing you've ever seen? "A Sound of THUD?" Please. Sometimes it's just easier to tow the line than buck the reviewers, isn't it?Fun. Well paced. Exciting. A child-like sense of wonder captured on film, and yes, it's OK if an adult enjoys a child-like sense of wonder once in a while. It's good for ya. Relax.I found this film a pleasant surprise. No, it isn't brilliant, and that's OK - it's ENTERTAINING. Good old fashioned Hollywood stuff. I actually liked Ed Burns in a film for once. If you liked TIME COP, see this film. The two movies could play on a double bill, with "Thunder" being the sequel.Relax about the special effects - they aren't all going to be at ILM level. Not everyone can AFFORD ILM. Bitchy audiences. You'll sit through the next 10 summer movie sequels and have your plot and CGI expectations handed to you on a platter, but give you some effects that merely exist in service of the story - SOMEBODY'S HEAD HAS TO ROLL!! I want my fake computer illusions to look better than this!! I paid good money to look at the same CGI crap again!! WHERE'S MY CRAP?!?The effects SUCKED? Really? What do you KNOW about effects? Do a lot of dinosaur animation in your free time, do you?What I'm saying is this - did you really expect them to NOT make the movie because they couldn't do every effect better than all films that had come before? Do you know how hard it is just to get a film completed? It would be like Joe Average walking out to his driveway and saying, "Hey, I'm not going to work today if I can't drive there in a BMW, so I'm not going..."If EVERY production that didn't have enough money to do everything perfect EVERY TIME shut down, there wouldn't be A SINGLE FILM MADE. Ever again. Period.Me personally? I'd rather be entertained. Hell, I say we get Ray Harryhausen back out of retirement. Bitch about that, CGI addicts...By the way, NO, the title, "A Sound of Thunder" isn't directly explained in the dialog of the film, you have to actually THINK about it. And if you are even remotely clever, you'll figure it out by at least the time Ed Burns and Catherine McCormack are looking out the window of her apartment, watching the time distortion effect "thunder" toward them...duh.

I'm a big sci-fi fan and I thoroughly enjoyed Ray Bradbury's original story. So I was a little disappointed with the direction the film took. The basic premise of both is the same: In the future there is a time travel company which takes rich people into the past to shoot dinosaurs. During one of the trips, a client gets scared, ends up killing a butterly and causes a "butterfly effect" which affects events which come after.In the original story, the main effect was on human culture and politics. And I would have preferred if the movie had been more faithful to the original story and had explored how the characters dealt with a different political system. (Maybe looking at what a totalitarian or fascist regime might do with the power to go back in time and how the heroes might respond to the new timeline.) In the film, the main effect was on evolution and so A sound of Thunder quickly turned into a silly kind of monster movie.

My friend recommended this movie to me.Is should have known not to watch it because my friend is kind of a video game nerd. But the name and the cover made it look good for some reason. I was so wrong. I mean first of all, what is up with their suits? And the acting! It seems like they got the people off Barney. Except for Ben Kingsley. And why was he even in this movie? Did he think it was a comedy! But I have to say the special effects were pretty good. But that was like the only good thing in it. I mean seriously, the movie is worse than Pearl Harbor. And thats actually an understatement. Everyone must have thought "oh I am getting paid so it doesn't matter if its the worst movie in the world." I would understand why someone would make this kind of movie if they were directing, acting, producing, writing, and getting their hopeless life best friend to do filming and editing. Probably one of the worst sci-fi movies ever. One truly jacked up film

Before I saw this movie, I'd never heard of it. I didn't really expect it to be good, because I figured if it was good, I would have known about it previously. The movie premise is pretty cool, although its not obvious. Somewhere in the beginning, you learn animals are extinct. The jumps are being done in hope of being able to reconstruct untainted DNA to bring animals back.The movie bases itself around the butterfly effect. This theory states changing something in the past has ripple effects through time. Well, something happens, and history (and the future) gets changed. The cgi effects are good in this film, both creating the jungle terra and the newly evolved animals.I loved this movie. I like the whole "what if?" scenario, and the time travelling is just icing. I wouldn't say this movie will win awards. The only big name in the film is Ben Kingsley, and his part is a minor one. But this film carries a degree of plausibility, it definitely was not what I expected.

reviews.review_title: Maybe history was altered for this movie...
reviews.content: Bear with me now, I'm going to take you on a magical adventure in what-if land, filled with twists, turns, and treachery.This movie was originally slated for release in 2003. What if this movie, in an alternate time-line, was released on time, with all the CGI perfectly done and flawless editing.Perhaps the movie was insanely popular... in fact, maybe it became the number one movie of the year. It could have been the only movie to beat out Return of the King that year.Peter Jackson didn't like having his climactic epic ruined by Ray Bradbury's little short story. So maybe in the year 2055 (ironic, no?), Peter Jackson (by this time a very old man) goes back in time and sabotages the movie by causing mass floods, production company problems, etc. The result? A Sound of Thunder is shelved for years, and finally released as an unfinished movie that is widely considered a joke. No competition in 2003 for LotR! ...Hey, at least my trumped up plot has fewer holes than this movie did.

reviews.review_title: I'm watching this movie now and...
reviews.content: I really, really wanted to like it. I love the premise behind it but did they ever screw this one up. Time travel movies have always interested me, just because they make me think 'what if' type questions. I'm a big fan of Butterfly Effect. This movie makes me think "what if I went back in time so that I never watched it?" Would my altered life be better or worse? Some of the 'monsters were pretty cool, but the sea monster was lame. I liked the rendition of what humans would evolve into...that was creepy! I think Ed Burns is better than this movie, a lot better. I close by saying my son loves it....he's 6 months old!

reviews.review_title: Three things that would have improved the movie
reviews.content: Well, anything would have improved it and I am happy I did not spend any money on it. But here is a simple three step plan: 1. Instead of the butterfly, use something that wouldn't have been killed by the volcano anyway.2. The core facility should have be protected against time waves via a force field. The force field would not protect against physical beings entering the facility, so all the silly "shoot monsters in increasing panic" - effects could have been kept. But the city outside would change after each wave.3. At the end, just before everything is restored, a fantastic culture, in every way surpassing ours, would be shown.

The story was decent, but the FX left a lot to be desired. Many times it was quite obvious that they were in front of a green screen. It was worse than a '70s movie.While there were some holes in the story line that did not mesh with the original short, it was still worth the price of the rental.Yes, the writers completely ignored everything that you would normally associate with time travel, namely that changes in history affects the future instantly, not in waves. R Bradbury understood that when he wrote the short.If you are into Bradbury, this is a good second movie for a weekend. Don't count on it being the highlight, though

reviews.review_title: A Great Story and not a bad flick.
reviews.content: I don't know any of the circumstances surrounding the bankruptcy of the production company,but this isn't as bad a movie as everyone is saying. Yes, it's production values are questionable,the CGI stuff is bottom shelf,the kind that looks like it was done on a home PC and a good paint proggy,but...I have to say,the story holds up pretty well and it's a compelling story. Travelers to the future inadvertently screw something up and have to return to reverse the damage???Man that's a classic great story. If you can overlook some cheapy SFX the acting is O.K. and the movie moves at a pretty good clip. Of course I had the benefit of watching it on my DVR (tivo)so I was able to swing through this movie in about 1/3 the time it would normally take.So considering that,I'd have to give this one 2 thumbs up =)

reviews.review_title: I found this movie to be very interesting Sci Fi story
reviews.content: For me to watch this movie, as entertainment, was a satisfying experience. The glitches of time lines and names on helmets were not what the story was about. When you look to be entertained, it just might happen. The time ripples that brought about changes when they occurred added an element of urgency to find what had caused the change and then effect a correction, but at least one member of this rapidly shrinking party had to survive and had to get back to the past mishap and undo the damage. Even the bio filter being left off to increase the profit margin was so modern corporate greedy an idea (i.e. NASA, ENRON and Haliburton) even with government oversight and regulations. I like this movie and have recommended it to F. Paul Wilson for his personal review.

reviews.review_title: "Time Machine" + "Jurassic Park" + Horrible Effects - Plot = Crap
reviews.content: I was actually looking forward to seeing this movie because I thought the story looked cool and the last movie I saw with Ben Kingsley (Suspect Zero) was very good. Unfortunately, this movie was horrible and if it weren't for "The Brothers Grimm" would be the worst movie I've seen this year. The CG was shameful and looked like it was done up on someone's home computer. If you saw this movie and then watched "Jurassic Park" you would swear that this movie came out over ten years before based on the effects, not the other way around. If the terrible special effects weren't enough (and for most of the people watching it with me they were) the story was also awful. Under no circumstance is this movie worth seeing, thankfully it is not longer in theatres, if you see it at the video store don't rent it, if in 5 years you see it at the bargain bin at the local WalMart for three dollars don't buy it. It is that bad.

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like this so much
reviews.content: This is a very poor movie that I wanted to enjoy so much. The trailer left so much to the imagination that I just had to get this. CG is hopeless, and the acting is laughably bad. When people talk to each other there is usually a pause until the other person mentally digests your fast-talk into something he can answer back with. This is a serious flaw, and I can't imagine how directors are allowed to get away with it. Mc.Cormack is a real sexy woman, but her change in accents between the start and end is incredible. Oh, and killing a butterfly just before it is vaporised in the dust of the volcano wouldn't change that much.Still I have to admit that I am a sucker for these movies, and my 8 year old daughter was deliciously terrifies by the bits of tension in it. So I bumped my vote to 4 instead of 2. Good job I only rented it before buying! Otherwise, this is a clanger!

I just rented this movie thinking that I liked the concept. Which I still do, but A Sound Of Thunder really let me down. I was expecting a movie that (especially after the line "It's bulletproof" when talking about their time traveling and how well they have things figured out) shows a humanity which has perfected time travel. I didn't know what to expect concerning the dinosaur hunting, so when they presented the idea that they kill the dinosaurs they knew were going to die in a matter of minutes anyway, I thought this movie was on to something.Oh yes, the green screen. To imitate Chandler "Could it BE anymore obvious?!" There was that one scene that was just so ridiculous, I couldn't believe this movie was made in 2005! How hard can it be to get two people to take a walk on a set? How hard was it to build a set? Was there enough funding for this movie? They actually had Edward Burns and uh... the woman. Was it the lady who invented the AI? Anyway, they're just walking along and it is incredibly obvious that they just have green screen behind them and they're on a treadmill or whatever they may be using.And then when they do go and hunt the dinosaurs, there's so much green screen, I don't think there were many sets involved, and even the ones that were involved were probably basic and the rest was green screen. I feel ripped off by this movie because with all we can do with technology these days, this movie really didn't do the best it could have done.You might be saying "Well a lot of movie are CGI, what are you complaining about?" Yes they are, but they're also smoothed over so that (for the most part) you can't tell there's a green screen behind, in front of, or beside the actors. If this was all because the movie was under funded... then I could understand. I don't know if that's the case or not. Sigh.

Let me state that I have never reviewed a movie for this site before, but A Sound of Thunder is so terrible that I feel compelled to warn people.This movie fails at virtually everything it attempts. The adaptation, dialogue, acting, directing, visual look, CGI, everything is bad.The acting is horrible. I don't know what Ben Kingsley was thinking. He's normally does an excellent job, but he is constantly chewing scenery. If Kingsley, the best actor in this movie, is that bad, imagine how terrible everyone else is.The adaptation could not stray more from the short story and retain the writing credit for Ray Bradbury. I'm willing to bet Bradbury would be glad to have his name removed if it was used with his permission. The similarities to the short story are only the most essential. Even the logical plot points are altered or removed completely. None of the changes are for the better.There is no point in the film that I felt what I was supposed to feel. Major characters die and I did not feel loss. Jokes were made that I did not find humorous. Things that should have made me feel tense did not.There were green screen affects that were unbelievably bad. Conan O'Brien driving his desk uses a green screen on a less believable level, and that's about it.The CGI was some of the worst I have ever seen. A small child may be convinced by them, but no adult of normal intelligence could be. They stick out even worse than the terrible green screen affects. The dinosaur obviously had to be visible, but there had to be a way that makes it convincing. If Jurassic Park could do it 10 years ago, surely A Sound of Thunder could.The only positive thing I can say about this movie is that the Foley artist did a decent job for the ambient noise cretaceous era scenes.I could go on about how bad this movie is, but my words would never be angry enough to describe this movie. Do yourself a favor and avoid this at all costs.

I just got through watching this movie and I don't think it's as bad as I've heard everyone say it is. The special effects do leave something to be desired, and the time travel aspects might not appeal to those who need to have their movie follow the rules, but remember it is a movie and the reason why we love to watch movies is to enter another reality for a little while, and that reality doesn't necessarily have to have great effects or follow the rules of the space time continuum etc. You'll find this movie is similar to the movie butterfly effect in that one small almost insignificant change can lead to very significant consequences. An interesting thing about the story which was written by Ray Bradbury is that he wrote this story ten years before the phrase "butterfly effect" was coined and long before the scientific community understood the principle.

A sound of Thunder.Well, what's it about, a big thunderstorm? No,it's much more exciting then a big thunderstorm. From a big Allosaurus to reptilian monkeys to a BIG excitement. A big, mean underwater snake serpent monster. Now THAT'S what I call exciting. It was like nothing i had ever seen before, but it looked really realistic. The CGI on it was great. All of the creatures had good CGI but especially the serpentine snake. I thought it had a pretty good storyline. I can't believe so many people thought it was a screwed up mess. I mean,it could have had more dinosaurs but you can't let that rip you off your feet! the only thing I did not get was the name. It should have been called something like 'Past Creatures of the present'. The only reason I can think of why they would have called it that would be when the time waves kept coming or the few times the dinosaur roared. Anyway, back to the setting. One thing I liked was most of the movie was at night and I thought that made it more suspenseful. The only thing I wish they would not have made at night was the bats attacking the car scene because you really could not see the bats. The last thing I really did not care for was the reptilian monkeys. They were not the best creatures of the movie. Anyway, over all I give this Two thumbs up!
Don't analise it too much and it is a very good watch for anyone just looking for pure entertainment.

reviews.review_title: A good adaptation of a classic sci-fi writer
reviews.content: I have gone through and read quite a few of these comments. Quite a few were rather scathing, and some where slightly favorable.Let's be realistic here....what is the purpose of going to see a movie? It's to spend a little time away from the reality that we live in, enjoy (or hope to enjoy) a good story. If a person wants realism in a movie, then they should simply shoot home video's because you cannot get any more real than that.When I rented this movie, I rented it for the story concept and the writer that it was adapted from. I will admit that some of the special effects, like the vehicles moving around in the background, where a little hard to take in, however there were other things going on that I paid more attention to, like character dialog.In the short story, you've got the team going through to go on the hunt, same as it is in the movie. Then things go wrong, and in the end a simple butterfly is killed. Back in their correct time everything seems to be good, in the movie. The short story is different in that a new governmental regime takes effect. Ultimately, in both the story and the movie, they have to correct time by preventing that one butterfly from being killed.The movie adaptation of the short story allows further possibilities to be explored. It's one that I fully intend to pick up as soon as I can because I feel that it's that good.

reviews.review_title: Its B-Grade for adults, But A-Grade for kids!
reviews.content: Im pretty picky when it comes to movies, I cant help but spot inconsistencies and effects problems and it can let the smallest fault ruin an otherwise good movie for me. I end up spending the whole time looking for more issues or I just lose interest because of it. With this movie though, i knew it would be bad, so my expectations were pretty low. Another reviewer on IMDb said the special effects and acting were so bad that it made the movie good. This combined with a story line and subject matter thats right up my alley, then it had to be good! The movie actually wasn't AS bad as i expected though. Sure the special effects are bad, the acting at times can be way off and the script has some noticeable holes, but i couldn't help but think how much i would have loved this movie when i was a kid. Watching some of the movies i loved when i was a kid, its obvious that bad acting, bad writing and special effects glitches go unnoticed to kids, what matters is a fun action packed story that doesn't get too weighed down with details, character development and plot. reviews.review_title: Bad movie based on a bad short story
reviews.content: Time travel is probably the most abused trope in science fiction, especially sci-fi cinema. Since no one has ever time traveled, stories must fall back on logic. Both this movie and the short story it is based on left it out completely. The short story emphasized what has come to be known as "the butterfly effect" where tiny changes have a major impact the longer they are given to propagate, as though causality were simple ballistics. However, the author then turns around and permits a floating metal path through this incredibly sensitive jungle with hunters firing steel bullets into a dinosaur (or other animals on other safaris). One character is "punished" by giving him the job of retrieving the bullets from the dino carcass, but what about stray shots? How about the mere presence of the path disturbing the intended route of some other animal? (Perhaps an animal escaping from the target dinosaur, or even another predator.) How about the blood from the dino splashed on the hunters -- won't those few molecules be missed by the bacteria of the Cretaceous and have dire effects on the future that was? The story also explains paradoxes, and then invokes several.The movie is even sillier. NOT OF THIS EARTH was so bad it was funny. This movie was just plain bad. We have the same scenario as the short story, only multiple safari groups are taken back to shoot the exact same dinosaur! This is the "time happens again" notion in bad writing. So after something goes wrong, and our heroes return to their own time fully cognizant of how their world should be, "time waves" ripple through the world changing reality. Wait for it now -- As our heroes set out on their quest to fix what went wrong, someone points out that no one will remember after time is corrected! That's called having your paradox and eating it, too.Another reviewer was defending the time wave concept, but I see it as another symptom of the "time happens again" school of thought. That is, a time traveler alters history. The changes than take some measurable amount of time to catch up. Conceptually this "nests" one dimension of time within another. I'll leave the problems with this concept as an exercise for the student. The movie BACK TO THE FUTURE used time waves (and paradoxes), but I was willing to excuse it since the story had many other redeeming qualities. Logically, the only way to change history and live to tell about it is by using the quantum "many worlds" concept. If history can go one of two (or more) ways, it goes both ways, splitting off a new universe that is different only in that one alteration. The BACK TO THE FUTURE series invoked that one, too, and also messed it up.Assuming a single time line, paradoxes simply cannot happen; a writer cannot posit causality and also ignore it. Time travelers should remember that their very existence is causal, no matter how hard they try not to (or try to) alter history. THE TERMINATOR (without the sequels in tow) is a perfect example of reflexive causality. Time does not "happen again."With the above influence of time travelers in mind, the "touching the environment without touching it" isolation suits and floating path strikes me as a metaphor for Mankind and his environment. We're here and anything we do will have _some_ effect on the environment (meaning we're natural, too). Pretending otherwise is self-delusion. We can, however, choose to be a good or bad influence.

reviews.review_title: The VFX ARTISTS are the VICTIMS, and nobody knows the TRUTH...
reviews.content: Most of the comments talk about the visual effects: that they're poor, bad, or just worth laughing about. I recently bought "A Sound of Thunder" & wanted to see what this is all about. Surely I (usually watching movies with an eye on vfx) wasn't very enjoyed when I saw the visual effects in this movie, sometimes I even wonder how they actually made it into the final cut, but: As a visual effects geek, I did some investigations (mostly based on the information found here) and I have made several discoveries: - "A Sound of Thunder" seems to contain about 350 - 500 visual effects throughout the movie. - The movie was shot in Prague (as read in Trivia) and the visual effects were done by several companies spread out in Germany, except Furious FX, which only did about a dozen shots with monitor replacements and fix-its.Does that mean that the visual effects in "A Sound of Thunder" are so bad because they were done in Germany? No. Watch "Dreamship Surprise" or the television miniseries "Die Sturmflut", whose visual effects won several awards.I think the problem aren't the visual effects themselves but the approach of the production. Hoping to keep the costs low, they shot the film in Prague, and gave 95 % of the visual effects business to European fx facilities. Most of the European fx facilities, unlike the 100-200 large facilities in the USA, have only about 10-40/50 fx artists at work. Giving each of these facilities 80-100 shots (including some very complex shots which you'd normally assign ILM or Sony Imageworks for, the dinosaur for example), doesn't mean that you'll get sophisticating results. It's like if Lucas tried to produce "Revenge of the Sith" in the 1990, with a low amount of people and without all these developed sophisticating tools.Referring to another commenter on this movie, in which he tells that he saw no difference between the vfx at a preview, and those he saw when the film was released. Why? Remember the walking scenes in the city? Some might notice that the backgrounds are very sharp and contain no motion blur. Actually the company posted their work on its homepage (it's Black Mountain): The colors are accurate, and there IS motion blur. What is the difference? The shots in the movie are only HALF FINISHED.According to the trivia, the production company, when it's true, went bankrupt during the post-production. Therefore there AREN'T any new versions of these shots left over. The shots in the movie were either ACTUALLY FINISHED (the EASY vfx shots) or WEREN'T FINISHED AT THE TIME OF BANKRUPTCY... I finally come to the conclusion that the vfx shots' quality AIN'T THE FAULT OF THE ARTISTS; they're just VICTIMS in a series of unfortunate events... My voting is therefore a neutral 5 because after these investigations, I cannot judge the visual effects properly and concentrate more on people, story, and rest, which I would describe as mid-class work.I hope some of you, after this review, see this movie with a different view.

reviews.review_title: Have your cake and eat it? ( Spoiler alert !)
reviews.content: I have just finished watching the DVD of this film and have just a few comments. You are led to believe that all of time has been changed by a hunting trip 65 million years into the past. Evolution has been disrupted and the human race has not evolved. I understand that the changes in reality are occurring in waves, but when the last wave hits just as the main character is sent back to the past and you see what humans would have become,how come that the buildings are still there. If the human race never existed, then the buildings could never have existed either. The main hole in the story line though, (the "Have you cake and eat it" reference), is the fact that they keep going back to the exact same point in time with different clients to kill the same dinosaur, but never meet themselves there. Then at the climax of the film the main character goes back to the same point in time and interacts with the group who changed the time line. If he could go back and do this, why don't the hunting teams keep running into previous hunting teams? This seems to be the biggest hole in the story line,and in my personal opinion ruins the credibility of the story. I am sure that this story is based on a short story that I read years ago, but I can't remember how that one ended. I know that the only way for the story line to evolve was for the equipment that sent them back in time to continue to exist, but it's just a shame that they could not have thought up some reason to explain why things that should have not existed in the new time line did still exist. Sorry to rant on but these are my feelings!Gary

reviews.review_title: Not a great movie, but one to enjoy for sure!
reviews.content:
A Sound of Thunder is a fun, not too serious, and entertaining film. The movie itself is not great but it can be fun to watch and possibly be enjoyed as long as you don't go into it taking it too seriously. I say it shouldn't be taken seriously just because it's difficult to drag a short little story made many years ago into a full movie. So the fact that it can be kind of dragged out at times, combined with the god awful early 2000's graphics make it fun to maybe watch every once in a while, but nothing that will be considered in the movie hall of fame.This movie is called A Sound of Thunder based on the short story by Ray Bradbury and directed by Peter Hyams. The Warner Bros movie consisted of a cast including, Edward Burns, Jemima Rooper, Armin Rhode, Ben Kingsley, Catherin Mccormick, and many others. The movie was made in 2005 and received a pg-13 rating. You can currently watch the movie on Amazon Prime Video and Cinemax with your paid subscription. The basis of the movie is a greedy rich man who found a way to use technology in order to take rich people back in time and hunt prehistoric animals without changing anything or altering the future. This movie starts to explore what would happen if something went wrong and they did change the past.The movie is placed in 2055 where a man has used a time machine and founded a company that can make a lot of money off rich clients that are willing to spend a lot and go back in time. They go back in a time in a way that makes sure nothing is changed, they plan ahead right where a dinosaur is going to die, and they kill it then and there. There are many precautions in place but when something goes wrong they need to figure out a way to fix their mistake and make sure they can save humanity before the time waves cause humans to be extinct forever.
The concept for the movie based off the short story is a really fascinating idea in theory, but it can be difficult to drag out what was once a short story into a full feature length movie. Many things in A Sound of Thunder aren't great, but they aren't bad enough to make you want to just shut off the movie and never watch it. They tell the story well enough to keep you halfway intrigued and wanting to watch until the end, after all, it's only an hour and a half. Some of the movie's weaknesses are the acting, and the just terrible 2005 cgi. The best part of the movie is easily the concept, because nobody truly knows what would happen if we were to go back in time and change something, and this is an interesting way to showcase what could happen if humans were to obtain the technology to go back in time, and the biggest question of all being whether or not we should.Though the movie is by no means great, as long as you go into it with a positive attitude and not pick out the many plot holes you will be able to enjoy it. I would recommend this to just about anyone over the age of 10, because it could be fun to watch and a nice movie to be able to just sit back and enjoy for a bit while you relax. I enjoyed it just because of how the idea of time travel and changing the past is one that could be on your mind for a while. One question I constantly found myself asking was "If the past was changed and that also changed the future, how would the people in the present day realize that the past was changed because this is what they have alway known?" If you are ever bored and feel like seeing a stupid fun movie, this is a great choice.

I read the short story once a long time ago, so I don't really remember the plot details too much. But I thought that this movie was okay, even though it is only loosely based on the book.I did not like the fake-assed special effects and the constant cutting away to the city scene before going to the characters. It all reminded me of a not-to-bad made-for-TV-movie. I also did not like how it all degenerated into your typical monsters-are-chasing-us kind of thing.I had no idea about the budget or the rest of the production problems. And I thought the Ben Kingsley character was pretty neat.If you are bored and have nothing really to do, I would say go see this movie. It is okay.

The Sound of Thunder movie is based off of Ray Bradbury's short story called "The Sound of Thunder." If you are into weird poorly done sci- fi movies then this is perfect for you. It is a very strange B movie that sat on the shelf for 3 years. This movie has it all from bad CGI, bad dialogue and a cheap budget causes it to be a train wreck for all who watch it, but even with a cheap budget is it as bad as people say?
The Sound of Thunder is a movie directed by Peter Hyams. In 2005 The unrealistic film came out making only 11.7 million in the Box office. The main Actors, Actresses are Edward Burns(Travis Ryer), Catherine McCormack(Dr. Rand), Jemima Rooper(Jenny Krase), and Ben Kingsley (Charles Hatton). This movie is about a wealthy businessman who owns a time travelling safari. They take wealthy clients to hunt dinosaurs until one client gets a little too careless and his/her actions might come back and haunt the near future.
In the movie The Sound of Thunder takes place in the city of Chicago in 2055. A greedy businessman named Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsley) makes millions with his company, Time Safari Inc., this allows millionaire clients to travel back to the prehistoric era using a time machine computer and hunt dinosaurs. Regulations are put in place and monitored by a Government Agent (August Zirner) to make sure nothing goes wrong on any of their trips and so that the present time is not altered. On one of their trips one shaky client steps off of the path and steps on a butterfly. After this event happens it creates time waves which will change the present evolution starting from least evolved to most evolved organisms. They attempt to fix the past, but each attempt is harder on their already altered present day time.
After everything happens the team rushes to Eckle's (William Armstrong) apartment to search through his things to look for anything the group might have brought back. They know someone has taken something from the past back with them because one of the scientists noticed their weight coming back was heavier than their weight when they visited. This is a key part in the movie to trace back who might've caused the future to change after they strictly told clients to stay on the path.
This movie would be good for unsophisticated children, I bet they wouldn't complain about it as much as teenagers and adults. Like I described earlier this movie had a cheap budget and good CGI graphics cost money which is mainly why their graphics were bad. I did not hate the movie in fact I found some parts to be enjoyable, sure it definitely isn't the best movie of the 2000's, sure it's just a B movie that was poorly made and sat on the shelf for a while, but what's the problem in liking a weird old B movie it's not as bad as some people would say?.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as you may think (in my opinion)
reviews.content:
When it comes to the Movie A Sound of Thunder I like it which happens to be an unpopular opinion. As much as the movie did have many shortcomings in production despite all of it the movie was still very good in my opinion. After all they ran out of money twice and had to resort to less than satisfactory green screen moments; they still had a very interesting concept.
First off I need to establish some ground rules one: I like this movie´s concept, two: I don't care if you disagree with me this is my opinion, and three: I don't like everything about this movie but I feel in the end the good parts more than make up for the movies shortcomings. Now that's not to say that it didn't have some really bad moments because some moments were really rough for example the cars they have time travel but they don't have accident prevention software in cars like we do today even though they are set 35 years in the future.
In A Sound of Thunder there are a number of characters for example main characters like Dr Travis or Dr Rand while there are also significant side characters like Mr Middleton and Mr Eckles. And throughout the film the plot is fairly straightforward but still interesting at the same time. You know the typical go back in time change something you change the world but normally in other movies they don´t go back to the cretaceous period so normally we don't see massive changes like evolutionary changes so that is what makes this movie so much more focused on fixing what they did.
At moments like when they are hunting down Mr Eckles to find out what he did any normal person who also read the short story before would think that it was Mr Eckles who stepped on the butterfly but finding out it was his buddy Mr Middleton adds in a whole different view to his schple beforehand at the office. For me that moment was what made this movie so good. The original story was good, and they took the idea of time travel and ran with it almost completely diverting from the original story and normally you see great books turned into horrible movies because of copyright laws and whatnot but for me that was the reason it was good. Just the fact that they made a semi successful movie alone is impressive.
So in the end I don't quite know why so many people hate this movie, It's almost like they believe they need to hate this movie for some reason. I mean sure they had some rough green screens but those were few and far between. And for me those moments didn't discredit the movie as a whole.
