I want to go on and on about how terrible this movie really is, but i'm sorry, I just can't find the words... and I don't think it's worth it.If your'e not convinced, and are intent on undertaking the misadventure of watching this flick, then at least insist on being paid for your time. Free just doesn't cut it.Shame, shame, shame, and damn shame!

Granted the green screen walking and looping traffic was bad... The movie in general wasn't horrid like many posts suggest. I thought it was fairly entertaining. Certainly not an award winner - but for some simple Sci-Fi, Future-esk/Time/Creature flick its really not all that bad. The acting for most is good, the story is interesting idea, the creatures are decent.People can ( and obviously have ) debate the climate, creatures etc but to what end. The movie simply staged events for a story to unfold. Debating the realistic possibilities of a sci-fi film is kinda silly. Without some extreme events it would be pretty dull. It would also be a really long movie to get certain points across without the exaggeration of certain elements. I do wonder if the poor green screen stuff was intentional, since the animals were done fairly well I thought the look and motion of some was pretty good. I suppose a lot of the budget could have gone to CGI-Critters. If your the type of person who gets their stomach tied in knots, over details that wouldn't change the story anyway - then maybe sci-fi films in general are not your bag. But if you like to see different movie ideas just for the sake of entertainment. Then you wont mind this one.

If you've ever wondered what power hungry billionaires do in their spare time in the year 2055, the answer is go back in time to kill dinosaurs. How could that go wrong?
A Sound of Thunder (2005), directed by Peter Hyams, was written based off of the book "A Sound Of Thunder", written by Ray Bradbury. The movie follows a scientist working for a time traveling company, Travis Ryer, who studies extinct animals. This role was casted to Edward burns. His co-star Catherine McCormack plays Sonia Rand, who invented time travel and openly opposes using it. Together, the pair forms a team with Jenny Krase, Payne, and Dr. Lucas, respectively played by Jemima Rooper, David Oyelowo, and Wilfried Hochholdinger, to correct a fatal mistake that occured when Time Safari Inc. took a group of hunters back in time. Travis Ryers' (Edward Burns') group either works for or formerly worked for Time Safari Inc. under Charles Hatton, played by Ben Kingsly. Ryer's party has to battle evolution changes in the modern world while trying to figure out and correct the mistakes they made on their time traveling journey.
The opening scene shows Travis Ryer with Dr. Lucas and Jenny in the past with a group of hunters fighting a Tyrannosaurus Rex. After a successful hunting trip the team hosts an after party where Dr. Rand is introduced protesting the unnecessary time travel. This leads to a conversation between Dr. Ryer and Dr. Rand where the dangers of time travel are explained and the purpose of studying extinct animals behind it. Before Dr. Ryer is able to take his next team of hunters into the past, chemicals leak on the gun needed to kill the dinosaur. During the hunt, the guns fail to fire causing a panic, in which the hunters stray off the path, breaking the number one rule. This rule break is discovered in the next hunt, where the hunting party is sent into the past 5 minutes later than the scheduled time. Travis goes to tell Dr. Rand of the change in history, where he is exposed to the first changes of evolution and hit with the first time wave. Dr. Rand explains that since the past has been changed, different time waves will come altering the evolutions of different species, ending with humans. Dr. Rand and Ryer's team work together to try to find what the hunters changed on the trip, and how to fix it. While doing this, they have to fight off newly evolved creatures and plants and dodge around the time waves. Their mission is very time sensitive, as they have to find a solution not only before humans are evolved for good, but also doesn't create a never ending time loop.
The mechanics behind the effects of changing time is a unique idea and portrayal of creative superiority. This movie supports the theory of the butterfly effect, meaning that a tiny change in the past, i.e. the flap of a butterfly wing, could have a large impact on the future. After a small change is made in the movie universe past, separate time waves arrive changing evolutions of the species of the Earth. The first change is weather and plants, and gradually more organisms evolve into gory and deadly beings. The idea is that the last time wave will change the last evolved species - which is humans. After humans are evolved, there is nothing that Travis Ryer and his group can do to fix the future. How certain creatures are evolved is unique and creative to this movie. Having a mix between a gorilla and a velociraptor that sleeps upside down is definitely not like any other, and shows how creative the movie actually is. The concept of different time waves also gives a chance to see gradual change without it happening all at once. This can spark creativity in a reader's mind by wondering how other species of animals would evolve or how humans and human interactions would be different.
I would recommend this movie to people of all ages. If not over-analyzed and taken too seriously, it is actually pretty fun and enjoyable to watch. With the right mindset adults and kids alike can see the good aspects and humorous values. A golden property the movie holds is it's graphics. Attempting to make a dinosaur appear scary with the graphics of a poorly made mobile ad turn the scenes so ridiculous it is hard to not find the movie comical. Watching a group of heavily armed and outfitted adults whimper at the sight of an obvious and poorly CGI'd tyrannosaurus rex is an amusing scene. The film puts the dinosaur front and center on the screen, and pays no mind to acknowledge or cover up the poor graphics. A second humorous aspect to not be overlooked is the dialogue. In the scene where Payne dies, some toxic thorn he was struck with makes him go crazy, so as gorilla raptors are circling in on him he's laughing about the stars. His crazy banter has no relation to the movie and takes away the little emotional connection that might have been there. This, in a way, makes his death scene laughable. Also let it be noted that while the gorilla raptors were closing in on Payne, every angle switch of the camera set the gorillas back and dragged out the entire scene to a noticeable amount, making the death scene even more humorous. Just another showcase of the movie's superior graphics.

The movie A Sound of Thunder is different from most movies you will see. It brings us back in time to the future and has some interesting made up animals. It shows a different look on what could happen to technology that most people don't really think about. Although the writers had a lot of good thoughts for the movie, they were not very well executed. If you read the short story you will probably recognize quite a few differences right from the start of the movie. If you didn't read the short story, I definitely recommend reading it after this review.
A Sound of Thunder came to the theatres in 2005. The movie is based on the short story written by Ray Bradbury. Other writers include Thomas Dean Donnelly, Joshua Oppenhimer, and Gregory Poirier and was directed by Peter Hyams. Some main actors were Edward Burns, Ben Kingsley, August Zirner, Catherine McCormack, Jemima Rooper, David Oyelowo, Wilfried Hochholdinger, William Armstrong, and Corey Johnson. The rating for this movie is not very high and most people didn't give it over 5 out of 10 stars. The movie is about what could happen to people and technology.
In the movie a company got rich people to pay them a lot of money and in return they let people travel back in time to hunt dinosaurs right before they were about to die. The company made it very clear that when you go back in time to kill the dinosaurs you SHOULD NOT step off the path. If you brought something back or changed something from the past it could alter the whole future and life as we know it. But as most of us expected someone ended up stepping off the path and changed the present. Everything quickly started to change with time waves. Every time a wave passed them it would alter the present a little more until everything changed to how it would be if that change occurred in the past. The scientists have to work hard to try to fix what happened before the time wave hits that altered humans. They also had to find a way without having to be in a constant loop where they fix the problem but it just keeps happening so they have to keep fixing it.
I definitely think that the writers had a lot of good ideas for this movie but they didn't have enough time to fit all of their ideas fully into the movie. I think the writers shouldn't have used all the ideas and only use few good ideas to get the full effect of the ideas making the movie more enjoyable to watch. I also don't think that they should have mentioned that you couldn't go through time waves with the time machine. It made it very confusing to understand and just wasted time trying to explain it. They also added filling conversations that didn't have anything to do with what was happening. For example when Dr. Ryer and Jenny were walking on the sidewalk and Dr. Ryer asked Jenny who her boyfriend was. She was talking about him and then just said you don't know him. I think if they had a more intentional conversation or just cut that whole part out it could have moved the plot along and made room for better things.
I would not recommend A Sound of Thunder. I think it is just much better to read the short story. Overall the movie was kind of confusing and I think that the short story gave a much better message. Even if you're more of a movie person I don't think most people actually really enjoyed this movie. It had a lot of topics and conversation that didn't match anything that was happening. The movie also lost a lot of concepts and ideas leaving an unfinished feeling and just kept me wondering. The movie had a lot of holes and things didn't quite make sense. Most of the special effects were not good either. The animals all looked super fake and they couldn't even make the actors walking on the road look realistic. If you just want a movie to have a good laugh and you're not trying to take this movie seriously this is the perfect movie for you. On the other hand if you want to learn a good lesson and watch an educating movie I would not watch this one.

If you're looking to laugh, A Sound of Thunder is the right movie for you. No, you won't be laughing at a creative joke made by one of the characters, but at the awful special effects and the poor way the movie was put together. I feel bad for Ray Bradbury because his short story, "A Sound of Thunder", which was very insightful, was butchered by this film. The movie A Sound of Thunder which is supposably based off of Ray Bradbury's short story, was directed by Peter Hyams and the screen story was written by Thomas Dean Donnelly and Joshua Oppenheimer. The stars in this movie are Edward Burns (Travis Ryer) , Catherine McCormack (Sonia (Dr.) Rand), Ben Kingsly (Hatton), and Jemima Rooper (Jenny Krase). It was released in 2005 by Warner Bros. and is rated 4.2/10 stars on IMDb. The story follows Time Safari Inc., a company that uses a time machine to go back into the past and allows wealthy people to hunt dinosaurs. As something goes wrong during a jump in the past, the present, as a result, is altered and Travis Ryder (Edward Burns) and Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormack) have to figure out how to set it right. In the beginning of the movie Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormack), who created the time travel technology, warns Time Safari about the dangers of accidentally altering the past. Travis (Edward Burns) has succeeded in traveling to the past with many different groups of wealthy people, planning his trips down to the second. Everything had gone smoothly up until a particular group that included characters Eckels (William Armstrong) , Middleton (Corey Johnson) , and a faulty gun. All of the characters make it out alive, but they soon find out their trip had not gone as smoothly as Ryder's (Edward Burns) past excursions. The rest of the movie follows Ryder (Edward Burns) and Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormack), accompanied by some pretty horrible special effects, in their adventure to fix the past and set the present right again. Even though the movie was pretty bad I did like the concept that something so small could have an effect so large. It's crazy to think about that when the past is altered just a little bit it throws the whole course of the future off in such an immense proportion. I recommend that this movie be watched with a few people because it would be fun to laugh at and point out the flaws with someone else. The movie can be a bit hard to follow at times, so I wouldn't recommend it for younger kids, but almost anyone could watch and get a laugh out of it.

reviews.review_title: Truly Bluey a one of a kind movie.
reviews.content: A Sound of Thunder was a short story written in the 1950 by Ray Bradbury and I think he would be ashamed of the movie A Sound of Thunder. This movie was definitely an awkward movie that turns into a hot mess but if you're into that then it is your type of movie to keep on watching. If you go into the movie with an open mind, not looking for something serious, and just looking for a good laugh with some cheesy greenscreen and bad one liners then this is the right choice for you. But if your intent is to watch this movie with all seriousness keep moving because this movie is not for you and will make you wanna scream with frustration on how bad it is. Well the thought Peter Hymes the director had going into this movie was good it just didn't turn out the way anyone was thinking it was, with the absolut awful green screens and in some parts awful acting it turned the movie from being a good movie to being so-so in a quick second.Its 2055 when we are brought into the movie at Time Safari, Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsley) the big shot that owns Time Safari that allows rich people to get away from hunting the same old things that they are used to and go back into time and pick a pre- historic animal that they would like to hunt and kill. For this trip Travis Ryer (Edward Burns) takes the customers to shoot a dinosaur but Dr. Sonia Rand ( Catherine McCormack) The designer of the time machine wants Times Safari to get shut down because she keeps telling everyone at the company that if they keep going back into time they will mess something up in history and alter the world of today. But When they go onto this trip one of the hunters messes up and does something that alters the world forever, But if something is done fast they can go back in time and fix what was done to save the world. But they need to hurry soon because the time waves will start to come and everything after each wave will start to change and change drastically.¨The Sound of Thunder¨ By Ray Bradbury and the movie to this short story have some similarities but not a lot. The movie and the story both start off in 2055 in Times Safari and both go on a hunting trip but once they get back they take off on different paths. In the story we realize right away that something was brought back and that had changed everything. But in the movie it takes us about 5 minutes to realize they messed up and the world around them is changing. After they realize that they have a short amount of time before they can go back into time and fix the world before it is changed forever and there will be no way to fix it. Once they head out to find what caused all this change they run into a few big monstrous problems that set them back a lot.This movie was extremely good at one point making me laugh and the next point has me asking why I am watching this because it is extremely cringy. Travis (Edward Burns) And Dr. Rand( Catherine McCormack) kinda has this awkward love tension throughout the whole movie that makes you wonder if they will have a relationship after you know saving the world as we know it or if they were just being flirty to add some jazz to the cringy but yet funny movie. One part that stuck out to me in this pitiful excuse of a movie that I think is ironic is that once they get back to the time machine it's broken so right down the street there is another one at the college, Like how cliche is that. I think this movie could have had so much more potential but the absolute horrendous green screens made this movie drop to negative 10 out of 5 stars. I mean come on we can tell that they didn't know they have as good technology that we have today but in the city scene we watched the same 5 cars drive by on a repeat while Travis( Edward Burns) and Jenny(Jemima Rooper) walk and they look like they are just walking in place. And don't even get me started on the 1950s style in 2055.Now I know I completely dragged this movie through the mud and drove over it with a car, But honestly I really enjoyed the movie. I mean it got put on the shelf for 3 years and didn't get produced until of september of 2005. But if you can put behind some of the off putting scenes I think you will enjoy this movie too and it may even give you a good laugh like it did for me.

Future. For the rest of the film they have to try and stop what he did.Ray Bradbury's, A Sound of Thunder, is a very strange film based off of what you would expect from reading the short story. A very interesting storyline mixed with a low budget film and some pretty shaky visuals makes for a pretty unique movie.A Sound of Thunder was directed by Peter Hyams. The film's release date was September 2, 2005. Some of the most important characters include Travis Ryer (Edward Burns), Dr. Rand (Catherane McCormack), and Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsly). I would give this movie a 5 out of 10 star rating. The reason I took off two stars was because of the bad visuals/graphics. That was because the film had a low budget. Other than that the film had a very good storyline and used suspense to keep you interested. The film is all around the idea of the butterfly effect. Basically a small change in the past could ripple make a big difference in the future. That is what they tried to avoid doing but ultimately failed."A Sound of Thunder" was originally a short story written by Ray Bradbury. He made the storyline and did a very good job of keeping you interested. The story takes place at Time Safaris Inc. and they found a way to jump back in time, so they decided to start experimenting. They would keep repeating one jump where they killed a dinosaur. They were trying to avoid doing something that would change the outcome of the future (the butterfly effect). Like I was getting at earlier, the film definitely had some pretty sorry graphics. You shouldn't go into this movie with high expectations because you would be very disappointed. There were scenes where the background didn't match with the people at all and at some points it was actually laughable. Enough of me hating on the visuals let's get back to the storyline. They were told not to step off of the path but one of the hunters did. He ends up doing something that drastically affects the The problem was that the crew had no clue what he did wrong so they also had to find that. I think where they went wrong was spending too long trying to figure out his mistake. It got almost annoying with them trying to make the movie more interesting with the low budget and bad graphics they had. Some of the creatures they made up looked more funny than scary. Overall the short story written by Ray Bradbury did a better job of making you want more.I thought the butterfly effect being the main idea around this short story and film was very interesting. Although I wasn't by any means impressed with the CGI, the effort put into this movie was definitely there. I liked how they tried to build the movie around someone messing up the past and causing a huge ripple that affects the future. I loved the idea behind all of the time waves and the changes that came with all of them. I also enjoyed the random creatures that they made up. I don't know if enjoy was the right word there, maybe more along the lines of I had a laugh at them. Once again the effort was totally there but the CGI was just hard to take seriously. Lastly I thought that it was cool that they took the butterfly effect literally. The reason the future was changed is because one of the hunters stepped on a butterfly when they walked off of the path. I just found that kind of funny and I thought it was a nice touch.I would definitely recommend watching this movie. I already touched on this earlier but dont go into this movie with high expectations, because you might get disappointed. I would recommend this movie more towards adults because I could see this being a little confusing to kids. Some of the stuff in this movie even confused me. In the end, I would give this movie 5 out of 10 stars. Ray Bradbury did a great job of writing his short story but i believe they could have made a better movie out of it.

Was barely able to sit through it. Whose bright idea is to use this story, which has been beaten to death by most SF writers since the dawn of SF writing.The worst part was the total lack of emotions of the protagonists in the face of total annihilation of earth as we know it - they took is so very coolly, going about their work as if it was just another day in the office. I know this is how superheroes are supposed to behave - but so much of a carefree attitude makes the movie suck!All the actors seem totally nondescript, too, so there is no attraction to watch this one! Stay away from it!

Everyone loves to make fun of things that are just downright awful; it's human nature or something. Nothing about that changes with the movie A Sound of Thunder (2005) directed by Peter Hyans. If you're looking for a movie that doesn't require much brainpower to follow and would be great to laugh at with friends, this is the perfect movie for you. If you can't stand cheap, poorly made movies, I'd run the other way as fast as you can.
As a reader, when books or stories are made into movies, the thing that annoys me the most is when the creators think that they need to change a lot of things to make it a successful movie. This is one of those movies.
"A Sound of Thunder" by Ray Bradbury is a short story about time travel, technology, and the power of one's actions. A Sound of Thunder is a mishmash of horrible dialogue, cheesy CGI, and a myriad of plot holes. It's 2055, and a big-shot millionaire (Ben Kingsly) owns a company called Time Safari, where people can pay huge amounts of money to travel back in time to kill dinosaurs. Everything he does is primarily for getting more and more money. Meanwhile, a seemingly eccentric woman (Catherine McCormack) blatantly slanders Time Safari's little "time jumps", claiming they will destroy the world as they know it. Along for the ride is Travis Ryer (Edward Burns), a scientist (who is curiously brawny for his profession ) that leads these safaris.
So the group of hunters is on their way back in time to kill a dinosaur that would have been killed anyway. And one of them accidentally brings something back, which is very much against the "rules" of time travel. This incident causes a series of problems; ones that Dr. Rand and Dr. Ryer need to fix, of course. Thus, an exciting adventure is born, complete with strangely mutated dinosaurs, near-death experiences, and absolutely random, horrible dialogue.
Sounds great right? Honestly, if you can forget that this movie was made in 2005 and imagine it as a much older one, it's pretty enjoyable. Nostalgic even. That's one of the things I really enjoyed; it reminded me of memories of watching old movies with my family and laughing together. Another thing I liked was some of the creativity that went into this film. While there isn't much to go off of, the concept of the nitrogen bullets was really cool in my opinion. The guns the hunters would use had nitrogen bullets in them, which still kill as effectively as a normal bullet. But, they dissolve and are completely gone within two minutes after being shot.
In a different review that I had read, the reviewer said that you must be in a "generous mood" to watch this movie, and I wholeheartedly agree. This isn't a movie meant to impress, but it's a great one to make memories while watching. So if you're looking for a movie to laugh at, I recommend watching A Sound of Thunder.

Have you ever thought about how the smallest actions can alter our future, or wonder what it would be like to live as dinosaurs roamed the earth? The film A Sound of Thunder, based on the short story by Ray Bradbury delivers us a half decent film packed with action, time travel, not so special effects, and plenty of dinosaurs.
A Sound of Thunder is directed by Peter Hyrams, and you may recognise his name from several other science fiction movies. This 4.2/10 star reviewed movie was released September 5th 2005 and made over 11,000,000 dollars worldwide in theatres. Actor Ben Kingsly plays Charles Hatton, the owner of Time safari with Edward Burns and Catherine McCormack as Travis and Dr. Sonia Rand, the scientists that are trying to save the day. To put it simply, the movie is set in 2055 where a time travelling company offers to take the rich back to prehistoric times to hunt and kill a dinosaur, for the price of 10,000 dollars. On one of their missions something goes wrong, and changes the future on a huge scale.
The movie starts out with a group of hunters being led on a path through the jungle, but the green screen walking is just a little too obvious. Once they get back from the hunt they are warned by Dr. Rand (the inventor of the time machine) that what they are doing is greedy and could mess up the timeline of the human race. She was right of course, and the evolution of plants and animals since the prehistoric times started changing through a series of time waves. The time waves in my opinion were very cheesy and just didn't make much sense. Travis and the other scientist that work for Time safari, team up with Dr. Rand to try and go back to the past, to fix the present before the last time wave hits. As the team travels across Chicago and fights killer plants and primates, you can't help but notice the poor cgi animation of the half baboon/half lizard primates.
I think whoever wrote this movie tried to make it exciting and filled with special effects and action, but ultimately didn't meet the bar in the end. At every checkpoint the team reached, another poorly animated primate appeared, with essentially the same outcome every time. This I found extremely repetitive and by the end of the movie I was bored. It's almost as though halfway through the writing process, they ran out of plot elements and just decided to throw in another dinosaur or killer plant. But, I do have to give the movie some credit for bringing the story, A Sound of Thunder to life. This film provided somewhat good entertainment if you didn't focus too much on the negatives like the special effects, or think too much about what was happening in the movie. For example, why don't the hunters run into each other if they go back to the same moment in time, to kill the same dinosaur, and why don't the sound of the hunters' bullets scare off other animals, altering the timeline.
I wouldn't recommend for someone to go out and pay to see this movie. The positive of this movie is that you could watch it with younger kids. It's not too difficult to understand that the objective of Travis and Dr. Rand is to save the day, and they definitely won't be scared by any gore or special effects. I didn't enjoy this movie because it was repetitive, the plot drags on, and the special effects and cgi just weren't up to par for a Science Fiction film.

A Sound Of Thunder By: Peter Hyams is a science-fiction movie based off of the short story "A Sound Of Thunder" By: Ray Bradbury. The short story for "A Sound Of Thunder" was written is 1952, but the move A Sound Of Thunder Was filmed in 2005. This story was about the dangers of going back in time and how if you change one thing from the past it can change the future drastically.I watched the move A Sound Of Thunder and I would recommend it, personally I would give the move a 5.5 out of 10 star rating. The movie did not go with the short story fully but I believe it still got the point across that the written short story was trying to. The point was that anything you do in the past will affect the future, this I will explain more in the next paragraph. I think that the move A Sound Of Thunder added a few more details to try and intrigue the people watching the movie instead of having a vague and boring movie which I thought at certain parts was a good idea but at others were executed poorly. The main characters in the move A Sound Of Thunder where Travise (Edward Burns), Dr. Rand (Catherin McCormack), Jenny (Jemima Rooper), Payne (David Oyelowo), and Alicia (Heike Makatsch).The main characters had to try and stop the changes that were happening after something was brought back from the past. Things are changing because of something called the butterfly affect. The butterfly effect is that once one small thing changes it can make a large difference later on in the future. When the group when back into the past someone brought something back that changed evolution and the future. This caused the time waves and the main characters tried to go back in time again to fix what they messed up so it would be like nothing happened and they could go back to normal.In the movie there was animation with the time waves, creatures, cars, etc. With the budget they had they started to run out, and you could tell. Some parts of the animation weren't as well done or put together as other parts where. I understand that they started to run out of money but that was one of the parts that I didn't like about the movie. I feel like if they figured out how to spend there money more efficiently they could have made the move a little better. But I did like how they added a backstory to the characters unlike in the short story. I think that the backstorries made it more interesting and made you more connected to the characters. Connection to the characters is a good thing for a movie it makes you more intrigued to the movie and makes you want to continue watching.Like I said earlier, I did liked the movie. I liked how they explored the human relationship to ecology and the natural environment throughout the move. I also liked how the movie showed the impact of human interference in the environment and how easily something can be changed. Lastly I liked how there was a message being brought throughout the movie. And how they showed that tampering with time can lead a mistake changing everything even if there hasn't been any yet. But I think that the movie is more for adult or kids probably no younger than 10 or 11. Some parts of the move could be scary for they younger kids and I think that older kids or adults would connect, understand, and take interest the move more than the younger viewers would.

When I first read the short story version of "A Sound of Thunder" by Ray Bradbury, I originally thought the story was amazing. The story had an amazing plot, very good dialogue, and I understood what was happening as the story went on. So, thinking that the story is amazing, the movie has got to be just as good, right? Well...to be honest, the movie wasn't as good as I thought it would be. The movie "Titanic" had better quality than "A Sound of Thunder" and "Titanic" was made in 1997. What I do understand though, is during the filming of this movie, the production team had serious financial problems, resulting in the poor quality and dialogue.
A group of hunters go back 65 million years in the past in order to kill a dinosaur that has no future and no meaning 65 million years from that day. The movie "A Sound of Thunder" was published for the world to see in 2005, directed by Peter Hyams at Franchise Pictures. The main actors of the movie are Travis (Edward Burns), Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormak), Jenny Krase (Jemima Rooper), and Ted Eckles (William Armstrong). In "A Sound of Thunder", a team of time travelers travel 65 million years into the past to kill a dinosaur that doesn't have a future, and someone changes something in the past, that then changes the whole entire future when they return. I gave this movie a 3 out of 5 star rating because I understand that they had a lot of financial problems while filming the movie, resulting in the poor quality and dialogue.
At the beginning of the movie, Travis Ryer and his team are on a hunt for a dinosaur with a wealthy man and his daughter. After the hunt, Dr. Rand came in and sprayed blood out of a wine bottle in order to protest against Time Safaris use for time traveling and hunting. Travis has an interest in what she has to say, so he talks to her and finds out she's the one that created time travel and explains it to him while he confesses that he uses it for research on extinct animals. The next thing you see is some sort of chemical that leaks on Travis' gun he uses for the safaris. Travis and his team then go on their next hunt with Eckles and MIddleton, while on the hunt, Travis' gun gets jammed and they almost die, until the gun is fixed. After the hunt, Travis and others start noticing small changes like the weather and plant life, time has shifted by 5 minutes. When Travis goes to see Dr. Rand, he learns that time waves are occurring, and after another one hits, things start to get worse around the world. After learning what is occurring, Travis and his team plan on jumping back to change back what has occurred but he can't jump back far enough back in time. Another wave hits and makes things worse. There is no power to jump through the time waves and he needs to "slingshot" back. The team learns they brought back extra weight and there was "no bio-filter" in order to see if they ever brought something back. They go see Eckles, figuring he was the one that brought something back, and learns he wasn't the one who did. With everything being worse, they have to fight off creatures and monsters. They find out Middleton was the one who brought something back, he stepped on a butterfly. The team takes off to the time machine, and a flying creature takes off with Dr. Lucas. As another time wave hits, Time Safari is flooded and monsters take over, Dr. Rand takes them to her university to use another time machine with a portable hard drive. They then travel through a flooded subway and Jenny is taken by a serpent. Travis and Rand successfully get to the university, and Travis has only 20 seconds to slingshot and after the jump, another wave hits and Dr. Rand is turned into another creature. Travis warns Jenny on the safari with Eckles and Middleton and then he gives her the disc, and he stops Middleton from stepping on the butterfly. Travis then returns time to the way it is supposed to be, he then decides to stop time traveling, so this doesn't happen again. Travis returns to Time Safari before the jump. Jenny gives him the disc and he then gives it to Dr. Rand.
The part of this movie that caught my attention was the whole plot. The time traveling 65 million years into the past, the technology used to time travel. I liked that the movie was very visually descriptive. During the whole movie, I wasn't confused. I understood completely what was going on.
I would recommend this movie to someone who was extremely bored on a Monday afternoon and it was rainy. I believe a teenager around 13 to 17 would maybe be interested in this movie and then any adults would like this. I would recommend those age groups because I feel as if this movie would not be appropriate for a child to watch. I liked this movie because the plot and backstory of it kept me interested during the movie. I never felt as if I was going to be disappointed while watching.

Most pathetic piece of crap i have seen in a long time!! Me a big Sci-Fi Fan, was very very disappointed!! Man you people are way to frigging PICKY! Overall it was a very good movie. It was an EXCELLENT glimpse into an interesting 2055 Chicago. I pay attention to science stuff in movies and just frown when its wrong or stupid. This movie had fairly good science fiction in it. The look of the city was REASONABLE for 50 years into the future. The cars were electric and they should have been auto driven. You did notice that a car quickly decelerated and stopped when a pedestrian walked into the street. Thats normal for 2020. It didn't stop suddenly but quickly decelerated so the pedestrian and the occupant of the vehicle were both unharmed. That was carefully thought out. There were a few flying vehicles using heated air to levitate and were completely under computer control and stable. Very normal for that era. No folks, we wont all be flying around in hover vehicles. No frigging way to control the traffic and a collision would be fatal more that 2/3 of the time. But having a few hover vehicles would be reasonable. The buildings were not all too tall. I would estimate the tall U shaped one at around 2000 feet or so with very nice curved inner walls to reduce wind tunnel effects. Not a single building seemed stupidly designed. Thats a nice touch. The people who did this movie THOUGHT A lot about how the world of the near future should look like and this one rocks in that respect. I Don't buy cars going up walls in MINORITY REPORT. But i do buy the electric type vehicles here, along with the electric commuter trains and buses. The only complaint is a human driving the vehicles, ala the taxi cabs. Cars of any sort in 2055 will all be computer driven. Even cabs could have that JOHNNY CAB driver from TOTAL RECALL. Perfectly reasonable and DOABLE in 2020. Maybe even 2015. The laser mounted gauss rifles are perfectly reasonable. Now the short story this is based upon was a little CHEESY. This is way better. The thought of time correcting itself in waves is not all that unreasonable. As a matter of fact, TIME TRAVEL has been done today, although by todays' theorems, you cannot go back further than before your machine was built. (Things have gone back in time like microseconds in a laboratory, so far). Acting was fun and reasonable. I WAS NOT DISTRACTED BY ANY OF THE ACTORS. I got fully into the story. Now there were gaps here and there that you can overlook, but many many scifi movies ARE CHEESIER THAN ALL GETOUT. This one isn't. The temporal walkway was not unreasonable, the idea of killing a Dino just before he dies was not unreasonable. I'm sure they could see what was supposed to happen by watching it. It was unreasonable to kill the same Dino over and over tho. That was a goof, the teams cannot overlap, they would see one another. BTW, that huge hard drive they carried probably had eta-bytes of date on it. Haha. The idea of time displacement coming in waves was exciting and well done. I don't necessarily buy into it but it made the movie move along in a nice way. Guys, read the short story by Ray Bradbury. Its WAY CHEESIER that this movie. This movie takes it and fleshes the story out big time.Its a shame none of you folks liked it. It was a very enjoyable movie with science that was thought provoking and interesting to see. No, its wasn't perfect, but the questionable science was not distracting.

reviews.review_title: Nice expansion on Ray Bradbury's Short
reviews.content: A long time fan of SciFi writer Ray Bradbury, I was interested to see what twists and changes were used to create a feature film from a short story. (Most movies created from short stories seem to fall flat). I was very pleased to see that they maintained a strong connection to the plot of the original story, with plausible updates to make the futuristic world believable. I think the effects were decent; I'm more interested in the story than the eye candy effects. I thought that the acting, story, and action were okay. I especially like the ending of the movie much more than the ending of the original short story. Overall, I enjoyed the movie and even watched it twice (on HBO), but was surprised that I had not heard that this movie was in production. Thanks to the IMDb web site info to learn of the financial woes that severely limited advertising and finishing of the film: That explains a good bit!

A Sound of Thunder was directed by Peter Hyams and produced by Franchise Pictures. This movie was released on september 2, 2005 and was filmed in the Czech Republic. A Sound of Thunder received a 4.2/10 rating and has a run time of 1hr and 50min. This film is basically about a company called time safari that brings people back in time to hunt extinct animals.The movie starts out when they're on a hunt. Led by Travis Ryer(Edward Burns) who is the leader of the hunts and a scientist.we are introduced to Dr. Rand(Catherine McCormack) who created Tammy(the time machine) and protests its use due to the fact that it could alter time if something were to happen. This story deviates from the short story by Ray Bradbury as in, the story continues even after the material from the short story is exhausted. Something goes wrong on one of the hunts and they spend the rest of the movie trying to fix what went wrong.I feel there is only one thing about the movie that is somewhat okay and that's the fact that it seemed like the actors knew this was a bad movie and just basically tried to play it off. None of this dialogue is even remotely serious, when they talk it almost always sounds comedic. Especially Travis, who almost sounded sarcastic with every word he said. reviews.review_title: Excellent movie, if you're doing nothing for the next hour.
reviews.content: Whether the movie is good or not is up to the watcher's opinion. Even though A Sound of Thunder has received a lot of hate, it too, has received just as much love. In my opinion it was an excellent movie, if you're doing nothing for the next hour.For being based on an amazing short story of the same name, it lacks amazement. The scifi element stays, but what should have been called The Time Waves or The Ripple Effect instead spits on the original story. As many good actors are in the film: Payne (David Oyelowo), Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsley), and Dr. Travis (Edward Burns). For the script and scenario that were given, their acting was great. It wasn't the actors fault that the writer didn't want the watchers to have a connection with the characters. All that was needed was for the watchers to build a connection with the characters.As a nerd and a lover of random facts I found myself jumping up yelling stuff like "that's no butterfly, that's a moth!" I feel like most of humanity looks at something and takes it literally, but if people would just sit back and watch something with the mentality of "Three different people took the time to search all of this knowledge and try and implement it into one film." As long as you see this film with a surrealistic point of view and not a literal one, you will enjoy this film. Don't take any of it for fact and instead, think of the film as a false scientific theory.One of the most important and contradicting moments is when Dr. Rand (Catherine McCormack) is explaining the "slingshot jump" and breaks the only rule of time travel.All in all the movie was good; just not researched well. I do believe deep down in my heart that the film, actors, special effects, and attempt of a scientific theory were good, but the script and storyboard was not.

reviews.review_title: A team of time traveling hunters and scientist are able to make the worst movie of the new millennium
reviews.content: This was one of the WORST movies I've seen in a long time. In critical analysis of any literary work, technically that what a movie is, a person should try to identify the good the bad and then formulate a thoughtful opinion. This movie was sooooo bad that any good points to be made are far out weighed by the sheer lunacy of the story. After watching the movie five questions presented themselves: 1.) Why was everyone in the movie an a-hole, each of the main characters, at some point, has some obnoxious or snarky comment for someone else. 2.) How was it possible for the team to jump back to the same point in time without running into teams from previous trips? 3.) How did the Baboon/reptile survive and evolve without any knowledge of them by the people who live on earth, I mean the characters seem totally taken aback by these creatures, if it took them millions of years to evolve should someone have noticed? 4.) If the "time waves" were causing the history of the world to change or regress how did the buildings or other man made structures survive into a future that never happened? 5.) Why was this movie named "A Sound of Thunder"? It was based on a Ray Bradbury short story, maybe the title had meaning in the short, but in the movie it makes no sense. This was a terrifically bad movie, I wish I could sue to get compensated for the time I wasted watching it, I am going to want that time back on my death bed just so I can lay in silence or just look out of the window, which would probably be better than this movie.

The on screen talent was mediocre to bad. The script is pointless! And, after spending 30 minutes punching holes through the storyline wide enough to drive a semi through, my girlfriend pointed out that the story's fundamental premise is, in truth, fundamentally flawed. The only sound this movie makes comes from the nasty bowels of the movie industries surplus equipment and time. Pew!!!

I expected an adaptation of the Bradbury short, and it started like an average re-tell of the story: a group of time tourists modify history and the world experiences a literal Butterfly Effect.However, where Bradbury ends his novel abruptly when the protagonists discover their mistake, this movie goes further and explores the consequences - and the heroes' thrive to fix the mistake.From then on, the movie follows the same plot as another story I had already read, Stan and Vince's Vortex. More exactly, its volume 6, where the two heroes are stuck in a New York hit by time shock waves which de-evolve everything because of an object they left in the past. Human retrograde to apes, and later on to amoebas. The movie only slightly modifies this concept (the object is taken from the past, like in Bradbury's short; de-evolution is affecting humans last). In fact, the last scene before the time jump, with the heroin now a big fish, is taken directly from Vortex.Overall I did enjoy the SF contents, and the general effort. But, let's face it, it's not a good movie. It's let down by the special effects (it looks like a 1999 computer game) and the acting (the main character has a weakling's voice).And, above all, it does not credit Stan and Vince for their story.

A good sci-fi movie but with some flaws -- This was a decent sci-fi movie, and I've seen quite a few time travel shows. (Small spoiler here) You have time tourists who are warned that the slightest interruption in the past can cause a cascade of disastrous repercussions in the future. Here, the changes in the evolution of nature don't come immediately but instead through a series of time waves. The acting and special effects were good too.

This is certainly better than the effect in Ray Bradbury's original story "A Sound of Thunder", where stepping on a butterfly 65 million years ago only caused a change in the outcome of a Presidential election. Now that's too much of a stretch.

My main problem with the movie, as a scientist, is that the movie completely overlooks the mass extinction of the dinosaurs. Any interference with the evolutionary time line the travelers made during the age of the dinosaurs would have been greatly impacted by their mass extinction around 65 million years ago. However, no mention is made in the movie of the effect the mass extinction could have had on ripple effect caused by the killing of the butterfly.

	"A Sound of Thunder" the movie directed by Peter Hyams. With a budget of 80 million dollars beautifully shown by the horrendous special effects. Released in 2005. Main actors including Edward Burns,Catherine McCormack,and Ben kingsley who must have lost a bet and this was the consequence. 
	Many people think this is a "bad movie thats fun to watch" and i agree its a bad movie but "fun to watch' is extremely debatable. My brain was going 100 miles per hour trying to figure out what was actually happening. Almost nothing is explained properly and i honestly don't even think the writers really knew what they were doing as when you ask Dr.Rand what shes talking about she just uses big words to rush past the topic and everything goes over your head. Another thing is multiple weak story lines. I think in an attempt to make the movie more interesting they really just made it worse. Its like they tried to shove to many big ideas into one movie. They have so many cliches in this movie to like the whole corrupt business, stolen idea,and don't forget your classic genius ex-marine whos really just in it for the research. If they were trying to make it less like the book they did exactly that in the most terrible way. If i was Bradburry i would've taken back the rights and not even let them associate this movie with the book none the less let them name it after the book. 
	Lets start with our main character Travis Ryer.The classic adventure movie main character. Hes the head of the crew and is always there to shoot something or call out a random fact. Hes also just in it so he can research the dinosaurs.Then we have Dr.Rand who really thought of the whole "jenny" thing who is like Siri but better? Were introduced to this lovely character when shes screaming like a mad man in one of the first scenes because Hattons going to ruin the world and stole her idea blah blah blah etc. Shes the one who really is like the mastermind behind everything. Hatton is the corrupt business owner who runs the whole time safari thing. In the rest of the crew we have a doctor, a mechanic person and a camera woman.Id take the time to go over them but you wont have to worry about them. Without focusing on the after thought storylines the story comes down to this. Two men take a safari with the crew back to the dinosaur ages and step on a butterfly therefore changing the future. The rest of the movie is the crew trying to fix that immeasurable mistake with time traveling. 
	I think one of the only things that this movie got right was the idea that wildlife and nature would be thriving without the current evolution of humans. I mean when you think of evolution you think of that one weird photo with the chimpanzees slowly turning into a human but then we magically turn into fish people? Im no scientist but that doesn't add up. I honestly think the outcome would have been better if Travis had failed to time travel correctly and save the current evolution of humanity. I mean without all of the people going insane and everyone trying to shoot anything that moved that world would have been doing magnificently without the pesky little humans.

A Sound of Thunder by Ray Bradbury is an amazingly well written short story. Yet the film…. It's like the Jar Jar Binks of movie history. Horribly, Stupidly, Annoyingly...Funny? With the right sense of humor and standards of course. 

           The short story is about a company for wealthy people to go back in time and hunt a dinosaur that was already meant to die minutes after so it would not mess up the timeline. The short story holds suspense through the entire thing. It even ends in suspense. There is no real relief. In the film, they stretched out the story and added in some hilariously unreasonable and unneeded details.

              This film is hilarious..ly bad. But, if not taken too seriously, this film is amazing. To take a short story and stretch it into a 2 hour film, it was very well done especially with a limited budget. The green screen and graphics were pretty bad, but what do you expect? This film sat on the shelf for far too long. It was very enjoyable and had a very cool story line. To the realistic issues (animals like lions going extinct and the serious issues in messing with time), to the obvious plot holes and fictional creatures.

              There is some cheesy comedy that you can't help but laugh at. If you walk into this film expecting graphics that would actually be available in 2055, you will not take any pleasure in watching this film. It gets to the point where there are SO many plot holes, unreasonable creatures, venomous vine thorns, and time waves that wreak havoc on the entire city, that you just have to sit back and laugh and the epic horribleness. 
		I would give this movie 3 1/2 stars for the unreasonable, yet hilarious events. I would suggest this movie to a friend if they were having a bad day or if I just wanted to mess with them. Definitely not a person who takes everything, especially films, seriously. There are definitely worse movies out there. I'll cut this one some slack.

The movie, A Sound of Thunder by Ray Bradbury is a terrible movie. From the editing to the dialogue, it was a pitiful attempt and sorry excuse for a movie. In this review you will find out why it is a terrible movie.
	The movie is, A Sound of Thunder is directed by Peter Hyams and came out in 2005. The studio, Franchise Pictures Crusader Entertainment Baldwin Entertainment Group Etic Films Forge QI Quality International. The main characters Travis Ryer (Edward Burns), Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack), Jenny Krase (Jemima Rooper), Charles Hatton (Ben Kingsley), and Dr Lucas (Wilfried Hochholdinger). The movie is about a time travel machine being used for a hunting safari, and how it can affect the future drastically.
	The basic plot of the movie is that Charles Hatton is a money greedy man and tricked Travis Ryer into a contract so that he must bring people on these time travel hunting parties. Sonia Rand tells them that if they continue they will cause discourse in time. Well eventually they do end up messing up and they have to try to go back in time to intercept the hunting party. 
	A big moment in this movie that really threw me off and kind of ruined the movie for me is the bad logic behind the movie. They always go back in time to the same spot to hunt the same dino, but never meet the other hunting parties. But at the end of the movie he can stumble into their hunting party and save the day. It makes zero sense and it was kind of frustrating to watch. If the movie was consistent it would have been a lot better, just tying up those loose ends with a little dialogue would improve the movie quality drastically. If they would have taken out that excruciatingly terrible scene of the sewer monster (Which I think was a Pokémon?) and that horrible CPR attempt, they could have had a 10 minute segment near the beginning of the movie where they are explaining the time travel to the buyers and tie up all the loose ends. The movie was terrible and it had a lot of wasted potential. 
	I do not recommend this movie to anyone unless they want to see a fine example of a waste of $80,000,000. I may sound harsh here but I think a 14 year old with 80 million dollars and Power Director could make a better movie than this studio did. All of the monsters looked like copy pasted models with bad editing. A lot of great movies came out in 2005 and this was just not one of them. Even if they didn't have the funding for good CGI the dialogue and logic was atrocious. Here is an example, Sonia says that humans would be the last affected by the time waves because we are the last to evolve, which is not true at all. I learned in 9th grade that everything is constantly evolving and the script writers must have missed that day in school. If you decide to watch this movie after this review don't expect anything special. I wonder what Ray Bradbury thought of this horrendous movie. Use the 2 hours of your life to work on something important or watch something else.

"A Sound of Thunder": smart premise, dumb movie. It's 2055 and humanity has perfected and commercialized time travel. For a significant fee, the wealthy get to hunt dinosaurs courtesy of Time Safari Inc. The trips are set under very specific rules to avoid altering history. The hunters are brought along with a team to the past, where they find an Allosaurus (a large, meat-eating dinosaur similar to the Tyrannosaurus). As it wanders in a tar pit, moments away from certain death at the hands of a volcanic eruption the team emerges from a portal. Using frozen nitrogen bullets, they kill the animal, tape the whole thing as a souvenir and return to the present. They travel on an invisible floating path (Sort of like a force field) to ensure that they do not disturb anything else because even the smallest change in the past could have titanic consequences in the future! On one such excursion, something goes wrong. The weapon held by the lead member, Travis (Edward Burns) malfunctions and in a panic, the two businessmen being escorted by the employees of Time Safari are left unattended for a few moments. Travis manages to get the weapon working again, kills the dinosaur and everyone makes it back to the present. Travis notices a day later that the present as we know it is changing. When he asks the inventor of the time machine software, Sonia Rand (Catherine McCormack) about it, she tells him that the only explanation for the changes and the malfunctioning computer at Time Safari is that someone has made a change in the past. The alterations are small at first but within a couple of days we've got a new species of deadly plants engulfing skyscrapers, cities being torn apart, swarms of killer insects, packs of carnivorous dinosaur descendants attacking humanity and it's only a matter of time before the human race as we know it ceases to exist completely. The team at Time Safari, along with Sonia must find a way to return to that fateful trip that went wrong and prevent whatever changed everything from happening.
When you hear about the premise of the movie, it actually sounds pretty awesome. We've got a dinosaur safari, time travel, killer bugs, killer plants and some pretty high stakes. What could go wrong? The biggest flaw with the film is that it's nowhere near as intelligent as it should be and is riddled with scientific errors. There are many theories on how time travel should work but from the premise, you can tell which one this story is going with. Time travel is possible and furthermore, you can alter the past and the present without blowing up the universe or accidentally erasing yourself from history. Unfortunately, this movie plays so fast and loose with its own rules that it becomes an incomprehensible mess. Towards the middle of the movie, we learn that Time Safari actually escorts its customers to the same Allosaurus every time. Makes sense, because how many dinosaurs about to die by volcanic eruption are there really? But wait, that doesn't make any sense. Think about it. If customer A shoots down the dinosaur, then customer B would have to arrive earlier to ensure he/she can arrive before the dinosaur dies. But that would change the present because customer A would find itself in the presence of a very dead dinosaur when it arrived in the first place. If it's possible to kill the same animal over and over without affecting history, how is it possible that this one trip actually changed anything? On a side note, how lame is it that when you go back in time and shoot down a dinosaur, you're shooting down the exact same one as everybody else, under the exact same circumstances as everybody else?
Let's move on from that moment of nonsense. Let's just say "ok, they made a mistake, just ignore that one". But the movie is filled with events and plot elements that make no sense. Let's say you find yourself in this situation where time is being altered.  Maybe what you would do is... travel back in time a couple of days before the trip that went wrong and prevent the whole incident from happening by making sure those guns work ok, or maybe leave yourself a note? That would be the smart thing to do, but it's not what they do in this movie! This is nonscience-fiction! Our team of geniuses decide that to change the past, they need to go back to the exact moment where things went wrong, observe it and then fix it. Seems to me that it would be way easier to just not go on the initial problematic trip than to go back in time, way back to the time of dinosaurs and risk accidentally erasing something important from history. To further demonstrate how stupid this movie is, look at the way that the changes appear in the present. When the changes happen, it's described as a "time wave", it's a wave of changes, ripples in history that affect each other. These changes increase in severity as more and more of these small modifications pile up and affect the flora and fauna of Earth. Humanity is suddenly stuck in a world it doesn't understand because of something that was altered in the past. We're told that humans are the last species to be affected because "We're the last species to evolve". Did the writer even understand how evolution works? Living things do not have a predetermined "final evolution" like in Pokémon. Each generation is constantly adapting to its environment as climates and food supplies change. Successful species procreate while natural selection eliminates mutations that create undesirable or inefficient designs. You can never know how something is going to evolve, it just sort of happens. Maybe if the reason we are not immediately, physically affected was that we were the cause of the change that would make sense, but this explanation just makes anyone who knows anything about biology want to dash their head against the wall. Towards the end of the film, we actually do see humanity change into something completely different from what we're used to, but it just goes on to create further problems with the plot. If humanity evolved into a race of fish-like creatures, wouldn't our civilization be... underwater instead of on land with the same cars and buildings we have now? I guess the ripples in time only affected history in a way that we still got every single development in human the past (otherwise, you know we probably wouldn't have invented the time machine in the first place).
Aside from the mistakes in science, it just isn't very cleverly set up as a story. It's the kind of film where when the whole world is coming to an end, this team of experts never think of contacting the police or the army for some help. Despite the fact that our heroes are being attacked by a flock of bat monsters and may hold the entire future of the human race in their hands, they just decide to take this mission on by themselves. This team of experts who are in no way qualified to handle the kind of action they find themselves in just decide to go gung-ho and explore the city on their own to save the universe. They're not even clever enough to carry weapons with them at all times. It's a movie where things often happen not because they make logical sense, but because the plot demands it. We get a scene were we see a woman get eaten alive by these carnivorous bugs (which never appear in the movie again). Seeing this, Travis and Sonia jump out of her apartment window, landing in a tree. This tree is as tall as a skyscraper though and the two of them must have been at least on the 10th floor. How did Travis, who initiated the jump know that the time wave that just passed was going to conveniently place a tree branch there and that they weren't going to fall to their deaths? How did later in the film, that sea monster know to break through the glass just at the right moment so it could snap up a secondary character in a dramatic fashion? How convenient is it that the hard drive powering the time machine also happens to be compatible with the particle accelerator used at the university nearby and that they can turn this particle accelerator into a time portal?
On top of all these problems, the special effects for this movie are terrible. You can give a lot of slack to a movie with a low budget if it's really smart or if it's older, but this train wreck was made in 2005 and the special effects look like they're from a cheap documentary about dinosaurs that aired on TV during the 90's. Right from the beginning of the movie you see the Allosaurus emerge through a forest of trees, which fall over like dry, wooden sticks without a single leaf on them. Even worse, this clip of the Allosaurus is repeated again whenever the team travel back in time so if you thought it looked bad once, here it is again, and again! In the present, the cars look needlessly futuristic. More like shoes or tissue boxes with wheels than vehicles and as our characters talk on the sidewalk, not a single one of them slows down, stops or drops off a passenger. Not only does it look cheap, but the movie is unimaginative. The "Time Wave" mentioned earlier is literally a wave that encircles the glove and makes changes to the environment. The way we are introduced to this time wave is completely nonsensical by the way. Sonia tells him to look out the widow and he sees it pass through the city. Apparently she has psychic powers that allowed her to know this was coming and no one noticed this enormous time-distortion passing by during the previous 24 hours. Why do the changes happen every 24 hours by the way? Do chronological anomalies work 9-5 jobs like humans do?
The story is filled with clichéd characters. Ben Kingsley (one again in a terrible film) plays an amoral businessman, who delights his clients with talks that would make snake-oil salesmen blush. While he is able to charge pretty much anything he wants for these trips, he is still looking to cut costs and corners... at the expense of all of humanity! Meanwhile, Sonia is the scientist that mourns her invention being used for commercial uses. Don't they see that tampering with time will eventually result in death to us all?! Maybe people would take her more seriously if she hadn't wasted countless hours programming the time machine's computer with a sassy attitude. Our main character Travis is incredibly bland. We get a few scenes early on when he tells the audience and Sonia what he's all about but quickly degenerates into a typical action hero. Everyone else, forget about them, they're about as animated as the dead Allosaurus.
It's a movie where humanity is unable to fight off a race of carnivorous baboon-like dinosaur descendants. These animals are not any more intelligent than you standard lion or other large carnivore but when the stuff hits the fan here, it hits it so hard the whole world forgets everything it knows and devolves (not literally) into cavemen. It's a movie that looks bad from the beginning but gets worse and worse as it goes along. In a way, it's a perfect analogy for itself. A small mistake in the beginning of the production, a single person who didn't understand the intent and ideas behind the original short story stepped in the wrong spot and created these waves of problems, which only increase as the story goes by. It would be a terrific bad movie if it wasn't for the fact that it's extremely boring to watch. You just want it to go full throttle into idiocy and become a bad action movie with killer baboon-dinosaurs but it insists on trying to have some brains. If the concept interests you, just read the short story or even watch that old Simpsons Halloween special where Homer has a time-travelling toaster. "A Sound of Thunder" wants to be an action-packed adventure science-fiction movie with a brain, but it's simply a bad movie. (November 29, 2013)

Somebody's got to defend this movie, by gum, and I guess I'm the man for the job! Yes, it does have some obvious green-screen and rear-projection work, and yes, the Tyrannosaurus Rex that figures in the opening action sorta looks Somebody's got to defend this movie, by gum, and I guess I'm the man for the job! Yes, it does have some obvious green-screen and rear-projection work, and yes, the Tyrannosaurus Rex that figures in the opening action sorta looks like he needs to be returned to Macy's in time for the Thanksgiving Day parade, but who says every movie involving dinosaurs has to be visually on a par with or beyond Jurassic Park? One person's "shoddy and unconvincing" can be another person's "charmingly old-fashioned", and A Sound of Thunder is still eons closer to vintage Ray Harryhausen than to Bert I. Gordon. And some of the visuals really DO work: the various creatures that attack our heroes, heroines and bystanders in the altered future are far more imaginative and variegated than the CGI-wallpaper that enveloped Stephen Sommers' godawful Mummy movies; the filmmakers' version of downtown Chicago (which I recently visited) 50 years hence is surprisingly witty and well-observed; and I loved the solid/transparent/flowing "pathway to the past" that visitors took in order to hunt and kill a prehistoric beast. Director Peter Hyams has been doing mostly sci-fi and action flicks for over 30 years now; like fellow warhorses Richard Fleischer and the late J. Lee Thompson, his stuff can be remarkably pretentious, badly conceived and dull (remember 2010, possibly a leading contender for the most uncalled-for movie sequel ever made?)...but like those other two craftsmen, he's also perfectly capable at turning out a nifty, enjoyably fast-paced entertainment. Nobody's going to rank this with Gandhi or House of Sand and Fog as containing one of the all-time great Ben Kingsley performances, but he's very amusingly hammy as the greedy, duplicitous proprietor of the potentially dangerous time-travel device--his amusement park capitalist is actually much closer to the conception of same in Michael Crichton's original novel Jurassic Park than Richard Attenborough's teddy-bear interpretation in that film; Ed Burns isn't exactly in my Top 100 as viable action movie heroes go, but since every moment he spent filming this was one he WASN'T spending writing or directing one of his allegedly true-to-life, annoyingly twee romances like The Brothers McMullen or She's The One, who's to complain? Again, I don't see much point in griping about ANY of A Sound of Thunder if you view it in the right perspective: a 12-year-old watching it in 1957 would think it was the coolest movie in the world. And even though part of this has to do with Warner Bros. treating the film like something it found on its shoe and waiting THREE YEARS to release it, the fact that it's a movie version/expansion of a piece of literature (a beloved Ray Bradbury short story) in a summer even more filled than usual with sequels, remakes and equally unnecessary TV show adaptations, in itself makes A Sound of Thunder kinda cool, too.
